content:
Posted: September 30, 2015
Early Access Review
								So this is the squeal to the Dungeon Defenders series. let's start with pros and cons and give it an equal side.Pros+ LOOT, this is the life force of the game, there is SO much awesome loot.+ Fun game-play with multiple classes you can build or jump on you hero and smack things with a sword, or other weapons.+ Players can be creative with the classes and builds, so you can play your way.+ Large multi player base, Lot's of people playing and it's easy finding a group of people to play with for anything.+ Don't like Multi Player? With one of the recent patches/changes the game has been re-balanced for single players so you're not punished for wanted to play alone!+ A daily quest system that can hold 3 quests! This mean each day a quest will be given, the game will hold 3 for you so you don't have to play every day.+ Don't like a daily quest because it doesn't fit your play style? Or maybe you just don't wanna do it? Then you can re-roll!+ The monthly quest system introduces major rewards making them feel they are really worth doing.+ With how the new item system works alot of gear now introduces abilities and effects to your towers will gives way for more interesting play, frost towers being able to buff the damage of other towers, or having your harpoons explode on each and every target as they pierce the horde of monsters.+ Many maps and modes to play on, you can hit the hard maps for the godly gear or play the normal maps to relax and just bank up your coins and pets.+ Did I mention pets?!! You can find eggs during matches and then take them back to the tavern to be hatched! Pets can do multiple things for you from giving you a boost in stats, damaging the monsters you fight to having a an ability that assists you or damages enemies and there are lots of abilities.+ NO PAY TO WIN  at all Trendy has made it their goal to do this, all micro-transactions are skins for pets,heros and (planned) Tower skins! So towers will look different and have different animations, oh and bags let's talk about bags.+ Trendy has recently introduced a system where you can now Auto gather to specific bags and auto sort with them to keep your cache of loot neat and tidy! You can also customize your bags icons/names to what you want making organization a breeze.+ It may not seem like it, but the developers read every scrap of feed back people offer for the game, the forums are incredibly active and the developers do listen and will partake in the forums and chats, sometimes you may even run in to a white named person in a game and play with em!+ Every week they have a Developer cast on twitch to show case some of the new features, talk to the players, get feed back and improve the game, they will also answer various questions from chat and forums. The developers are really active in the community. + Vibrant art style full of colors and awesome effects.Cons every game has em.- The loved lobby system is no longer, we can no longer scroll through a list and see a list of players playing what maps and what levels they may be or modes they may be running, you just kinda go in to a tavern and go to the war map and join a game based on map and mode, and if there are others playing it will put you with them, if there isent any then it will create a new game for you.- No offline single player, this will effect some more then others.- The RNG in this game is heavy, some times you just want that one item with those beastly tower stats and all that drops is hero skill gear.-The game is currently in alpha, so bugs and other issues are to be expected as well as changes, this may include wipes or changes to the core of the game, so once you get a feel for the game you can lose everything you thought you knew due to the changes,-The pet skins the only negative thing about this is the fact you have to buy and apply a skin before knowing what rarity the pet will be so its a gamble and not a very good one.-There are some Anti Troll mechanics put in to place for the actual game, but while in the tavern they have almost free reign(can always make a private tavern to bypass this though)-4 classes at this time there are only 4 classes in the game so options can feel limited, however trendy has said they will release more heros(free)- NPC shop keepers kinda have nothing useful for sale, all the good stuff is out there in the monsters gullets! So get out there and get chopping--Pet hatching time is a bit long, as of now it's 8 hours for a single pet to hatch, that's real time, there is talk from the devs that the time may change soon.- Unlike DD1 the mana is sparse so you have to play more carefully so no more maxing out all dem towers and seeing all the pretty stars.- The current lack of content you can play on multiple maps on multiple modes which is really fun, but I just wish there was more raw content, I know they are working on it though.Over All I would recommend this game, please remember this game is in alpha, so if that bothers you then you may wanna wait or go watch some game play on twitch or youtube before you decide, if you're like myself and don't mind a few bumps here and there and get to watch the game grow then jump on it.

content:
Posted: December 5, 2014
Early Access Review
								17.10.15 - I'm recommending it now and will replace the review below once it gets out of early access.--I loved Dungeon Defenders 1, I even loved the nightmare-gear gap that a lot of people struggled with. This is my opinion about DD2 on Day1/2.DD2, out of the box and eventhough it still is in early access, is a heavily gated experience. It forces you through an abyssmal grind while isolating you from the rest of the player base the higher you go. Personal skill isn't rewarded, but how many times you attempted a mission. You can win a campaign map but it doesn't unlock the next one - something I have never seen before - it's behind a ridiculous mechanic where you have to grind previous maps over and over for XP until the next one unlocks even if you wouldn't have any problems winning the next ones. You can't even attempt harder maps or harder difficulties. I know a fair deal of grinding, but I don't understand why a game won't let you progress even if you conquered all the maps you've previously played. The whole war table thing doesn't make any sense and should be abolished because a system where players are put into tiers is dumb.A lot of my fun in DD1 was figuring out placements, but it seems it has been completely thrown out of the window here.If you're too strong, the game just downscales all of your stats/towers and always attempts to put you on the verge of barely winning. It's good if you want that sort of challenge, but the game also forces you through this item progression grind. In DD1 you could perfectly well do maps below Nightmare if you knew how to play. You would also believe that finishing on normal would unlock harder difficulties for the map - it doesn't, you have to accumulate a ton of XP until the game decides you're up for 'hard' mode on specific maps. It doesn't make any sense, considering that the game limits your access of maps depending on your level. Most of the times you will not be able to even replay levels in the next tier. So the progression system actually regresses the options you should have available. WHY?I think this is all an effort to stop people from twinking and powerleveling, because otherwise selling gold or other services isn't going to be profitable in the future if it wasn't obstructed. Which is probably going to be a big deal because even upgrading your gear requires a lot of gold to a point where you waste more gold on a level 1 upgrade than you possibly get from finishing a map. That's completely bonkers. Though there are a few silver linings.The PC version is well done, as opposed to DD1 which struggled with a lot of port problems. Eventhough there are a lot of interface options, it's still lacking a way to disable ally health and enable that tower health is always being shown or at least if it's on low health. I like the concept of the chests at the end and that you don't have to complete all waves to still get a reward. Actually between finishing or failing a map there is very little incentive, aside from the possible higher rarity loot at the end and slightly more xp depending on the wave you were. All that matters in the end is that you've attempted it and you get your fair share of a reward. It turns everyone into a winner, behind a heavily grind/gated based mechanic. I can't recommend this to anyone who loved DD1, as it is right now. Wait for it to come out in 1-2 years and hope that they didn't turn this into a game on-par with a mindless cow clicker and with more substance instead. Also be aware that this game can only be played if you are online, it's basically a mmo.

content:
Posted: May 2, 2015
Early Access Review
 Here, I am going to explain the Dungeon Defenders PC lineup to you in TL;DR fashion: DD1 (Dungeon Defenders - that's the first one) Base game is best value for money, boasts great replayability and lots of tower defence & hack 'n slashing fun and great to get your feet wet. DLC rather steep: Â£5 will get you a single map and a challenge, slightly less may get you a single character, less than that may get you a costume.  DLC price total is triple that of the original game. DLC controversy due to not only being overpriced but creating a divide in playerbase (People with DLC's couldn't play those without DLC's) and a heavy power creep in new gear making the late game shamefully easy for veterans and causing many newer players to hit a wall they could not surpass (say goodbye to winning any online PvP challenges!). Hacking became an issue - as of current has mostly died off though abuse of Steam Workshop has created massive Mana (Money) / EXP / Hacked Gear generation maps, as tempting as it is, don't do it. You'll ruin the game for yourself.Advise people interested in the series to start here - buy full package (That means game + DLC) on Steam Sale, Indie Bundle or otherwise where cheapest. DDE (Dungeon Defenders Eternity - the worst one) A rereleased version of DD1 - purported as the 'definitive' version, which is basically a glorified DD2 beta - testing out features of the new engine for the recent DD2 release, I'm not even going to list the features here - they are so insubstantial to what was lost and you just shouldn't bother even considering buying this one. No Local Multiplayer.  No Steam Workshop. Always (forcibly) online, with god awful connection - just trust me on this one. Ingame store with microtransactions despite already having paid for the bloody thing. This is the MOBILE PHONE version of the game ported to PC.Would not recommend to my worst enemy. DD2 (Dungeon Defenders 2 - What you're actually here for) I was incredibly wary of DD2 upon hearing of its release - having read other reviews I made the decision to take the plunge into buying Early Access, here's what I think, take it as you will: ~ Larger emphasis on combat, for better or worse depending on your own personal tastes: each class has had their number of unique skills increased from DD1 from 2 -> 3, however the total types of towers each has fell from 5 -> 4. + Combat, thankfully, feels better for the most part. + Animations are more lively than the previous game. + Skill spheres are a pretty cool concept. + Microtransactions ingame grant no play bonuses to those that pay for them (ergo: no pay-to-win), and Trendy have made the promise to keep to this. - ...But damn, ingame purchases are expensive: for a single Monk Ninja costume it will cost you 1200 gems - the equivalent of $12. - Characters are normalized across the board: no colour customization at the time of writing and the game has lost the RPG character development in favour of gear being the sole provider of stat boosts, along with Skill Spheres, which, depending on the size can increase stats by variable amounts or completely change the way a facet of your character works (such as a tower's mode of fire) though there aren't many of these at the time of writing either. - Characters feel somewhat imbalanced - Monk and Huntress have great synergy together (for those who have/n't played: Geyser Traps and Electric Aura can stun & damage for days) which writes off the viability of the Squire (my class) and the Apprentice - which is a shame because while tower synergy is really cool, the current designs indicate little synergy outside of the Monk-Huntress combo I mentioned - making them more popular for people who know of it. - Maps can feel claustrophobic compared to the previous game (we're only counting DD1 as a comparative: screw DDE). - It's always online - you can host a Private Game and play by yourself, but good luck: this game was NOT meant for soloing, and is significantly harder to do so alone, considering prior shady practices of Trendy in and outside of DD (look them up, and need I mention DDE again), it's worrying that once this game - as an MMO - gets out of Early Access, they may simply drop it if the money isn't good enough anymore, meaning people who have invested into the game will flat out no longer be able to play it (which is my biggest overall apprehension - but it can't really be avoided). Final Thoughts As surprising as it was, despite my skepticism I still really enjoyed (and am currently enjoying) my time playing DD2, and was impressed for what it offered, being pre-alpha.Do buy if you: Are crazy for another blast of Dungeon Defending goodness. Have tried it elsewhere and like it and can see yourself playing it in future (It's good value for money!). Or alternatively you're one of many Steam-goers who just likes wasting money on games they'll never likely play.Don't buy if you: Have never played DD1: try that first and THEN consider this game. Didn't like DD1 - at the time of writing it still currently stands as the best of the  three  two Dungeon Defenders games. Felt that stat allocation and creation of character builds was vital to your enjoyment of DD1 - as an MMO this game currently just doesn't boast the allowance for such individuality and feels homogenized as a result. Are on the fence on the matter - you can always wait rather than waste your student loan on an eventual F2P MMO. Don't have enough money in your Bank Account/Steam Wallet/Steam Point Card because Steam will refuse to let you purchase a game you can't afford and you'll just look like an idiot.All in all, I actually really enjoyed myself, and got the Collector's Edition on top of that to show my support: don't let me down Trendy.Edit: Steam completely destroyed my formatting for some reason.Most recent Edit: â¥â¥â¥â¥ dis grame

content:
Posted: February 8, 2016
Early Access Review
								EDIT: Made my points clearer, and fixed some of my horrendous grammar.EDIT 2:I've added some more points.DISCLAIMER:I have some 200~ hours as of the time of writing because I've been mindlessly farming stuff I hope to trade some day, not because there's actually this much content.Please read this, Trendy, for the sake of your game. Trendy saw, read and responded. I'm impressed. I just hope you'll take some of this to heart.They didn't.TL;DR at the bottom.It is a good game, right now a downgrade from DD1 sure, but a good game still.  I'd like nothing more than to change my review to a positive one, but It has some concerning flaws that makes me want to discourage the purchase of any dlc/gems until they are fixed though, especially since Trendy seems more intent on making more skins rather than adding content or fixing bugs. The game is still in alpha with alpha amounts of content, and its making me kinda nervous when Trendy is saying they're planning on releasing the game this year.They are as follows:Loot and loot customization/upgrading is completely shallow compared to DD1. Items have class specific traits though that make 99% of the loot you find without said stats useless, making it harder (read: not in a good way) to progress. In dd1 you could just grab near any piece of decent loot and upgrade theâ¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥out of it. All gear say for some legendaries are now trash. There's no real achievement to getting legendary pets either, considering a single onslaught run up to 15 gets me on average at least one. Getting good loot used to be such a rush...Upgrading your loot nets you about one items worth of the single stat you want, whereas in DD1, depending on how much mana you had and the upgrade levels, the benefits could be massive. This makes upgrading to get a grand total of 300 tower health split across all your items such a letdown.The game has general lag and disconnecting issues for many players, even while playing singleplayer(!). The game runs over 60 fps, mostly, but never 144 fps, even on my gtx 970 and i7-4770k... And suffers frequent fps drops in certain areas, like the tavern. .  It runs better now. Still suffers a lot in the multiplayer hub area, but its much better.There are few maps, most of which not really that interesting, and no fun challenges like in the previous game (incursion is just more mobs and minibosses, onslaught is near pointless to do for anything other than golden egg farming). This, combined with the loot problems doesn't exactly encourage the progression into the higher nightmares.No trading (yet?) and no playershops. This was a really big part of the previous game for me and many of my friends who enjoyed DD1. Customizing your very own tavern with your items and having your achievements on display was a really neat feature.They keep using the words "Play [the hero] your way" in the devstreams, but in reality, there's only the four builds (dps, towerdps, waller and hybrid), and mostly just the same way of beating levels with the same ways of placing turrets.Trendy is adding more heroes as their first priority (according to what I hear on the devstream) and I think it is the wrong way around, they need to add more stuff to do with those heroes rather than the heroes themselves. Otherwise it just feels like doing the same over and over only barely different.The reason I list this bunch of cons and not recommending the game is because I have a blind hope that trendy can fix their game and make it live up to its grand potential. I'll thumb this review up in an instant if Trendy ever decides to fix some of these issues.TL;DR This game is good, it is a dungeon defenders game, but everything it has from DD1, it has less of.

Posted: June 8, 2016
Early Access Review
								So the core DD experience is here. If that's all your looking for, than your good. However as someone who paid for the game before it went free to play and ended up buying a bit of the "premium currency". I didn't think that much into it because the currency was almost entirely for cosmetic stuff. Fast forward to today. I picked it up again after a lengthy break (almost a year). First thing I noticed was: Damn this game is STILL in early access?!. The second thing was the new characters locked behind a paywall requiring you to invest tens of hours into it just to unlock ONE, or fork over cash for them. I regret every penny I put down on this game. After investing all the money I did and hundreds of hours of play time I still have characters locked behind a paywall. That is unacceptable.

content:
Posted: February 9, 2016
Early Access Review
								This review is mostly addressed to the players of Dungeon Defenders 1 that have not probably experienced DD2 yet. I will try to save you some frustrationg, disappointment and money in the process. This is a copy/paste from my post at the official forums here: https://dungeondefenders.com/2/topic/131203/ with a few edits so that it makes more sense as a review. Hope it does not get deleted from the forums so you can always refer to it.Note that this is not a negative review because of bugs or early access status etc. This is due to design choices and the direction the game is taking.Dungeon Defenders II or "Farming players for cash." or "How you go from a great game, to a mediocre one in order to increase revenue". Take your pick.Everything that is wrong with this game is everything that differentiates it from Dungeon Defenders 1.Meaning:a)The Hero Deck. It is awful, restricting, makes it impossible to solo high difficulty if you need to do so, makes you go in and out on multiplayer as people join up who have what you need but..not in their deck. Hey we all left our purge monks out of the deck. The moment you decide to bring your monk, no one has whatever else is missing...b) The match creation/joining system. Old DD1 was just great. The current one is a mess.c) No bank, selling inventory space and generating content that clutters inventory space. Consumables are now in the game, yeah!! NOT.d) Loot went from huge amounts or interesting loot, item sets, etc (DD1) to loot that only allow cookie cutter builds (forget hybrids folks).e) Tedious monthlies. Seriously 50 pet affection levels? 600 waves? Leveling pets you don't need on maps that generate loot that you don't need. Yeah!! You're a casual gamer? Have a job? Family? Tough luck buddy.f) Timers on eggs. What for? Inventory clutter. Buy bags, buy gems.g) Did I mention separate pet inventory? Buy more bags and gems.e) Overpriced skins/models, yeah! 4800 gems to show your support and buy a new character model. Wait, I already showed my support with the collector's edition and the awakened pack. You obviously need even more support. Yet because I missed the "promotion" (which also required buying!) I can't be recognized as a DD1 veteran. Shows how much you support me, the player that's been loyal to you and already supported you with lots of money although they smelled the direction this was going for. I didn't want the gems that came with the promotion, I only wanted the title. It's the first game ever that I see requiring a payment for giving you a title recognizing you as a veteran from the previous game (and I collect games for over 25 years--1035 games 872 DLCs owned currently on Steam alone). Every game out there that offers such title, all they require is you owning the previous title (which of course I own, with all available DLCs). And I own 2 of copies with all the DLCs, not one. Because I played it with my other half.f) Overpriced skins for pets that you gamble your money on. Yes, I can't even buy the skin I like and apply it to the pet I farmed for. I have to buy/spend gems to transform eggs to get random quality that may or may not have the elemental damage I want. Ad infinitum.g) Here comes the carnival event. Offering a wheel that drops up to 700ipwr legendaries (at least not like the useless shops that cap at 550) with bad combinations of stats and..inventory clutter. Masks(see head skins) that you don't even get to keep, they're consumable and serve as inventory clutter. Either you use them up immediately/sell them or if you want to save them, buy even more gems/bags. While the good part of the event requires..gems again!h) We now know there will be many more heroes coming up! Heroes that you have to buy space for. And skins for. With.. gems! The perpetual carrot. You wanted a MOBA element to this game exactly for this reason, the community of old DD1 players said no and you backed off, yet you kept the MOBA carrot in the game, new heros every other week, new skins for the new heroes, new things to buy gems for. Ad infinitum. Yet, the existing heroes have useless towers, bad combinations and there are only cookie-cutter builds viable. But sure, lets get more heroes because strategy and tower defense is not the point. The point is having new heroes and new skins every month so we have something to spend gems on.I could go on. And I'm sorry for the sarcastic tone in my post but I feel that this way it gets the message across much better. We played DD1 because it was a fun game of tower defense with FPS elements that required strategy as well. This game is turning into the mindless perpetual money making machine that defines games like League of Legends etc. I have already deeply regretted that I supported this title but obviously the romantic in me, smothered the cynical critic and hoped that it would not go this way after all.I have already paid a lot for DD2, but from now on I will not spend another cent on it UNLESS it changes business model, or at least adds a SINGULAR pay-once-for-everything option and addresses the real issues with the game instead of creating perpetual carrots. Fix all existing heroes so that they all have viable tools with synergies with each other and provide content updates in terms of new maps etc that require strategy instead of things that constantly require gems or indirectly just cause an influx of revenue. EVERYTHING that was fun in DD1 is missing from DD2 or has turned into something that generates revenue.This report/review will go up on steam as well as my negative review, addressed to the players of DD1 that may have not yet experienced this, in order to perhaps save them from the frustration and disappointment that I personally experienced.

content:
Posted: December 6, 2014
Early Access Review
								As of early access. I have to give this one a thumbsdown and here's why.First of all the positive:Graphics - Game looks a lot better than the previous in my opinion. It  doesn't look blocky, It looks smooth. Lighting's quite impressive and it is also colourful which is what I like about the game. Not to mention they actually manage to put a little bit of realness(if that's a word) to it by making trees sway, leaves on trees move and grass and other plantation have animation as well.Items - The item actually looks better in terms of quality. Like my squire for example I have a common, epic and mythical sword. By looking at the three the higher the quality the better than look of the weapon, I mean I played DD1 and a lot of the time, I prefer the looks of my supreme quality items than my ultimate quality ones which doesn't make sense since you want to make the better quality to look more epic, right?Character specs- Ok I like this on my squire since It got specwhere it would make my barricade have a chance to stun enemies after hitting and knocking them back which is good for a defensive structure.Now heres the bad part:Character specs- Even though I said good things about character specs, The fact of the matter is that, there's not many of them and some of them are just outright useless like the "powerful spears" on my squire. 18 im at lvl 13 with 18 spec points and If i use it on "shiny spikes" which makes my barricades stun, It gets a 47.62% chance to stun while If I use 18 specs points on powerful spears, I would give me 3% chance for my ballistas to do penetration do full dmg which is sooo low considering there's no stats to add when you level up to get more defense speed, these are all items based now. Im guessing to prevent people from using cheat engine like DD1 but that is just bad.Structure's Stats - Ok There's no way to increase your structure's range other than upgrade....Yep..you heard it right. Ok how does this affect the game you might ask? Considering that there's barely any green crystals(currency to build turrets and stuff) you are pretty much stuck with at most time tier 1 or tier 2 upgrade and not to mention that YOU HAVE TO PROTECT them for a round because 100% of time at my level, it gets destroyed because at the first round you get 230 crystals so for example i put in a ballista which cost 50crystals and upgrade it to tier 1 for another 50 crystal and tier 2 to make it decent cost 100 crystals and the best at my level is tier 3 which is 150 crystals. Now as you can see, at 1st round you can only go up to tier 2 and that is only ONE structure while the maps have several of these paths where enemies will spawn! so you are forced to almost not upgrade any of your structures at 1st round because you will NEED barricades to at least slow enemies down and 60% of the time, they get destroyed because of the fact that theres about 4 enemies on my level that would far outrange all my structures including the ballista which makes structures almost useless at my level. Firebomb chucking enemies, Dragon that fire fireballs from its mouth, spear throwers and flying dragons all outrange any structures from any classes that is IF you do not upgrade which is more likely what you are going to do because green crystals are soo limited. What the hell?Sort Button - No sort button considering you can easily get full inventory quite quickly unless of course you got the gold to buy more inventory spaces.Item/Stat Downscale - You get downgraded when you try and do low level maps which is just bad because grinding is much more tedious now considering the game is based on grinding for items and most of the time you get sweet (F word) all. I just don't like the way DD have changed from its previous predecessor. It feels more forced into you like you are forced to grind for level to unlock the next skill or map. The range enemies need nerfing and what the hell is up with the ogre? It can one hit kill my barricades with 8k hp (either this is a bug or intended I do not know). There is not much variety in terms of classes. You still have your base classes with almost the same structures as in DD1. The only good thing is your character's skills, it's more useful now and is actually needed in order to win the game such as the earthquake attk that stuns AoE for squire. However,  I really think they need to improve on this, I know it's only early access but I cannot recommend it at the moment in its current state. Wait for it till it goes free to play.Edit: Edited Structure Stats

Early Access Review
								Even in pre-alpha, DD2 expands on what made the original Dungeon Defenders great. A better loot system, more customization, and an overall more rewarding feeling that the original, and well beyond what most games offer. If you were a fan of the original DD, this is a must-have.

content:
Posted: December 16, 2016
Early Access Review
								tl dr: Not a tower defense game anymore. With the addition of a new enemy Siege Roller that can only be damaged by heroes, not towers and him being present everywhere the only way to win a map is to get 4 dps hero players, while towers are left with a little support role as any hero can hold off lanes on his own. Yes the new enemy is no problem for hero dps, but thats about the problem! this renders defenses pointles thus this game became an ARPG instead of a Tower Defense game.Oh and solo play? forget it, this enemy can come 2-3 lanes at same time, and you alone can only do one. Thus this new addition killed solo play.Oh and in a tower defense game it should matter ur wisdom of how to place towers right? well NO, only matters how much time you spend to farm equip to get the right rolls, oh and there are alot of rolls and RNG on top of RNG on top of RNG. First RNG is how much ipwr this item has, then what stats it has, then the stats range and then the passives and then the passives range! thats 5x chained RNG! This game is not about tower defense, its about farming gear and throwing out 10000 items till you find that one that fits your build. Oh and then next month comes with an update and trashs your build and tells you: farm again for new flavor of the month!There is no real space to place towers any way different then designed. The distance between enemy spawn and cores is the firing distance of towers. You have only this one option to build and no other tactical options. Only thing that matters are stats on items to make your towers stronger.This game has tower defense tag on steam. This is simply wrong, its an action RPG with small tower defense elements.And even as action RPG it fails, all heroes have 4 action skills and 4 towers, while gunwitch has 8 action skills and is supossed to be pure dmg hero. Well what does our lovely rollie do? yeah he simply is immune to all skills! The only way to kill him is hold leftclick down oh what a joy! autoattack! Gunwitch spells that perfectly fine work on all other bosses dont work on this one. And ofc to have the dps of leftclick you need items, see above lol. Example on huntress that has oilflusk and phoenix to set the oil ablaze(basically napalm), a nice combination of 2 skills right? well rollie ignores that completely. Leftclick for the grind!!!

content:
Posted: February 17, 2016
Early Access Review
								Edited, yet again.I'm not sure where to begin at the moment. Part of me loves this game and wants it to succeed so very much, and part of me is very bitter at the moment.I'll try my best to explain why, and you can make the call based on that, whether or not it's worth your time.Leveling, and getting to max level is not bad at all and in fact if that's all you intend to do, I say play it, you have nothing to lose really and things are quite fun especially if you have multiple friends to play with. The art is well done, the gameplay is quite smooth and it's a fun casual relaxed experience which I think anyone can enjoy really. Here's where it starts to get gritty, and you'll either hate it or love it for the most part. Once you're maxed level, and you want to start to improve your gear, there's really not much left to be desired. You'll play the same maps you were playing, only with higher HP monsters and higher damage. And you'll not see any variation from that at all. Allow me to reiterate:Onslaught, previously Survival in Dungeon Defenders, is â¥â¥â¥â¥. Literally. I'm not going to sugar coat it, it's a big steaming pile of â¥â¥â¥â¥. Literally the only reason people run it, is on a super low difficulty, so they can farm gold. Rewards suck. The time it takes to do sucks. Nothing special about it at all. Don't even waste your time, IMO. Incursion, a slightly different variation from maps, but really nothing different other than throwing mass quantities of mobs at you in each lane. Yeah I guess it's harder but it really doesn't bring anything new to the table. Nothing new, just more mobs, more HP and more damage. Sounds so fun right?Nightmare 1-4 is my gripe with the game, I suppose. In DD1, we had one nightmare mode and that was it. This game tried to change that and it's pretty much fell flat on its face. There is no difference between Nightmare 1-4 outside of damage numbers. So much engaging gameplay. So you farm the same enemies while you're leveling, to continue farming the same enemies through nightmare 1-4 only scaled higher. Absolutely nothing different, you'll run the same maps until your eyes bleed, and then more.Pets are bland. Seriously if you played DD1, you're going to be very disappointed here. Liked that mega chicken and it's badass DPS from DD1? Well sorry to say you're going to laugh when you see the pets here. Overall, this game lacks the fun that Dungeon Defenders 1 had in all aspects. No goofy weapons, no goofy pets, nothing fun at all. Defense speed and range are not a thing here, and I hope you like watching a tower fire slow as hell. Gear is boring in every since of the word, and you'll see what I mean if you play this in comparison to DD1. The same stats, and you'll be looking for 1% upgrades which is laughable to me. Don't even get me started on the â¥â¥â¥â¥ they've pulled with the latest update they had in which they threw a carnival at us when the game has been needing core changes for months, and what do we get along with it? A 40$ costume that's a reskin. Yes, you read that right. A frickin costume that's 40 bucks. I believe in supporting a game if you enjoy it, but they seriously overstepped their bounds on this. Every patch seems to roll out costume after costume and core gameplay changes that need to be made, have yet to make it into the game.Take a look at steamcharts and you can see what I mean. TL;DR: If you enjoy casual relaxed play and just shooting the â¥â¥â¥â¥ with friends and trying out a tower defense game to level to max level and not expect much more than that, check it out. If you want fun, laughs, and was hoping to see a sequal to the dungeon defenders name, and are expecting a hell of a fun time, avoid it. My two cents, take it or leave it. Obviously I can't cover every major gripe/perk of the game, and if you want a good view on what players think, check the forums out for yourself and you'll get an idea for how negative they are, especially after last patch.Obviously I want better changes to come, and I hope they do, I'd really like to recommend this game, but sadly in its current state, I wouldn't recommend it to anyone.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2016
Early Access Review
								I fell in love with the dungeon defenders franchise with the first game.. It was a wonderful mix of genres and I just loved it. Then in came Eternity, which had some improvements, but also made the game a bit less fun, due to the lack of local co-op (don't know if that was changed at a later date, but when I played, there was none).Then in came Dungeon Defenders II, and I was excited.. Bought it as soon as I had the money for it and I liked it.. I liked it a lot.. Just like many other reviews have mentioned before, you got some premium money (gems) when you bought the game when it first came to early access, and back then there was no talks about any other uses for gems aside from costumes & more inventory space. So I spent my gems and kept playing.. Then there wasn't enough new content to keep me interested, felt like updates came far too seldom.. Then I heard that there'd be a new character coming, the abyss lord.. and I got all excited about the game again.. Started my game up & tried making a new character aaaand then I noticed that the character costs gems.. or "hero medals".. That just broke my heart. The game series that I had loved and spent hundreds upon hundreds of hours playing, was just turning in to an early access f2p moneygrabber.. If you liked the original dungeon defenders, go play that instead. Or if you want to try this one, don't waste your money on it. I'm out 20â¬, and what I got to show for that, is a couple of outfits for my characters.. or I could've gotten a character unlocked, if I'd saved my gems for a year and a half. It's unfortunate, but this game series got ruined with the switch to a free to play model.. sure.. It's free to play, unless you want to get a new character & not have to grind for day after day to get your hero medals to unlock said characters with.

content:
Posted: April 9
Early Access Review
								A few months ago I would have recommended this.But then since their new Trials & Chaos update, it's been very downhill.It's essentially still the same game, but instead of tower defense with hero assist, it's the other way around with hero base defense with tower support.Every time the community comes up with an easy way to do something or a powerful item combination, the devs decide to patch it and nerf it until it is virtually useless.There is a lot of unexplained things related to progression that you have to check or ask on forums.  Most of the progression is gated by daily medals now because the gold you get from doing maps is so little, and you are required to spend these medals/gold to find upgrades.Microtransactions are mostly cosmetic, the exception being buying an alternative hero instead of spending a month saving up medals, and bagslots because boy do you need a lot of bagslots.  The new shards system uses up a lot of bagspace, duplicates do not stack, and some of them you may need a lot of.What with shards, there is a lot of grinding, so much so that even if you can complete Chaos4 or Chaos5 difficulties, you'll still be spending most of your time in Chaos1 for very rare & essential shards.  The higher difficulties also do not give proportional rewards, so it is still best to grind Chaos1 for exp, gold, and medals.In it's current state it is worse than it used to be and not even worth trying.  (I don't know how bad it might be to level from 1-50 right now, but I've heard transitioning from 50 to chaos1 is much harder than it should be)

content:
Posted: October 3, 2016
Early Access Review
								Defense Council Member, meaning I've played the game since like 2012 or 2013 when it was in pre-pre-pre Alpha as a Child's Play perk with no sound or anything, and I believe the first few days all you could just walk around in the tavern. I've played a lot, you can see the hours on record, and that's not counting any of the time before it even hit Steam. Played through every iteration, "wipe-a-geddon" last summer and beyond.The game is just not nearly as fun as the first and it is ******* prohibitively expensive. It's kind of hilarious that in DD1 people would complain that a new hero would come out and it was five bucks or a new map and it was two bucks and you could usually get them on sale for half off. Here, get ready to shell out a whopping $15 for a character, which is beyond insane. Look at the value in that vs something like Smite, where $20 or $30 (depending on the sale) would get  you every character and all future characters which is up to somewhere around 80 characters right now. Are you kidding me? And don't say they are optional, the Abyss Lord on his own is better than all 4 starter heroes combined and it's not even close. Everything in this game needs to realistically cost half of what it currently costs. But pricing structure aside, I have no idea why they got rid of the action wheel HUD for trap placement for controllers like the first game. It was basically perfect and now they have some weird layout that has taken almost 4 years to implement. Also, every time there is an update or a patch, the game will wipe out all your custom controls and you have to redo them every time. Neat feature. And finally, the only gear you equip that changes your appearance is your weapon. So if you find some sweet looking armor or helm, nah... it's not going to show on your character. That's kind of unforgivable in 2016. I used to really pull for this game but now I simply just don't care. I'd rather go back to the first one which is something I never, ever thought I'd say.

number of helpful: 40 of 41 people (98%) found this review helpful5 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 20
Early Access Review
								I tried. I really, really tried.Ever since I bought this game in 2014, I continued to throw my time and genuine effort at it, hoping to get at the very least a decent sequel to DD1. I even ignored the very clear warning sign that was the release of DD Eternity  (DD1 was abandoned to hackers, then repacked and...sold again under a new name, wham, bam, profit). Today, with the game about ready to leave yet another developement stage, instead of having hope and tons of fun playing the game, I am disgusted and bitterly dissapointed.Let's put the issues I have with DD2 in a neat list, so that I can check myself for bad language after each point I make. Yeah I'm bitter, can you tell? :/ DD2 used to reward maps played with full 4 people team with better loot. Nowadays, it heavily punishes co-op with difficulty spike added with each player (why on earth would devs do that?!), often alienating players not willing to farm for days for equipment for a full set of builders and creating issues amongst people trying to play together yet failing. Oh and public games for higher difficulties? Pretty much dead, thanks to exactly that. Every update leads to massive issues, game-breaking bugs, giant lag spikes and results in the need to implement at least 1 (often more) makeshift patch. Updates are usually 1,7gb, patches are often just as big. While I enjoy a fiber connection, there are still people who sometimes need to wait 2-3 hours to play this game after every mess the devs try to fix. Out of all the games I have, DD2 has the worst update management I have ever seen. Yeah...part of the issue with updates? No real testing. Yep, that's right - DD2 utilises a remote testing group, with disastrous results. Rtg mostly consists of players waaay too devoted to the game to be objective (been there, done that, never again), hence their feedback doesn't represent the majority of playerbase. Has that ever worked well? No. Stupid overlooked things, like boots with a certain passive on a boost aura (that was actually years ago and it didn't teach devs anything), towers doing crazy damage or being suddenly broken, etc., that's the stuff those "testers" never find.  FUBAR hitboxes - from never updated tower hitboxes (remember when towers were smaller? no? no worries, their hitboxes remember! /sarcasm), to absurdly big hitboxes of environment (why are some leaves and twigs not simply textures, ffs?), oh and let's not forget the glorious moments where you see mobs pushing themselves over your barricades, where you can literally see how the outlines of crazy hitboxes push against other mobs. Such a fun away to lose a map. And why the hell am I constantly stuck on stuff I can't even bloody see?! Bugs take forever to fix. And by forever I mean years in some cases. YEARS. One of the bugs I reported in 2015 I think? is still there. I ended up thinking of it as my own pet bug and I named it Clarence. Our requests, even the most reasonable ones, also take forever to be even considered. With the light beams from loot littering maps, we whined and begged and asked for help with that for months. Rewards for early stage supporters? Still bugged. Guess we weren't all that "valued" after all. Bye bye, Grumpy. All the passives and most special weapons, that had their own history and were tied to the game's storyline and certain maps, were recently nuked and turned to shards. Yeah, makes sense - spend months developing special items and passives, get people to enjoy them and farm them enthusiastically, then...go to nuke city. Perfect logic. Response to tickets? Lol what? If your pet is suddenly gone, forget it. You can fill countless tickers, nobody is getting back to you - unless you're a streamer of a member of the forum suck...err, I mean, forum enthusiasts. If you're a streamer, you will get 2 dracoliches in mail without even asking (yes, that happened). No, I'm not bitter, I wanted to get rid of that perfect, expensive, fully evolved lil Betsy anyway /sarcasm. DD2 is NOT eye friendly. God forbid if you have epilepsy or headaches induced by flashes, because DD2 is a hot mess of special effects that no longer make any â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥ sense and serve only to make things harder and more tiresome. If you ever have any doubts about the level of professional training and education Trendy has, just turn all the video options in DD2 to default. Enjoy the crazy excess of bloom and your complimentary seizure. DD2 performs really bad in terms of fps, fluidity of gameplay etc. I can easily run much bigger games and never notice any kind of issues, but DD2 tends to get choppy and laggy for no reason. Co-op sucks as well - in other games I can join servers on other continents and barely notice any lag, but with DD2 it's sometimes impossible to play with someone 2 towns away. For years now, we are being forced into a closed loop cycle of new content, patched mistakes, change of direction, new content. You either join the train and win new content with exploits and bugged towers/abilities, or enjoy being left behind (did I mention Trendy is NOT building a healthy and happy playerbase?) Let's leave this list at that, I'm just not sure I can write down the rest without resorting to really foul language and obvious jabs at the devs. I am thoroughly dissapointed with the state this game is in. And it's not just a current thing - it feels like for years with every tiny step forward, we took 2 steps back and were hit in the face, our daughter ran off with the gardener and someone kicked our puppy. Repeatedly.  TL;DR  version: it's terrible. I waited, I helped, and it still didn't matter...DD2 took every good thing from DD1 and....threw it out the window. It also flipped it a bird and went to drink toxic moonshine with terrible devs and fanboys.

content:
Posted: February 8, 2016
Early Access Review
								If you played DD1, you will quickly see that this game is completely gutted. From the leveling to the gear to the social interaction. Leveling:-In DD1, leveling always was fun, at any time, you could pick which map you felt you were strong enough for, and you     were rewarded for completing more challenging maps. -In DD2, it doesn't matter which map you choose, it is much faster to just play the quickest (hard difficulty) map possible, and keep repeating the process. The difficulty is trivial at best, and it just feels like a chore.Loot:-In DD1, loot is very diverse when it comes to the stats on the items that are dropped. There is a continuous search on any map for those rare pieces of gear with the perfect stats for your character. Many times, there are pieces with negative stats, because other stats on the gear are over leveled, and it is up the player to decide if the loss in some stats, is worth the gain in others. This makes you want to see how far you can push yourself in each wave to find the most overleveled piece of gear possible, even if it means sacrificing all of your character health and damage, for a full tower stat item.-In DD2, all loot feels linear. You progress through the maps which have an indicator of what item level of loot will drop. You run the map and get gear that is slightly better than the previous map. You repeat the process, slowly getting better, but never standing out for pushing yourself. You never feel the need to push yourself.Social Interaction/trading:-In DD1, you get your own tavern, where you can place items on the floor of your shop, or in your personal shop. In your personal shop, you set prices on any items you wish to sell for mana(currency). Players tend to place the best items on the floor, in an attempt to barter with players that join their shop. It really makes you feel like you are selling something that has meaning, because items can have very unique stats. This makes the player WANT to go do more tougher and tougher maps to improve their shop. Having a personal tavern is one of the best aspects of the whole game, you can spend hours just setting your shop up the way you want it, and chat with customers who enter.-In DD2, trading is non-existent. You get a personal tavern, but can't sell or trade.Please Trendy, randomize stats on loot based on map difficulty instead of just increasing the gear by a percentage. Give us taverns that we can sell our items that we work for, and let us level up the way we want to, with more experience based on how tough the map and difficulty is.

content:
Posted: August 5, 2015
Early Access Review
								Yes yes yes.  The game is great.  Fans of the first game which is also good should enjoy this, and newcomers should as well.  Fans of Dungeon Defenders Eternity, well...we don't talk about that one, but you should enjoy this too.Currently there are 4 characters.  The monk, the squire, the apprentice, and my personal favorite, the huntress.  Each one has 3 different abilities (with the 4th always being a heal) and 4 different kinds of towers/defenses.  Use these to fend off waves of monsters and bosses who follow paths to try and destroy whatever it is you're defending.  As you play, you will get all kinds of loot drops.  Armor pieces, weapons, and eggs which can be hatched into a bunch of different kinds of pets.  There are quite a few maps, as well as higher difficulties and some different modes to play.  As you level up, you can also unlock special slots that you can place various passive buffs in.You can play solo, with 3 randoms, or a private lobby with friends.  You'll all be gathered into a cool little player HUB area before you start, where there are all kinds of things you can do.  I do believe however that you need an internet connection to play, so keep that in mind.  If that bothers you, stick with the first game or wait until this one is released and goes F2P.  Lots of fun, definitely worth checking out.

content:
Posted: January 18, 2016
Early Access Review
A great sequel to Dungeon Defenders 1Pros:+4 player co-op+Auto looting+Now free to play+Lovely graphics+New pet system+Daily Xp bonuses+Several game modes+Great co-op experience+Cosmetics and costumes+Daily and monthly challenges+The squire finally has his pants covered >.<+Characters are grown up, I wasn't fond of the little toddlers in DD1+Tower combos, I'd like to see more of this, certain towers do more damage together+Social tavern is a great addition, allowing many people to converse and group togetherCons:-No bank to store items-Community isn't the best-Still needs tweaking, balancing and fixes-No lobby list like DD1, makes you join random games-Game uses too much computer resources, needs optimization-Cosmetics and costumes seem to be worked on more than everything else-AFK players, you may come across them, for me it is a big negative, I like active players-Not enough to do, flow of content is too slow compared to completing it all, leaving nothing to do but daily missions and such.-Developers are greedy, even after winning money in a lawsuit they continue to put costumes into the game, some of which cost over Â£20 for a single costume. Optional yes, however the price tags just show you their greed.Download Size: 7514mbTrading Cards: 15 cards in the setAchievement Difficulty: Easy to 100%Hours to 100%: 100+Rating: 6/10Recommendation: Worth playing since it's freeMy Opinion:The game is very different than DD1 and does not have the same feel to it but still sticks to tower defense of course. It has some features I like a lot that are not in the previous game, and while it is not as good as DD1 at this current time it is still in early access, and can be very much improved. I follow the game and look forward to when it is complete. Still a ways to go but I have enjoyed my experience so far, however there are some things I do miss that were in DD1, that being said the new things in DD2 are a welcomed changed.Note: I don't play anymore for now at least, so I won't be updating the review.

content:
Posted: July 29, 2015
Early Access Review
								First of all:Don't listen to those people who keeps saying: "This is the worst game ever! It doesn't even look like DD1."This is Dungeon Defenders. If you want  to play a sequel of games that are all the same, buy Call of Duty. They are right about one thing though, this isn't like DD1 but this is a good thing! This is only and pre-alpha and the work they did with it is just amazing. The graphics are amazing: just look at all the colour in the artstyle. Got to admit, not like the first Dungeon Defender which was, in my opinion, a bit low on graphic quality.Look at all the content!! So much new stuff in there! The new pet system, the costume system and much more. In only one patch, they doubled the fun I had the first time I played Dungeon Defenders 2. After 2 hours of playtime, I already bought the collector's upgrade because Trendy needs support for this amazing game.To those who keeps whining about the bugs and the crashes, etc. Don't cry in the comment section, send a ticket to Trendy! Plus, this is only Pre-Alpha, so there are still a lot of issues to be fixed. You need to remember one thing though. Don't buy this game expecting a fully developped game, it is a work in progress (which progresses like crazy!). I played over 500+ hours of Dungeon Defenders 1 on console and I am really satisfied with the sequel. I digged the first one and liked even more the second one. This is the kind of game that you can't get enough of.The only thing that scares me is the idea to go free to play. What will happen to the community? Will it get ruined? Will it be even better? I don't know.But the thing that I know is that I recomend that game to anybody who digged the first one and is looking for a Dungeon Defenders 2, not a Dungeon Defenders 1 HD.

number of helpful: 109 of 153 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 8, 2014
Early Access Review
								Pre-Alpha[08.12.2014][26 hours]I played the game for 26 hours now and I can safely say that this game is going in the right direction. It just needs content, changes and some fixes here and there. It runs surprisingly well for a game thatâs in pre-alpha. I did glitch through the map once, but I have yet to find another bug.At the moment it has only 10 maps that all feel unique and rich in detail, and difficulty selection is just like it was in the original. Monster variety is given but there are some monsters that have a higher range than your towers, and since you cant increase your tower range with stats anymore its pretty difficult to counter them. Also there are new monsters immune to physical damange, so squires are not OP anymore, as they were in the original. There are only 4 classes at the moment, with 4 towers and 4 spells each, and the max level cap at 25. Sadly, the game is quite difficult if you play it solo and it even gives you a disadvantage in the rarity of dropped loot. If you play with a group itâs much easier overall, and you get better loot for every additional group member (up to 4), so it seems to be clearly intended for co-op play.New:- Combining different elements to get bonus exp/gold is a nice addition to Dungeon Defenders, as it lets you experiment with the different tower elements (water + lightning, knockup + ice, etc).- There are sub-cores that can now be destroyed without ending the entire round. However, if you let them get destroyed, new enemy paths will open up and youâll have to build additonal defenses.- The cores are now unique level based objects that fit nicely with the surrounding map (doors, portals, generators).- New manually activated traps which do damage in an area, and can only be used again after a cooldown (Gas, Fire, Water).- Upgrading towers now shows visual changes, which is awesome.- There are now 2 kinds of mana, which I think is a good thing. (blue for spells and green for towers).- Items can gain levels by fusing other items into them, which will also reward you with skill points that you can spend on the tower/hero stats on those items.The graphics seem very minimalistic at first look, but upon closer inspection they are quite detailed close up, a clear and improvement over Dungeon Defenders 1. I personally enjoy the changes, but other fans might be put off. The new tavern looks fantastic and I can't wait to find out what theyâll add in later, as the game is currently in early access.All in all itâs a solid tower defense game as it is right now and you can have some fun with your friends for sure, but keep in mind that it will be Free to Play on release,  so you might want to wait untill then.The devs have claimed that the microtransactions will be purely cosmetic (costumes, tower skins, and tavern decorations ), but weâll see if they can keep that promise. Itâs sounds promising but other devs have changed their minds down the road. (Loadout, for example)There you have it, my first impressions. I will update this review if I encounter anything notable and as I play newer Early Access builds.Thanks for reading :)

								Ever since the item nerf last year I've had difficulty getting back into this game. I've tried time and time again with friends but I find the experience has become extremely tedious since, once you've capped your level, it's all about grinding for gear and the gear half the time didn't actually do the things it claimed it did, ie. Certain special effects were either bugged, non existent or simply worded incorrectly. I can only hope that the changes have in fact led to a more lasting and enjoyable experience for newer players. I find the hunt for better gear to be a flatout excruciating and nauseating experience since it typically involved high risk/difficulty and little or no reward should you fail to reach or beat the final round. If you challenge difficulties that meet your current item level you typically find nothing worth the hour of scrutiny it will take just to examine the whole lot just for a few measly points of extra damage, or crit or whatever. Tedious and distasteful.

								New update ruined the game for me. Some might like it, but i just don't like the new system. Range stat was removed (Only found in rare shards and as skill gambles) so aura and trap defenses are weak and useless. the Shard and medalion system means that a couple of stats will always be left out ( for example you can have def pwr, speed, and crit but no def health so your defense might do alot of dmg but gets hit a few times and gets destroyed as if you were a lvl 1 noob (and they will get hit because range isn't a factor you can control anymore). content:
Posted: December 16, 2015
Early Access Review
								I'll keep my review as a no, or a negative review until the problems I have with the game as of the recent patch are dealt with, or fixed in some way.Anywho, I haven't put as much hours as some people, I do admit but that won't really stop me from knowing enough for a decent review. I think well over 100 hours is perfectly fine for a game such as this one. Overall, I'd say my past 2 days roughly have not been very enjoyed. Honestly, this is a loot based game, and all loot based games generally boil down to the same point. Gear. This games content can run you about 200hrs for the highest difficulty. I had no friends to really play with, and I spent quite a bit of time dicking around. I got there about 125-150hrs if that, the other 50ish was spent again. Messing around, or playing with randoms.People can tell you that you have to play 1000hrs for a game such as this one, and its clearly not the case. I've played other games, that are more complex and they do not even take that long to understand, or even get to the highest difficulty. That being said, it takes about 100hrs, if you're actually 100% focused on getting to the highest difficulty, and maybe 10-25 depending on your luck to get the gear you need. This includes leveling every character. It just doesn't take that long as people seem to think it does.This is a pretty sweet game, ESPECIALLY for an ALPHA.. Man, it blew my mind on terms of how well optimized this game is, honestly I think games released sometimes are thrown out in alpha states.. Anyways. on with the Pros.PROS- Decent combat - Lots of variety in ways to play, and extremely customizable builds.- Well balanced between the characters, none of them really feel Overpowered (trust me, thats a +)- Nice pet system (actually pretty customizable too)- A tack to add on to variety in ways to play, You could honestly play strategy or go play it without any strategy in mind.- Music, its actually really nice. (Although, I think the most recent patch got me looking for positives to this game, and I can't believe I didn't notice how amazing the music was at times)- The few cutscenes in games were pretty nice, and slightly entertaining- Developers seem to listen, and quite fast. They seem to take action on it too. - Visually, this game looks pretty nice. I know some people will beg to differ on that, but I think this game has a nice     style, it doesn't look bad at all. I think it fits the game perfectly.- Harbinger boss fight is actually quite good, and not as stale as the other one they released. Giant thumbs up for that one.CONS- Gear/loot system is terrible now for certain builds, that are unattainable and didn't deserve to get nerfed. Everyone is about average like said in the pros.- Builds are tedious, and take more "perfection" (enter bad cell quote here) "This isn't even my perfect form" Although, this isn't really a con since more gear is "perfect".- Although not a bad for some people. This game is definitely a time soak. (Although still a time soak after recent patches, its a lot better than it was, guessing time frame would be 100 hours to get to final NM4 content if you're not as lucky as me)- Does have minor bugs (they get ironed out pretty quickly generally. Its an alpha lol)- Overall currency gaining in game, is horrible right now due to lack of drops, and drops being your money maker, even the trashy drops had use.- Definitely a game to play with friends, its a nice game but like most. It is definitely a lot better with friends.- Feels like uber spheres are generally useless, or not really any better than the original skill/tower if not weaker. Some Ubers are useful, just some are down right awful, and even questionable how it got through, and still hasn't been messed with.Its a good game, I just cannot recommend it at the moment. I honestly love this game, and I enjoyed it 170 hours. The farming isn't that bad anymore, still a bit of a time soak really not that much compared to other mmo-like games. Much better with friends and casual play in my opinion. Sorry for the long review. The game has been getting updates to fix the problems I had, but I feel as the damage is done, hopefully others can enjoy it. Its not a bad game, but I'm not going to reccommend it.

content:
Posted: March 9
Early Access Review
								Currently the priority of the developers and a lot of players no longer match.  The developers want to keep your engagement in the game by making it very slow and difficult to progress.  This has been done by:-Gear only starts to regularly drop on the third of five waves of enemies on a map. (Can still drop off Special mobs on the 2nd wave).-Shards needed to aquire power are given only for winning the map (1-3).-The only way to earn rarer shards is to do 1 of 4/5 random maps per Chaos Difficutly.-Each Chaos Difficulty seems to add shards to the possibility pool that you can earn, which mean as you go up in the difficulty the chances of getting rarer shards is more and more unlikely because the pool has increased.-Shards that you earn are completely random meaning you can get shards for characters you don't have/don't use.-Every piece of Gear has a random amount of available upgrades which means that higher quality gear can be worse than lower quality gear.-Gear is upgraded one of two currencies, one you can earn in limited quantities per day/week/maps (Medals) or a currency you earn constantly at a tiny amount that is less cost effective to upgrade with (Gold).-If your Gear stats are not high enough / you haven't leveled enough in the endgame you will not get gear appropriate to the difficulty level you are facing. (Essentialy you have to be so tall to ride but no way to know if your actually tall enough).Developers have stated on stream that they wish the final difficulty (Chaos 5) to be near impossible to beat at the moment... so their priority is to ensure that the majority of players can not reach that difficulty tier in the forseeable future... which leads them to prioritize increasing difficulty further and lowering passive damage sources like towers so that in this 'Tower Defense' game your towers can't effectively contribute to your damage... or they require so many specific pieces of gear/shards that it is unlikely you will have those combinations for months.Tl;DR : Find something more fun to play... there are thousands of other ways to spend your time that will feel less punishing and more fair.

content:
Posted: August 11, 2016
Early Access Review
								Let me preface my review by expressing that even though my review is negative, I  do NOT  think DD2 is explicitly a "bad" game, but I  DO  think the game is built on flawed game mechanics (that I will get to later...), that haven't necessarily been touched on by the Developers yet, and that I can only see compounding and negatively affecting the end result of the game in the future. But before stating why I think that is so, I'll try to draft a quick list of  Pros and Cons :Pros:Appearence: I find the game's artstyle and animations very pleasing aesthetically-speaking. The cartoony feel of the land of Etheria and the heroes themselves works very well to convey a story-book type atmosphere. There isn't a lot of compelling storywork behind the heroes or campaign, but it's meant to be a Tower-Defense title with minor RPG-elements, and so I don't necessarily see that as a conPerformance: Optimizing game performance via the in-game preference menu works well. There aren't a ton of options available, but my 5yo, overheating-prone, piece-of-crap laptop can still manage 30+ FrPS with the settings turned down. The game itself isn't graphically-intensive, so this makes sense, but being one of the few games my laptop can still run, I figured I'd list that as a Pro for other players with less-powerful machinesPersonal Loot: Learning from their experiences with DD1, Trendy implemented a "Personal Loot" system for DD2, where you are free to pick up whatever items you see on your own screen, so that Players don't have to fight over dropped lootF2P; NOT P2W: Contrary to some of the less-informed reviews for DD2, the game is indeed "Free-to-Play" (F2P), but far from being "Pay-to-Win" (P2W). Everything except for cosmetics and bags can be bought with DD2's in-game currency (known as "Defender Medals"). Unlocking new heroes is somewhat expensive at 10K medals, but Daily Quests award anywhere between 250-450 medals, while Weekly Quests award around 600 medals, so it's a fairly reasonable pricing system (unlocking a new hero comes with an extra character slot as well). An additional character slot is 2K medals, which I consider another reasonably priced item (and you'll only really need to buy a lot of extra slots if you want to create multiple builds of the same hero)Cons:Lag: The game does currently seem to suffer from a lot of stutter and general laggy-ness, which seems to be amplified when in a Public group. This can cause the dreaded "character-teleport" effect, where your active hero will sometimes pause for a moment, before teleporting many meters ahead -- often launching your hero off of the edge of a map. There has been discussion on the forums regarding this problem, that suggests the issue might be related to having multiple builders on the same map, in group play, whose visible defense ranges overlap (i.e. the large, blue, conical regions displaying the areas that your defenses can reach that appear when you mouse-over a defense). And there are also specific hero abilities whose animations are known to slow the game down (I've heard the "Gunwitch" hero referred to as the "Lagwitch" in the forums, to give you an idea...)"The Inventory Problem": While the game is far from being a P2W title, there is currently no way to unlock additional bag storage space without spending "Gems" (which are only purchaseable with real money). The game is  technically  playable with the default bags, but unlike in DD1, dropped items aren't automatically sold at the end of a wave, so the current solution is to set certain bags to "auto-loot", but you still have to go through and manually sell the items that you don't want later, which wastes a significant amount of time. The only option to prevent clutter is to choose NOT to auto-loot items of quality below a specified rarity-tier, but then you miss out on the gold you'd otherwise receive from selling such items (Note: "gold" is hardly used, which is fortunate in this context, but unfortunate overall IMO). With only DD2's default bags, more time needs to be dedicated to manually selling items, as you'll fill up your inventory faster -- to the point where I personally considered the game unplayable until I spent some money on a few extrasInventory Management: Trendy has introduced some pretty basic criteria that you can set for each bag regarding what kinds of items they will "auto-loot" from the ground, and also how a bag's stocked items are sorted, but these features could still use some improvements. One of the major downsides is that you can only choose 1 of these criteria at a time.  "Want to set one of your bags to auto-loot ALL item qualities less than Mythic?"  (Mythic being the 2nd-highest rarity, where anything lower than that is fairly worthless atm...). Well you can't. In order to accomplish that feat, you'd need 4 separate, dedicated bags, set to auto-loot the "Worn-", "Sturdy-", "Powerful-", and "Epic-" quality items, individually. Another problem is that you can't use the Sort feature across multiple bags. If it were possible, it would be easy to simply auto-loot everything, and then sort ALL of your bags (top-to-bottom) by "Item Rarity" with one button, so that it would be easier to sell off the lower-quality items. Instead, it seems the quickest way to sell items is to sort EACH bag by Item Rarity, manually drag the "Mythic" and "Legendary" items to an empty bag dedicated to NOT auto-loot (so that you can search through them for potential upgrades later), and then finally, you can hit the "Sell-All-Items-In-Bag" button on the low-quality leftover items that you know aren't upgrades. The quickest way to sell trash items is still far from being quickGear Stat System: In DD1, items would drop with the potential to include +/- stat contributions in ALL possible fields: the 4 Hero Stats (Damage, Health, Speed, Cast Rate), the 2 Hero abilities (Ab1 & Ab2), the 4 Defense Stats (Damage, Health, Speed, Range), the 4 resistance types (for armor), and various weapon stats (for weapons) (link to a DD1 item example) [images.akamai.steamusercontent.com]. Conversely, DD2's items have 2 stats that directly affect heroes  ("yes you heard me correctly... a whopping 2 stats!! And 1 of the 2 is always Hero Damage on weapons...") , while the remaining are item-specific (like weapon speed / firing pattern)  (link to a DD2 item example) [wiki.dungeondefenders2.com]. This means that it is not possible to stack more than two primary stats on any given Hero.  "Want to spec a Builder hero around defense damage, crit damage, and health?" You can't. You'll have to forego one. In short, item stats are infinitely less important than item passivesAlas, I have reached the character limit =(Other cons worth mentioning:Mechanic-changing item passives lock character builds behind farmed items rather than Player customization. Rather than simply changing how a defense is used situationally, most passives are just better versions of the original defense. They also complicate hero balanceGear rolls for one specific class making sharing gear impossibleHero balance - some heroes are vastly more useful than othersNo real end-game progression systemOnly maps with guaranteed legendary passives are farmed on end-game. Once you get the guaranteed item with a good passive roll, there is hardly any replay value for that mapNot enough item qualities / raritiesYour character absolutely HAS TO BE lvl 50 in order to contribute anything on end-game. This both rushes the leveling process and makes it less fun. Starting a new character is painfulPets = non-usefulEndless Onslaught is boring

Early Access Review
								i enjoy playing the game with other people, but there are issues with progression that have left the game difficult for me to play. when you get to endgame its fun but everyone joins random games to get carried through, so everyone is playing the toughest difficulty (NM4) but if you dont have gear for NM4 you are left to either 1) play solo... not at all why i downloaded this game2) scrub some carries off random people i have been stuck on NM3 soloing which is difficult for me because i get bored playing a co op game by myself. and if you bring someone along with you to NM3 after completing a weekly challenge together they will sabatoge your run because its not NM4 or just leave. it takes on average 2 hours to find one person willing to play NM3 in town. posting on forums is not any faster either. some posts looking for players just go unanswered, or have people saying they will carry me (to which i will always refuse). i can not recommend this game until the grind is better. no online co-op game should force you to request a carry or solo past 1/2 of endgame content. i have no problem grinding for the items other people buy with IRL money, but doing it by myself is just not fun.a suggestion i think would make this a lot better is if everyones itempower syncs down to the lowest item powered hero card in any of the 4 heros decks. so if i bring my level 1 apprentice card with no gear to NM4 then everyone in the party will have stats equivalent to their gear if it was level 0 but with the same type of rolls. or if i join a nightmare 4 game with my fresh level 50 to scrub some drops off people not paying attention they will get warned that their item power is about to drop down to 100 (which means they will wipe) if they dont boot me. that would force people to actually progress through the gear grind instead of jumping into NM4 as a fresh 50. the game has literally no middle class the way it is now. but meh il check back in a couple months to see if people are doing NM3

								For starters let me say, that i played DD2 a little when the game became avaliable first and i did not like it at all.A lot of time has passed and DD2 is still in developement, but this long process has brought alot of the stuff i love to remember about DD1 back. Like a decently functional upgrading system for your items. A pet system. Alot more synergy between classes and the ability to have 4 heroes in your deck and alot more out of your deck.There's still alot of things wrong with the game.One frustrating bug i encountered was said to have been around for over a year with nothing done to adress it. But these are bugs and even if Trendy works slowly, they will be resolved and i am ALOT more confident in saying today, that i am happy with what Trendy has done with DD2 over the last year. Alot of strong updates to the game and i'm looking forward to seeing the full package.Not recommending because its still in alpha/beta (whatever its called these day) and bugs are a frequent thing. If you love the game you should wait untill its full release, when bugs wont frustrate you into abandoning the game.________________________________________________________________________________OLD REVIEW - OLD REVIEW - OLD REVIEW - OLD REVIEW - OLD REVIEW - OLD REVIEW________________________________________________________________________________Oh how i loved DD1..For me the only similarities, between this game and the original one are the graphical themes, the characters and enemies. The rest was apparently destroyed by Trendy and the Defense Council. Max 3 classes in a 4 class game? No thanks.Leveling down heroes? No thanks. Classes having synergy with only 1 other class, forces players to sit endlessly searching for multiplayer games, with a correct setup, though a system that tries to find sessions for you, but does utterly nothing to look for class balance at all.So try try again, and hope it finds a good session... No thanks Trendy. The lack of choices in this game makes me flee, but above all else, the utterly stupidly abysmal item upgrade system, realy just... No. I'm gonna go cry that this game turned out to be only a but a shadow of its predecessor.
