content:
Posted: October 17, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is another of those times that I'm having so much fun with a game, that I feel the need to sit down and share why it is that I feel this way. I first tested DD2 very, very early on, before it was redone to be much closer to its predecessors, Dungeon Defenders, and Dungeon Defenders Eternity. Team Trendy was still deciding on the direction they wanted to go with the project. At the time it was PvP, and I for one am extremely happy that they went back to the tried and true formula that makes the series great. After trying the game again, post-redesign, I bought into the Defense Council, and it's not often that I feel thrilled to have paid $70 for a game. Here are the things this game does SO right: Dungeon Defenders at its finest:DD2, even still in alpha, trumps the first 2 games already. The tavern is bigger, better, and packed with things to unlock and discover as you play. The game features quests, NPC's, mad amounts of loot and items, a solid campaign, and once beyond that, multiple new game modes to dive into. For an Early Access title, there is a tremendous amount of content here already, with more updates pouring in every 6 weeks or so. I do look forward to plenty more maps coming in in the future, those are pretty limited currently, but not so much so that you get bored. Trendy!Trendy Entertainment, once again, shines in their interactions with the community, in addressing bugs and issues, and in building a great experience. These guys GET IT. I mean REALLY get it, when it comes to how to treat the community, and even in alpha they're right on top of things. You'll see them reply to nearly every thread, and for a game with around 14,000 concurrent users at the time of writing this, that's impressive to say the least. They've gone above and beyond the call, even compensating the community when issues arise which reset quests or cause the players to lose progress. This is an alpha, we will ALL lose progress at times, but these guys still know how frustrating that can be! ImmersionOne of the big surprises for me in DD2 was getting into the campaign and seeing more than just the same crystals to defend. There are interactive traps on the map, and other things to defend besides just the main crystal. In one case, there were even NPC's on the map, cowering up near the throne while you defended them and kept them alive. Tel ya what, having actual characters there made it feel so much more worthwhile! Who wants to defend an empty throne? I love the added depth they've brought to DD2, it brings so much life to the game! F2P done RIGHT!Trendy has done a perfect job with the cash shop. There is absolutely nothing pay to win in DD2, and never will be. It's a promise they made, and have stuck to like glue. You can buy costumes, bags, things like that, but never boosts, or anything that changes the way the game is played. You can't go to the cash shop and make your game any easier, or make it impact the experience. You can sure look great though! The costumes for each character are quite cool, and worth a spend for people looking to support the development of the game. Additionally, even with an already bustling community, I LOVE the option for private taverns/friends only gameplay. Let's face it, most people don't want to play with "that guy", who presses ready before the towers are even placed, or who afk's mid battle. There are plenty of players around, and getting into a public tavern/game is definitely easy to do, but if you want to chill alone or with the best friend, being able to do that is a huge plus for me. The game has taken the best of what makes a free to play game fun, and added in the way to play the way you want to play. To sum up: Pro's: -The game is already head and shoulders above previous games in the series-The development team is ROCKING this! -The game has depth, immersion, and a ton of fun, even for an alpha release-It's Free to play done beautifully rightCons:-It is an alpha, so you are going to find the hiccups and bugs that come along with an Early Access game -Maps are still limited this early on, but there are enough to keep you going for hours even now

content:
Posted: December 23, 2014
Early Access Review
								I do indeed reccomend this game, especially if you were a fan of DD1. The devs did a good job making this game similar enough to the first one, but added enough originality to call it a brand new game. This is NOT just a retexture of the first one, but so much more, there are now sub cores that if destroyed open a new spawn point for enemies, ability spheres, several levels, and much more. Also, unlike most other early-access games the devs are CONSTANTLY updating, the more you sign in and play the game, the more points you earn to vote on what they add into the game. These people truly care for their players.Pro's:- Better looking (Graphics, animations, enemys, tavern)- Tons more levels, items, and pets.- New types of equiptable items including vanity items.- New enemies and boss fights.- Item leveling requires other items to be enchanted into it, instead of just paying with gems.- Seperate tower gems and ability gems- I could freakin' go on forever hahaCon's:- ONLINE ONLY; This is one thing I don't really like, since a lot of times my internet is down or just bugging out, but there is a private lobby mode, and as long as you have a feint connection to the internet, you should be good.- The menu is somwhat complicated and progression is unclear, it's hard to tell what missions you have done on what difficulty, and which one you are supposed to do next.I was a huge fan of DD1 and I am really really exited for the release of DD2 when everything is finished up.

Posted: February 2, 2015
Early Access Review
								Really liking the game so far.Got roughly 100 hours in this game of which most was in the first two weeks.That kinda goes to show that even though the game is a lot of fun in it's current state it is also still lacking. upsides : - the game feels super smooth, other than two crashes I had on day 1 I've had no bad experiences at all concerning the smoothness.- nice map variation, sure there are not an insane amount of maps yet but the ones we have are pretty diverse.- Abilities of classes are a lot more fun to use compared to DunDef1, squire for example has a taunt and an AoE stun that are just a total joy to use.- friend system works nicely and due to the way downscaling works you can always play with your friends even if they are low level. ( though obviously a full geared level 25 that is downscaled will still be a bit stronger than a normal level 1 ).Downsides:- Only 4 classes, this is mainly due to the game being in early access so I will remove this one eventually but for now it feels lacking even though they are working hard on it.- Some towers are completely useless while others are a must.  This is also a temporary thing with balance patches coming in the future but I had to throw it down since at the current state some towers are just vastly superior to others.There might have been some things that I missed out on but all in all I greatly enjoyed playing the game and will check back with every big patch , on that note a big patch is coming again soon so those kinda waiting with buying it should totally get it when the patch comes out.edit:  removed the lack of endless survival mode from downsides since it was recently added.This game is being updated a lot and I still have high hopes for the future.

Early Access Review
								LOVE THIS GAME!!!EDIT: They have now made the game free to play which is insane because this game is worth buy to play without even thinking about it.(I never played Dungeon Defenders 1 before anyone asks)So I got this game today and I played it for 8hours straight and literally could not stop playing it.  As I write this review, it is 2AM in the morning for me because I am so addicted to the game!I enjoy this game so much I sent my wife a key and she is also now addicted to the game, we cannot stop playing it.So let's get into the game itself!Graphics: So the graphics are basically a cartoon easy free mesh style with nothing amazing or special to look at, but it does offer some nice aspect to play with a cartoon/ anime feel which draws you into the game with the cool design, meaning the game feels different and runs smooth because of the unique design! Overal decent to look at for once, very colourful!Audio: The audio is actually suprisingly good, cute cat meows, funny slashing with monsters growing, cool weapon swooshing and bangs with some really really relaxing old style music that draws you in!Gameplay: The gameplay is pretty simple! Seriosuly the character controls and the way you move is so smooth and easy, you master the game in seconds and cannot complain! It is basically a tower defense with a mixed in RPG (XP, stats, money, armour etc) so you earn coins and ranks, with armour offering certain things to make you better, you get pets which are awesome from eggs to hatch into some more support... It feels like Fable meets Diablo too me which is pretty decent to me (Even though I do not like Diablo) but this game really you work at it, play with friends, form defences and fight to survive against monsters.  It also feels a lot like "Orcs Must Die" which is another amazing game but this game feels more refined and balanced correctly!Too date I am playing at early access alpha, so I am unsure if there will be any character wipes! Too which I hope there best not because I am spending over 8hours waiting for an egg to hatch for a pet to hopefully gain a legendary or mystic!!!You can also have multiple characters to create the perfect setup on maps, example I have one character which is soul Hero DPS which I use to kill the bots, I swap to my tower dps to build which is tower power so it holds my damage, once built I swap again to another character to buff my towers health and DPS and finally I swap again to another just to deal damage before hitting my turrets... Once the build is setup I change back to my main hero damage, press ready and fight. The hand has a very in depth tactical edge which you can dive into and tank the game alone. This I prefer to play on all fields to hold the best edge at all times. (You cannot swap while a combat phase, only during build phases)The armour you obtain is important to what build you would like to have for that character so it's best to pay attention to what you are doing when trying for the right strategy. A draw back I do not like is the game uses matchmaking, no party create in main menu, you have to physically press play or private and then invite a friend into the game, but even when you select private and have 1 friend, you press play and that session is no longer private! Only the lobby is because you can and most likely will join a random person (happens every time with my wife and I)There are a decent supply of maps but my wife and I went through every one in campaign in 8hours (again to date of this review I am writing) we are. Ow playing free mode which is the same maps.... There are other modes but they are... The same maps! Which believe it or not is getting tiring already even though we cannot stop playing the game! Is it pay to win? Not that I can see! I bought the digital deluxe because I enjoyed the alpha code I was given so much, I was given the special blue coin things and found the only thing I could buy with them WAS access the the vault boxes which gave me clothing items (They do nothing, they are only cosmetic) and clothing store clothing (Which again is cosmetic)I could not find ANYTHING that makes them useless, you cannot speed upgrade or use them (Too date of writing this review) that would make them worth the money or beneficial to me or the game or like any cash cow, because it is not.Would I recommend this game?Yes, in a heart beat.  I love some tower defence games and now this is a game that is XP/ Stats/ Gold/ Ranking/ Community and much more on the side to enjoy!

content:
Posted: August 14, 2015
Early Access Review
								Dungeon Defenders IIIts still pre-alpha, but second version.I play this game now about 200 hours and i still like it very much. Guess the reason is that the developers always work on this game to improve it. Dungeon Defenders was released in the year 2011. The second part can not be compared to DD. Duneon Defenders II with new 3D animations is the next step with lot`s of improvements. This game belong to the tower defense game genre. The second pre-alpha update include some new game types ( campaign, free play ) like incursion, onslaught, end game, end game incursion and end game onslought. The difficult level has added ( easy, normal, hard ) four new nightmare levels. The match type Quick match is for multiplayer co-op and Private for invited friends only. New pets are available now in epic, mystic and legendary. For all of us who expect more, we can power up and increase our pet`s affection level in order to evolve. It`s necessary to use Shellium shards for evolve. To receive shellium shard let the founded eggs in your inventory about 48 hours. The first pre-alpha offered medium challenge, now with the second alpha it`s more challenge. From easy to hard difficult it`s possible to play single too, but on nightmare it`s obligated to play in a team. The currency in this game are crystals and wyfern tokens. The crystals are included in pre-alpha and the wyfern tokens can be earned in daily and monthly missions. With the crystals for example we can buy more inventory bags, new character slots or discover accessories. For all Uber Speres and lockbox master key it`s possible to pay with wyfern tokens. The balance of this game is good. From the  fondly social and private tavern we can choose challenge on the war table. Bug report is possible too at the tavern keeper. There are some different Shops in this game. The Gran`Masta ( Skill Sphere ) support improvements for hero skills and defense improvements. The Alchemist can improve your items ( clothes, relics and weapons ), simply put all stuff you don`t need inside around your good item and improve your `better choosen item`. The Hatchery for pets can be found at stable boy. For feed your pets go to the Keeper. The Seamstress offers assessories and on the Relic Hunter shop we can buy relics. All special uber skills can be bought on the adventurer token collection shop. The game has reached alpha version and is free to play until beta.short review: ( positive criterion ( + ) maximum 5 ) - single multiplayer and co-opmusic: +++++ (4/5)graphic: (5/5)gameplay: +++++ (5/5)tutorial: ++++ (3/5)

content:
Posted: December 10, 2014
Early Access Review
Dungeon Defenders 2 ReviewTL;DR -  Video Review	 The kids have grown up!  In Dungeon Defenders 2 you continue the story as the apprentice, the squire, the huntress, or the monk.  The kids are now what appear to be teenagers with slick overhauled graphics.  And, More characters are coming.  The game is now in early access on Steam and I thought I would provide my initial impressions on this unique game.Just like the original dungeon defenders game, this is also a hybrid tower defense and Action RPG.  You still get all the same fun loot collecting, leveling, and skill points, along with a slightly tweaked gear upgrade system.Before I get too far down the rabbit hole, I was an original Dungeon Defenders 2 Defense Council Member.  This meant I have seen every build prior to the Steam Early Access public release.  This game has progressed immensely from the days of its infancy and with much excitement I am glad to say this is one of the best feeling "Early Access" games I have experienced in a long time.  They did right by the community and didn't release a buggy product.  I have yet to see a crash.  The only issues I have noticed are a few camera clipping issues.From the first few moments in the game you can tell this is a smooth product.  If you were a player of the original this will feel liquid, with a slightly faster pacing.  When the game was initially announced it was going to be a MOBA styled tower defense game that was free to play.  A lot of the original fans were obviously upset that it wasnât a true continuation of the original game; I was not one of them.  I thought the MOBA style might provide something unique to this game but those ideas were tabled, but will it probably make an appearance in the future in some form.The game did keep the Free to Play ideology though and that will likely propel this game to new heights on the PC.  However to actually in the "Early Access" you do have to purchase a copy for $25, or catch it on sale.  This does come with perks such as premium currency, a unique title, and some exclusive skins.  This is the standard fare when a game comes to early access.  However, unlike other free to play titles all items sold for cash currency will, I quote "Never grant gameplay advantage. Ever."Being part of Early Access does have a unique perk. Influence.  Influence points are earned every day you login which can be spent to vote on what various features or implementations of features in coming builds.Back to the game, each playable class has 4 spells and 4 unique "towers".  The game builds upon its original format with each spell and tower unlocking through level progression, along with ability to upgrade the existing towers.  Another area where this game excels over its predecessor is the new Wave Director which will slightly randomize enemy waves.  This could mean different enemy types, where they come from, or various stat buffs.  They are also looking to get in the occasionally, "caught you with your pants down" events.This game is currently planning on remaining in Early Access for at least a year.  Hopefully the Trendy can keep up the momentum and keep new exciting features releasing until the gameâs final release.It currently doesn't have any form of cash shop available, or pets.  The biggest downfall to the game currently is the tedious matchmaking process, which can have you struggling to get in and out games fast.  Layers and layers of menus slow the process even though finding players to play with is the fastest part.Knowing this game is going free to play but still costs money to play before launch can dissuade a lot of players, but if you enjoyed the first game, tower defense, or casual ARPG games you will easily get your monies worth in entertainment.  This game sets a good example for what Early Access games should be in their launch status.

content:
Posted: April 8
Early Access Review
								I was waiting over a month to give developers a chance to somehow fix what they broke, but after last update i have to write this out of extreme frustration. Trials update was impressive, many great ideas, but it was badly executed. As a (solo) player with very limited game time it took me almost a month to get to the point where i was.... well, i haven't reached the point where i was before trials, everything is extremally hard.And after last update (19.5) my defenses were a little stronger, but my heroes got nerfed, and enemies got buffed, i couldn't complete maps on difficulty where i was farming earlier. Bosses are unbeatable, i can bearly finish difficulty i was somehow farmin before 19.5 patchNow i have 3 options: 1) uninstall the game2) find some1 to carry me3) farm for gear that won't be any better than what i have and try higher difficulty and fail, after that, pull the rest of my hairI'm sorry this went in such direction, and by that i mean dd2 became very unfriendly for players like me, with limited game time, who simply want to have some fun solo.After over a month since Trials update launched, i have maybe 5-10% better gear compared to what i had before update, while maxed out gear is 100% better. I'm writing this after 6 hours of failing in difficulty (chaos 4) where i COULD find some upgrades. I'm still hoping developers will realize not only hardcore farmers are playing this game and i can edit this review, but it appears they are happy with how it turned out, plus already maxed players are liking new changes, because with the gear they have, little enemies buff isn't a big deal compared to buff defenses recieved (and it's noticable on high end gear).

Posted: December 30, 2016
Early Access Review
								I have 116 hours on this game on another  account Do you like towers? Do you like upgrading your towers into epic epicness?Well, i'm sorry to say but you came to the wrong game. Dungeon Defenders II focus more on the different characters different building types and each has very few upgrades for each of their 4 towers/defenses. Do you like strategically organize the best route in order to get the best gear or the item you really want?Well, i'm sorry to say but you came to the wrong game.Dungeon Defenders II makes you grind and only grind and when your not grinding you're trying your luck in crafting items and when you are not crafting you're trying your luck in different maps trying to get that one item piece that you are missing unsure if it even drops in said map or not.Do you like to get to see all the stuff in more than 100 hours?Well, i'm sorry to say but you came to the wrong game.As I mention earlier the only reason I played it more was because of my friends needed to grind after they got some of the better items ( they are properly around 70 hours ) they quit. Honestly for the last few hours all, they were talking about getting some good gear before quitting which they did.Do you like to have progressive gameplay?Well, i'm sorry to say but you came to the wrong game.As in many other tower defense games, the only real change is the monsters, heroes and towers. In Dungeon Defenders II, however, you have seen all the content of 1 character after 2 matches in about an Lvl 20 map and the monsters get reskinned and recoloured but all in all no bigger change. You get a few starting heroes and can buy all heroes for in-game currency however some of them are again very grinding Want to upgrade your towers and your hero outside of your items to improving your personal playstyle on a hero?Well I'm sorry to say but you came to the wrong game. When leveling up you gain points these points can be spend on improving your hero's personal traits however it's basically rather or not you want to be hero focus or tower focused and once you pick one of them the other is going to be somewhat just a side role dealing damage and sustaining the damage but it will fall of later into the game. Do you like fanservice?Well, i'm sorry to say but you came to the wrong game.This game have none of that

content:
Posted: December 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								In short, not yet, maybe never.It's still early access, but after playing about 35 hours, I'm probably not coming back.  They tried to stagger your abilities, you get something new practically every round, but it's still about playing the same maps over and over.  I was level 30+, but I couldn't even play the events.  Pretty lame.I don't even know why they have the tavern.  It's just a glorified menu.  There's no interaction with anyone in there, and when you're in a shared tavern you are likely to get sucked into a game on accident.  That will drop you out of whatever thing you were doing.Balance is a big issue.  Having a ranged weapon that fires two projectiles is dumb, because neither of them go straight.  They also do 1/2 damage each, so you might as well just get a 1 projectile weapon and hit things.  Attack speed is the same, you do the same DPS whether you're firing 1 or 4 projectiles per second.  There are a few interesting weapons, but they become obsolete very quickly.  Higher tier items have a formula.  You get more effects, but the stats are the same.  The effects are totally unbalanced.  Some of them are super powerful while others don't even make sense.  Eventually I just sold all weapons if they didn't drain HP or if they fired multiple projectiles.For a game that is all about items, item management is stupid.  You can get hundreds of drops per round, but there's no way to just sell all the low quality ones or anything.  No favorites.  No filtering.  Just a pain.  I was spending more time selling items than I was playing the game, what with all the waiting for rounds to start and an item overflow that times out too quickly.

content:
Posted: November 10, 2016
Early Access Review
								I lost interest with this game after being a beta-tester for the Abyss Lord.I had broken legendary gear, able to solo nightmare 5 as huntress.But, what's fun about solo'ing stuff when there's no real challenge or sense of accomplishment?At times playing with other players actually feels like a crutch, you have to spend time arguing "Who's the builder, check my stats, I have more damage. But I have more speed, blah, blah."You also have to share the gems with those that argue, when their towers are just insufficient to do the task needed.At at times there's no need to even attack, just spam abilities now and then.And I get that can be 'fun' for some people, but it got boring for me over time.And I know Trendy has been trying to make Hero combat fun and needed, but it feels very forced. And the fun factor still isn't there.I've kept an eye on the updates ever since stopping to play after Abyss Lord's release, but nothing screamed at me to return to the game. The loot didn't interest me, the costumes didn't interest me, the pets didn't interest me, the new enemies didn't interest me, the events didn't interest me and the new heroes didn't interest me.To be honest the only thing that made me say "Oh, cool" was the current Terraria + DD2 collab, but that's not enough for me to want to reinstall the game.I don't regret buying the game when it was P2P and buying some of the skins in the past to support Trendy, they're an amazing company with insane talent.But this has no replay value, unless you like more OP loot to replay the same levels again and again and again...It's like some bad bragfest of who can solo what with the shiniest most expensive costumes.

content:
Posted: July 8, 2016
Early Access Review
								Like others who had originally paid for this game, I feel a little slighted by the shift to the Microtransaction model. Being "rewarded" with a single title and a small amount on abstracted in-game currency feels like a bit of a betrayal. I realise I backed a game that was not released and that was my fault entirely. Just had slightly higher hopes from TrendyEnt than what was received.PROS:-Its basically just updated Dungeon Defenders-Controls are responsive, if a slight departure from the original game. Vetrans to DD may find it awkward that all towers must be walked to and pointed at to be intereacted with, as opposed to just going into an aerial m view and selecting everything, Placing towers also feels wonky without this.-All the characters from the original have made a return (or are in the works) with more to come. That said, they're a grind to unlock regularly, or you can opt to pay a microtransaction.There suppose to (maybe) still be a PvP MOBA-style game mode with a large selection of classes to chose from. This might be worth checking out eventually.CONS:-I feel the new tarvern is too large, anjd awkwardly spaced. This is entirely personal.-The community seems to be kinda eh. I can remember jumping into the old one with a bunch of randos and co-ordinating builders and repairment and whatnot, all without a hitch. This time around everyone seems to do their own thing-The mana handed out at the begining of a way is untrue to the previous game. Now each player can open exactly one chest. Mana can still be given to other players, but this makes having one builder difficult, especially given the tone of the community.-The inventory and hero deck function essentially makes the Defender's Forge obsolete, yet it still remains, I'm assuming only because a team member spent time modlling, rigging, and animating it.-The bag system is abysmal - if I have 10 bags, why do they all have to be in the same window? Why not allow players to have multiple bag windows so as to not force you to constanly open and close them and drag and drop and scroll etc. -Early Access and still microtransactions. This is another personal point, but I feel that Steam should disallow any game that is tagged as "Early Access" from having a microtransaction store.-To me, maps feel awkward and sprawling, even if they do have a good flow, especially the early levels when compared to those of the first game. Perhaps sightlines could be improved-Its hard to convince friends to play this F2P game. This could just be my personal circle of friends, but most are more willing to play DD1 and start everything fresh there than they are to do anything here. -Personally, I prefer the old art direction largly over the one this game presentsOverall, the game isn't terrible, but it has shifted its direction and that's kinda left a bad taste in my mouth. I wouldn't say to strictly avoid this game, but would agree that this is a game you can skip and not have missed anything.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2016
Early Access Review
								I personally enjoy this game, but I don't recommend it. I place out cons of this game first.1) Bugs, many bugs and developer ignore it / take a long time to fix itSo there's a recent meta (defense combo), but we found out the defense is buggy, which makes it overpowered. I've started this game about 3 months ago, yet to be fixed by now (21 - dec - 2016)2) 1 hit on the core and lostThis won't happen on easy difficulties (Normal, hard, nightmare 1). This often happens on Nightmare 4 games, those monsters deal extremely high damage and your core just have about 2k health. They deal up to 20k damage, even able to kill you in 1 hit.3) Grinding system, sucks.You may ask "what do you mean by it sucks?", well, we grind our weapon from different maps that offers us the same weapon (legendary) with different stats, yes, thats it, different stats. But for example I just want (Hero dmg) and (Elemental dmg), sometimes you might replay the game up to 10 times, even up to 30 just for the stats. 4) Unfair leveling (IPWR level)For those who yet to play the game, IPWR means Item power. So when you just started, your average IPWR is around 30 - 150. But you can instantly jump into any public no IPWR requirements, grind loot from there and instantly jump from 200 - 600. This is a huge disavantage for those who started the game a long time ago and grind slowly from Nightmare 1 to Nightmare 4 difficulty.5) Spheres are in a complete messOnce again for those who yet to play the game, spheres is a token (or whatever you call them) that gives you a stats, for example +40 hero damage, +10% experience loot, etc. There's some of them which cost a lot (Indeed alot, because you need to spent 2 weeks or even 1 month to get it), and they're useless, pretty much. Because if the current meta defense doesn't require it, you won't find any help with the sphere if you are not someone that like to research.I've spent around nearly 200 hours, and i've gotten bored and lost interest to the game, this game is base on the angle you play it, if you don't like it, just deal with it, because no one is going to change the meta UNLESS the developer does.

content:
Posted: May 2, 2016
Early Access Review
								Waited some time for a few patches before I decided to review.  Has it been 2 years already? Well like most I was highly anticipating this game and was expecting that original DD feeling.  Did I get that?  ...Not exactly, but that is ok given games have to evolve in some way, even though it's not always based on our personal wants & needs.  At first I was excited and then somewhat disappointed and then hardly play anymore, but I come back time to time and it seems DDII can't grab me and keep me prisoner like the original still can.  I still recommend this because it has some changes coming, but replay-wise for now, not so much.  I still love the DD universe and appreciate all its parts, so hoping that flare to keep playing returns.NOTE:  Some of the below are based on friends of friends opinions, but seem to be matching equally to random people I asked the same question.PROS:1. Familiar Music themes2. Familiar map areas revamped3. A little more hero customizations4. Knight actually welds a shield without being an accessory5. Graphics are well done frame to frame animations6. Still maintains that unique hero feeling7. Abilities are a bit different, but still enjoyable8. Handling pets has changed9. New Quest system is realistic & fun10. Month-to-month quests for pets & other rewards is a nice addition11. Still has that Boss Fight fun factor12. Customizing inventory = Names, auto-loot categories, by class, etc and etc13. Easy levelingCONS: 1. Limited inventory compared to the original2. You have to purchase inventory slots (Bags)3. Towers to damage to creature formulas have changed4. Huge limitations on gear upgrades compared to original DD5. Handling pets has changed (placed as PRO and CON because itâs a huge argument to most in my circles and circles of circles)6. Open tavern creates some negative feedback on the community as a whole and reporting system might as well not exist (can be avoided with solo tavern play or private + inviting friends); which leads to a very immature atmosphere7.  Normal Mode difficulty does not feel like Normal mode, so difficulty to difficulty is not a realistic transition from one to the other.Most arguable PROS & CONS:Handling petsGraphicsAbilitiesOpen Tavern with no control or monitoringDifficultyEasy leveling (easy to vets but to new players? ...compared to the original)All-in-all I love that the DD community is still going in some way, but... (PERSONAL OPINIONS SECTION)1. Did it grab me and dedicate me like the original?       No2. Do I feel Trendy was able to make a worthy sequel?    Yes, but wanted that old rewarding feeling3. Am I already finding myself anticipating the next Dungeon Defenders?    Yes4. Will I still play DDII?    Yes, but not daily = a couple times a month5. Am I not playing due to the unregulated chat?    No, but I see how the racist names and 24/7 bashing among people in the community can alienate many new players and some vets alike.6. Will I stream DDII?    No, and it's not because the community is very small, it's just that I only stream/record games I play daily to almost daily = no streaming or YouTubeSo basically I like this game and can recommend it, because I do play it, but for me it lacks that replay value like the original granted.Sirspoony rating:    7.5/10

Posted: February 15, 2016
Early Access Review
								This is a game with a bit of graphics and well.. did i mention it have stuff that moves on your computer screen?The rest is a bit lacking...Not that fun not that rewarding, It's like that friend you have that always promises that he will change but still makes the same stupid mistakes over and over. He tells you that he values your input and listens to what you say. But then ignores you and runs away yelling lololololol while wearing a crazy cap (CC for short).All you can do is stare at the thing that moves, like your hypnotized by the movement and the stupity. You know you could do something better with your time. Do it, run away from the guy with the CC. It's not worth it, he will never change. It's all empty promises.There comes a point in every gamers life, when you must realize what's in front of you and let go... Just let it go.. Or don't go there in the first place. It's a wery bad and dark place filled of regrets, and restless nights waking up screaming in the middle of the night... Remeber It's all a fantasy, like the fantasy you have about this game ever being any good. It's time to face reality.And if you who tried DD1, DD2 is not the new DD, it's something else but with the same name. The game is just not that interesting or fun. It's like a dull idle game / hold down the button action rpg hybrid. I have som great memories from DD1, played it around 300 hours. Lots of maps that was fun to explore, just running the map and failing a lot of time just to understand the mob movement, was part of the fun. Finding unique loot on the maps, and big maps that you could get lost running around. There was always a sense of progress. A lot of...  let's try that map again and see if i can go one wave furter, maybe if i tweak a little here and a little there. There was a lot more strategy involved in DD1.DD2 is like a no brainer action-rpg with towers. You get a clear line that shows where the mobs will be, and chokepoints pointed out where you should build your defences. A lot more focus around finding the right loot, not upgrading loot as in DD1. Now you can spend days just farming for the perfect loot so you can take on the same map as you where farming the loot on. Even the skins in DD1 was a lot more rewarding since you hade to accomplish something to get the skins, now you just hand over your money and get your skin.Most of the time you fail a map while in a group is because someone from your team fell asleep and forgot to repair the wall. Or was watching youtube on his/her laptop while holding down the fire butting pointing the bow down a lane not caring what happens in the game at all.This game is so bad i regret playing it, I could have done so mutch more with my time like staring at paint while it's drying or contemplating my navel.

content:
Posted: January 12
Early Access Review
								DD2 is a very polished game with some very flawed fundamentals.  It's not really a tower defense game.  More of a baracade game, with shooting.  But not really fun shooting.  Most levels boil down to standing in the same spot the entire level and with four huntresses hosing down their lanes. I want to like this game so bad.  But honestly, it's just boring.  DD1 was much more fun.         Allowing players to hot swap heroes seemed like a good idea.  It's not.  The dps heroes are too powerful.  Here is a short breakdown of what you will experience:Start a level and use your builder to place initial baracades and towers.  This part is fun.  Probably the only fun part.After spending all your money, switch to the huntress and position yourself where you can see the most lanes.Level begins - Hold down the left mouse button.Level ends - Make a sweep of the level, heal some towers, lay some more towers, upgrade others.  (again, somewhat fun)Level begins - hold down the left mouse button.After you've beaten the level, the game has automatically picked up the prodigious amount of loot that dropped.  Now its time to sort through all that crap like its a sale at the thrift store and you're hoping to find at least one thing of value.  Chances are, you wont.  But that wont save you from having to sort through it all for every character you own.  Its as bad as doing your taxes, I kid you not.  I cannot express just how much crap gear you need to sort through.  It's awful.TLDR:  Instead of this, play Orcs must die 2, or even OMD unchained.  Also, Kingdom Rush does TD way better than this.  This game wants you to grind your life away.  Don't do it.

number of helpful: 18 of 21 people (86%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 21, 2016
Early Access Review
								This is a decent game. I've put a lot of hours into this game, meeting people, making friends, and simply socializing as I work my way up to find better equipment. I play this game to simply try out the new classes and try the variety of weapons this game has. I have never spent money on here to get where I am now and I don't find it much of a hassel to grind for what people would normally pay for with real money because you can still get things free. Paying for bag expansions are the only thing you really need to worry about. It's not a requirement, but your items do become full quickly. I was able to obtain 450 free gems in the past due to selling the collectable cards the game provided so I could get another bag expansion but let me tell you where I'm growing extremely frustrated over...The game's bugs/glitches. I cannot tell you how many times I've played this game and found myself randomly crashing or logging me out in the middle of active gameplay. There are bugs in this game that has been around since game release and no one has considered fixing them at all. Examples: Random log out of session, entire lobby randomly gets kicked out, a weird crash that causes you to log out and end up under the map in the lobby, falling into an endless void and everyone is glitched as 999 iPWR (You cannot simply log out to fix this glitch, you have to X out the entire game and reload it for it to fix), inaccurate defense stats when someone else looks at your defenses (Sometimes they even glitch so bad that they show only 1-4 as dmg), match making error, and much more.I've tried everything to reduce the chances of crashing, even lowering my specs to the lowest possible in the options only to still see myself freeze up and crash without warning and I have an actual gaming computer that can handle heavy graphics so I don't see why a game as simple as this would cause me to crash to much. It's extremely frustrating. I would love to recommend this game to people but due to the bugs that have been in this game for so long, have been mentioned to the staff on several occasions and still hasn't been fixed, I cannot recommend this game.I might consider changing my recommendation once these common bugs are fixed.

content:
Posted: March 24, 2016
Early Access Review
								I put in a little over 200 hours in DD1. Its mind-boggling the scope of how you took a fun game and what should've been an easy sequel, and managed to make something awful. All in the goal of chasing after a market you will never get.  Seriously, it's never going to happen.Sure the graphics are much nicer. Kudos for great artwork trapped in a horrible frame. The gameplay is now awkward. The forced social stuff is exactly that, forced and impersonal; in ways you simply can't seem to understand because there is no point to "team building" in DD2. This isn't an MMO, and it's also not LoL, and it never will be. Worse, the myriad of wonky systems feel poorly glued together, yet collectively don't have the depth of the simplier systems of the last game.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2015
Early Access Review
								So i thought after all this time i should step up and bring you guys my review:Early Access review: As an early access game you can only notice 2 things:- Small balance issues (which are being worked on daily)- Content (specially end game and higher difficulty) These are not game breaking of any kind, it's the less buggish early access i've played (Did i mention that it's still only pre alpha? Man the game totally feels way better).So should you get this game? Well that depends, the game will be F2p, if you have your doubts and only want to test you might wanna wait, now the game is early access, so that means there might be wipes and lack of appropriate content for the time you want to spend in the game, but you can always entertain yourself in many other ways and help the game develop. If you're okay with purchasing a game that's not released yet don't doubt it. If you want to help the game get better, go ahead and don't think twice.FAQ:-Do Developers even care about the feedback? Definitely they do! Many changes have been made for community request, and many were added. There's even an influence system that you can vote with points you gain by being active!-Dev Interaction? Yes there are streams every thursday and friday ; Forum activity by the Devs ; A devlog coming out weekly about what the devs are working on! -Better than DD1? Dungeon Defenders 1 is a full complete game, i believe DD2 has potential to be way way better than DD1, but it's still Pre-Alpha, so it's normal you might not find as interesting.-F2P? Won't that be P2W? Nope the game will have no such a thing as sold advantage, it will depend on costumes and all type of cosmetics and whatelse they can come up with but no sold advantage of any sort =).There's a lot of info i want to give you about the game to help you judge it, but go ahead and watch the streams/videos and decide for yourself, i found myself getting the game a while ago, and i simply love it, love the game love the dev interaction, totally worth it, this game is going to rock for me. There are some changes that must be made but i believe all that will come in time!

number of helpful: 155 of 270 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 9, 2014
Early Access Review
								The game is very similar to the first one in some points, even the graphics that everyone likes, even if I like the first one better, a matter of personal taste, I recognize the improvements.On the similar aspects, I give a thumbs up. As the first one the gameplay is very cool and the maps are wonderful. The characters and towers are very much alike too.The bad parts are the one that differs from the original DD. As you level up you are given a very limited and poor choices of specs for your skills and, as I have seen, most of the choices are pretty useless. That messes up a bit with your character customization, since you are forec to buff up a single tower with your specs, and once you get 10+ points on that skill its upgrading becomes pretty useless, since you wil get a 0.45% boost on that skill or less.The other aspect is that you can't level up the things you want to play with. You can't level up tower damage, health, hero speed, attack speed etc. You depend on item drop to do that, and you depend A LOT on item drop (and I say A LOT). You can go almost 30 hero levels without ever finding a gear that fits your hero, so you won't play it the way you want for a very long time. That is a terrible decision by the game designers and, for me, what ruined the game, because what makes a good RPG is character creation and the fact that you can costumize you hero to play the way you want to play it. DD2 won't let you.Personaly I like to play builder. That is not an option either in DD2, since you get enough "build mana" to build one or maybe two towers in a map. And, if you don't go aura, there is  good chance you will waste your mana by having your tower destroyed in the first waves.The other thing is that you cannot kick a player from the map or even vote kick him. So if someone decides to troll the party on the last wave, he will do it, and will remai unpunished. But I believe that there will be something regarding that for after the pre-alpha.If the game was just a few dolars expensive or maybe free to play, I would give it 5 stars, but, when I pay almost $20 for it, I feel a lot of regret.

content:
Posted: November 20, 2016
Early Access Review
								Hello there! :)I'm a completely new DD2 player, but I've already played for quite some time. Lovin' it!I don't understand all the negative reviews. No game can stay alive forever; everything gets boring in time, but why not enjoy it while it lasts? All games are played for the entertainment value; if you think the game is fun and fits your personal preference it's a great game.All the reviews in here comment on the game being F2P and that it should've just stayed as a P2P; well, the game is completely free of charge. 4 completely free heroes (you have to complete the first quest in the game to obtain two of the "free heroes," but that's easiely done); you can play through the entire game without ever buying anything.The only things you buy are either cosmetic or inventory space; what's your problem? You earn Defender Medals over time and can buy any of the heroes, again, completely free of charge.The only thing that really forces you to pay money are the actual skins. Are skins really that important to people? Does it really ruin the game for you? Well, that's sad for you, but I'm enjoying the game a lot. Just started playing and I'm already 45+ hours in. Great game! :)Score: "9.5/10"

content:
Posted: October 2, 2016
Early Access Review
Perfect game in the hands of the wrong developersDungeon Degender 1 was one of those amazing games that everyone knew and lot of peoples liked it, so it comes with no suprise that Dungeon Defender 2 was made, but it just doesent live up to the expectations.After around 10+ hours it quickly comes out obvious that the game just doesent have enough content... Maps,characters,gamemodes... there just isint enough variety. The game comes out so short that it only takes few hours to reach the max level of 50 and from onwards youll be forced to grind your way trough those exact same maps that arent interesting really at all. Numerous Bugs and Graphical issues also kill the experience a lotGood: Cartoonish graphics are nice Lot of items to collect 4 Player CoOpBad: Lack Of Maps No Customization (Other than paid outfiths) Same enemy types (Gets kind of repeative) Bugs (Antialising from ingame doesent work, Constant Crashing, Memory Leak, Connection issues, odd error messages)DD2 deserves to be made into a big name game with a strong playerbase but with all the issues and lack of content it just falls short too fast. Giving the game a steam workshop so users could craft theyre own maps would make the game 10x better or even the devs coming up with a 10-30+ map pack with new games modes and/or bigger character roster would definetly make the game much more worth the time.As of now its fun with friends but other than its just mediocre tower defence game.

content:
Posted: December 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								Game is far too different from the first one so far, in a bad way.- Each hero now only has 4 towers (used to be 5)- Unique towers have been removed (electric tower, ensnare aura, bouncer blockade, etc)- Monk has lost all but one of his auras- Many of these new gear passives enforce 'meta' builds- Melee combat is uncomfortable with the new 'lunge forward with every attack' thing- Resistances have been condensed into two categories (DD1 had 4)- Enemies are less interesting- Imo, the graphics feel unfinished, worse than DD1 evenThere have been improvements, but for them to come at the cost some of the core features many of us loved about the first game isn't worth it. The game is just too different. Had Trendy not changed all of these things so drastically and seemingly without good reason, and just improved the stuff that needed it, this game could have been a smash. As it stands, I'm not a fan of this game and wouldn't recommend it.

Early Access Review
								I really wish I could give this a thumbs up, but I can't.  I'm more neutral it than anything.The biggest issue is there really isn't a sense of progression like Dungeon Defenders 1 had.  I understand that there were balancing issues, but half the fun was dumping all your stats in range or attack speed and watching your towers perform ridiculously.  Dungeon Defenders 2 has more unique towers, but you can't really "play around" with them as everything is tied to equipment.  Specs are an interesting concept to replace tower/hero stats, but they're either broken, uninteresting, useless, or some combination of the three.Hopefully it'll turn around by release and impress me, but right now it just doesn't feel like Dungeon Defenders.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								Rewriting my review so its more up to date with the gameFirst up my playtime is divided with alot more hours put on the ps4 version of this game.Also on the ps4 version i have soon three level 50 characters with one of them being around 400 item power.Towers and spheresWith the updates rolling in fixing balancing and fixing stuff it gets a little bit more funwith setting the towers up and what towers to use. Like before i only needed a barrage of cannon towers and maybe one or two ballistas sitting close together. Now with the spacing you cant have as many cannon towers to make the range work all the time which then require the heavy cannonball sphere so you can set out some long range cannonball towers. The heavy cannonball tower isnt as great as the standard one in damage but the range makes it more effective in some lane defences.That being said it gets kinda weird to go to your character changing station on the map just to change the sphere so you can set out the heavy cannonball tower then go back and change back to whatever sphere you are using on the ultra sphere slot.++ a bigger combination of towers on the map then just three (two good offensive and the wall tower)- - weird way to make it happensuggestionThe heavy cannonball sphere should either have more effects or make the sphere into something else you maybe unlock upon reaching level 50 and not something you have to equip. More like just a alternative version of the cannonball tower that you can EASY change to when in the building stage.This also applies to the other tower changing spheres the other characters have. Its a great idea so i say: more alternative tower version = more gameplay (yeah i know, it requires a lot more work and balancing also).LootI love how they changed up the hero weapons to have more variety in weapon speed and attack pattern. There is also the special weapons (betsy weapons and spooky weapons and more) and thats real good. "more variety" = "more gameplay" to a certain degree.StoryBecause i have played from the start of this game when it was more difficult to see any story then the Dark souls games, i dont have any say in this, i think i have to play from the beginning with a new character to experience it.

content:
Posted: March 26
Early Access Review
								To Echo the other reviews: New update basically ruined the game. They stripped out all the old endgame content and replaced it with the same maps but instead of mechanics it has randomized buffs on monsters a la The Underdome from borderlands. They also made gearing arduous and frustrating, and based on a hidden value that your existing pieces have. Give it a pass until they do some kind of fix.EDIT: Another couple dozen hours of play in, def give this a pass. We got all our gearing woes sorted out and managed to slowly crawl up to the top tier content where one is treated to the worst designed enemy in any game I've played in this decade. This is an enemy with about a third of the HP of a wave boss, that spawns in groups, can teleport around the map, and glue themselves to you one at at time doing massive damage to you and defense near you. They mechanically get knocked off when taking damage but don't worry, the other ones that spawned in other lanes at the same time will happily take their place. Also you're constantly silenced as long as they're on you and they seem to leave you permanently silenced when they're done. Which has been a 'bug' for the month since this launched. Is it doable? Sure. Is it fun? Absolutely not. Total trash game design and a poorly designed frustrating difficulty spike.

content:

Early Access Review
								This game seems to have done to RPG games what Team Fortress 2 did for online army/war games. Made the genre nice and fun. A great, fun game to grind away with your mates in teams of 4 or by your lonesome. Bright and cartoony graphics make it easy on the eye, yet not cheesy in any way. It runs like a charm, smooth play and I have yet to experience any bad lag issues, just a couple of spikes here and there. The Devs are doing their job with consitant updates, changes and improvements. Looking forward to seeing where the game is headed. My only gripe is that you can't gift items to friends in game, or even drop them on the floor for some to pick up, OH, and it would be nice to see some way of upgrading your armour and weapons. That's about the only negative things I could say about the game really. Great fun and addictive.

content:
Posted: March 20
Early Access Review
								- I rate this game Positive with Mixed Feelings-Heres why:I am a big DD1 and DD2 fan, I generally enjoy tower defense games, and this game is no diffrent. Since the game is now free, I can easily have friends download it, and hang out for a day just leveling new characters, or trying difficultys that are too hard for us just too try and win, what you want out of a tower defense game in the first place.-Why is the game getting so trashed?Recently there was an update, a lot of players myself included that had spend hundreads of hours basically got knocked down to a casual level, our gears stats were randomized and most our effort was destroyed. That said, its for a better tomorrow. The game gets updates that changes it to its fundemental core for endgame, when this happens you always role the dice on if you're going to be setback, don't look at it as your time wasted, but as the game improving to a final state. Its obviouse the developers want there to be a semi-hard core scene for DD2, and its all in prep to see who has the best stratagy to down harder content, and get better gear.-What do I dislike?As if stolen from Diablo 3, they added paragon points after hitting max level. (I say D3 because the only game I currently play that has them. :) )) These add more grinding to help improve your character overtime, but personally I'm not a big fan of them, the game seems to be designed around these paragon points for character progresion, so thats also part of the reason old and new players were on a more even playing field, the more you grind the more it'll help you climb the ranks.-What would I like to see in the game?I would like to see some sort of ipwr, armor restriction, or something along those lines to joining harder difficultys. I want there to be a clear progression path for all players old and new that can't be skipped because you have someone like me with enough gear to afk through harder content, friends love me but they don't understand how quickly they burn them-selfs out just letting someone carry them while they afk, thats not where the true heart of the game lies.-Final ThoughtsI'll continue to play this game on and off for years to come, i'll continue to support the design team by buying their skins and other DLC, for a day I can clearly say "This is better than DD1, hands down." till then, keep on grinding, unlock those characters, and make use of the weekend events ect.

number of helpful: 53 of 88 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 15, 2016
Early Access Review
								It's a great shame that Dungeon Defenders II is as dissapointing as it is. I loved the first one and played it loads in splitscreen with my partner. While I bought a few DLC packs (that I understand were fairly controversal) the base game felt like a complete experience with plenty of levels and characters and tons of replay value.I actually bought Dungeon Defenders II before it became free to play for around Â£18, due to my love of the first game. My initial reaction, particularly of the artsyle, was of how much it resembled those crappy mobile games like Clash of Clans. Dungeon Defenders 1 was of course very cartoony but had a level of charm that elevated it above the generic cartoon style of F2P cash-cow mobile trash. Dugeon defenders II on the other had looks very tacky.  The problems don't end at the artstyle though; by going F2P the game now feels like a rubbish F2P MMO. When launching you are greeted by messages asking to buy things and enter a lobby with loads of other players milling about and spamming the chat with nonsense. As a result I overall did not enjoy my experience with the game so far. My reward for both buying in to the game early and spending Â£18 was very little, maybe 1 skin as far as I can remember. Performance isn't great although the game is in early access so this may change. Overall I feel the move to F2P was a huge mistake. While the tower defense genre is hardly an easy genre to compete in what with many other games existing in this genre I feel Dungeon Defenders 1's blend of tower defense with Diablo-style classes and loot was unique and interesting to stand apart from the competition. On top of that brilliant levels, music, art design, and charm meant the first Dungeon Defenders was well worth the up-front investment. I feel the developers almost didn't have faith in their own product with Dungeon Defenders II in their decision to go F2P, feeling they needed to rely on the game being free to attract an audience and that an up-front cost would turn away buyers. As a result the game has taken a huge hit to it's value; feeling tacky, grindy, and just generally unappealing. There is still hope I suppose, the game is still in Early Access and there is time for the devs to reverse the decision of going F2P or at least improve the game signifiicantly that it becomes worthy of a try. By the time the title releases (and exits early access) I will give it another shot and see if it is any better, I hope so because I want to enjoy this game as much as the first but so far I've not been impressed.

content:
Posted: May 20, 2016
Early Access Review
								I got this early before it was free to play.  I loved the first DD and I like this one.  I have some resurvations about some of the mechanics but in general I like the way the company is approaching it.  It's fun and it's not Pay to Win.  It's Pay to customise (mainly your look)  there are a few convinances that cost also (like extra bag space) but in general you don't pay for better weapons, upgrades, faster leveling, or anything else required to win.  I think DD1 had some aspects I liked a little more but DD2 is still great and it's not done yet.  The company listens to the players, lets you vote on upcoming choices and has great live streams where they actually address and answer YOUR questions.  If you like the First Person Tower Defense games (Sanctum, DD1) I recomend it.  And I'm still looking forward to seeing what else they do to make it even better before it stops being Early Access.Update:  Game is still fun though content is still a bit light.  I wonder if the game operated on DLC terms, where I could buy more content, if the updates would be more dense.  As it is I tend to wait a month or two for content updates then jump on and have a few days of fun before waiting for the next few content updates.  If you are planning on trying this out for the first time it's worth it, Free for a lot of fun.  If you like it I recomend buying bags to support the company as they make the game a bit nicer.  If you don't then it didn't cost you anything.   However if you run out of things to do or are waiting for some of the changes or new content to come aobut, know that it's a slow process.  Trendy seems to still be delivering, and listenning to the people who play, but it does seem painfully slow.

number of helpful: 30 of 47 people (64%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 12, 2016
Early Access Review
								Dungeon Defenders 2 should've been a very, very good game like the first one, but since its early access release, there have been so many tiny little things done wrong that were never corrected. All of these cascaded into the poor time of today; and no one is better for it.Bugs that have existed since the dawn of the game are still in, I'm not talking about small minor ones. No, I'm talking about pretty major ones such as matchmaking issues, enemy/map glitching and player's towers being broken. On top of that, the game is repetitive. Once you've played the campaign once, you've seen practically the entire game. You're never forced to adopt and refine your strategies or are given new interesting challenges to play through. The "incursions" the game offers, maps that have a special objective of some sort, are a far cry from DD1's challenges due to the fact that the player is given very little option to play around the special objectives. Simple invincibility fields or having the player run around to catch collectibles do not provide interesting challenges to the player, because there's no smart way to play it. You either play "Simon-says" with the map, or do the same thing you've been doing except without personally attacking with your hero. The player is not given a choice, and without a choice to make there is no obstacle to overcome.I believe this comes from a fundamental design flaw within the development team. They seem to be prioritizing making new content and incentive systems instead of making a game that is worth playing. If the game itself is not a sound concept, it does not matter how much content or grind mills you put into the game. Nobody wants to play your revival maps, and they most certainly don't want to run through your grind mills. This is why it's very important for early access games to focus on the game itself, not the content it has.If you're just a person looking for a game to mess around with friends though, there's a few hours of enjoyment for you here, as long as you can look past all the bugs. Otherwise, I would highly recommend simply purchasing DD1 instead of hoping this game works. If you really want to look for this game in the future, try to look at what the development team is doing and try to figure out their focus. Once you notice a large shift in their thinking, that will probably be the time this game comes back to light.

content:
Posted: March 26, 2016
Early Access Review
								I am having trouble enjoying this game anymore, even though I want to. Pros:You can get fun outfits without having to pay real money for them.You can get some of the highest lvl pets without having to pay real money for them.There is no pay to win aspect in this game.With those pros you would think that this game would be a great mmo tower defense, but the cons make you loath the process you have to undergo in order to even attempt the nightmare difficulty playthroughs. DD2 stops being a game of strategy long before you reach even the hard or insane difficulty levels preceding the nightmare ones. Cons:Grind, Grind, Grind goes the player. Item drops are arbitrary. What I mean by this is that the high lvl gear that drops as you solo a difficult map, will hardly ever be gear you actually want for ANY of your characters. What adds insult to injury is the carnival ticket mechanic. During every map playthrough, carnival ticket's drop, and for every 10 tickets that drop, you can spin the carnival wheel for the chance of getting Legendary gear of your current avg item lvl. This is the only way to dependably get good gear, because Legendary gear is the best in the game. So, even if it is not perfect for your build you may still be able to use it. To use the wheel in this way requires that you equip terrible tier gear that have high item lvls. This way you increase your avg item level before you spin the wheel. If you do not have tickets, you can use 2500 in game currency to spin the wheel. So, you end up farming maps for gold, then spinning the wheel until you get better gear, finally playing the same old maps at a higher difficulty setting, and then restarting the process all over again to advance to the next difficulty setting.Therefore, this game is more than just a grind fest, but also a redundant waste of time with no true reward for effort expended.

number of helpful: 12 of 15 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2015
Early Access Review
								Charming. Technically tower defense but not really. Hack-n-slash and pew pew game that takes almost no skill at all. Farm endlessly for no reason because there's literally nothing else to do.No real strategy. Basically block off every path and prevent the mobs from getting through. Have good gear = win. Not having good gear actually makes it fun and challenging but the fun doesn't last all that long.There's essentially one only one way to play each of the 4 characters. There is no depth to this game at all.High level play, like level 30+, devolves to players swapping their high level characters in to place OP towers and afk every round. Bugged flying mobs are the only thing keeping people active because it slows down the farmfest. Beyond level 40 the game begins to feel nearly dead. Probably because people with half a brain don't keep playing hoping it gets more interesting like I did. There are barely any players to play with aside from the farmers. Once you find a farmer, you can afk and go do something better with your time. Literally anything.You constantly replace gear because this game is all about ascending and descending in power. Take a few zeros off the numbers and check it out! It's as if you're still level 10! The difference is maybe your weapon looks cooler and your gear icons glow and have colorful borders.The gear you are constantly replacing isn't shown on your character. Instead, the devs have opted for costumes that you can buy with real money so your character actually changes appearance aside from weapons. Some of the costumes are cool but that's not going to excuse how silly the Squire runs and pretty much just makes it look even more ridiculous. It's like the devs looked at the melee character and said, "Make this one pretty much â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥." However, the attack animations are pretty damned good. The character goes from derp to Spartan warrior at the click of a button.It's charming and could be cool but deep down, just like The Mighty Quest for Epic Loot, it's garbage and will be until time erases it.

content:
Posted: February 11, 2016
Early Access Review
 Decent game, did not live up to DD1	Admittedly, this game is fun. The item progression and character progression make you feel more powerful as you play. The art style is unique and fun. Having it free to play is a bold move, but having paid for access earlier, I do not feel rewarded.However, this is a shell of what it could have been. Dungeon Defenders 1 had more classes, a better item system, a higher level cap and even more enemies (feels better killing 1000 enemies rather than 100). Rather than refining on a tried and true model, they created a different game, taking multiple steps backwards. Character leveling takes far too long, enemies do not spawn properly, waves take ages...After the trainwreck of Dungeon Defenders Eternity and this game falling flat, I cannot recommend this game, or even Trendy. While they produce many podcasts, they seem to have almost no involvement with the community (or at least the vast majority). The games have tons of bugs, many of which should have been easy fixes. It's laughable, really.

Also, a lot of the negative reviews on the front page are complaining about issues that have been fixed or changed or complaining about features that are not in the game YET.In my opinion, This game has a lot of potential. Even though it is currently in early access, it feels like it has enough replayibility to keep me going for hundreds of hours with the latest update. Now, here are some of the pros and cons for the game in its current state.Some Pros: + Pretty art design, the way it is done gives the game a more 'Toon' feel to it. + Alot more enemy diversity compared to DD1.  + The Game is regularly updated, with the latest patch adding loads of content in to the game. + The people who work on the game interact with the community and hold Developer streams on Twitch every friday. + According to the developers, There won't be DLC Map packs, so the community won't be split. + The music in the game is good. + The towers have more 'Personality' as i would call it... + Once it goes F2P, It won't be P2W. + Betsy and cute Propellor Cats + If you do buy Early Access, you get $30 worth of ingame currency to buy costumes with.A few Cons: - It's in early access, so you have to pay to be able to play it. - Tavern is laggy and the game feels slightly unoptimized. - Uber Skill Spheres cost waaaaaaay too many Wyvern Tokens.. (i call the tokens 'Betsy Bucks') - Level cap that does not take long to reach. (Level Cap will be increased later on) - Earlier maps become meaningless to play once you hit level 25. (They are adding Incursions soon for them to make them playable in late game again) - Bug paradise - No controller support yet.Note: Most of the problems i have with the game a due to the game still being in development and a lot of the features are not in it yet.Final Verdict: While the game is unfinished and has it's fair share of problems, it's fun, which is what people really look for in games. 8/10 (in it's current state)

number of helpful: 21 of 32 people (66%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 10, 2014
Early Access Review
								Firstly, the game is good but a few things have just irked me from the get go. The fact that when you level you cant put any upgrade points into tower stats is a massive fail, it is necessary to reinstate this to be able to even have the smallest chance on higher difficulties. The fact is to improve your towers you are completelly reliant on equpment drops (which are rare as â¥â¥â¥â¥)  The lack of controller support is annoying for now but i understand that this will be added later so isnt that important of a point to make now.The graphics are a nice improvement and i like the art style in general. Trash equpment that nobody wishes to pick up now no longer vanishes and gets banked at the end of each wave it stays until the end of the map making everything look cluttered by the end and instead of auto selling everything and splitting the cash it splits it into each persons inventory which you then have to manually sell or wait a few days for the auto sell.the preorder stated $30 of in game cash but my account has 0, not sure if thats a UK thing but i havent got a dime.The map order is strange and have yet had a chance to work out what sort of order I should be doing them in with no solid structure like numbering added to the map names it is slightly confusing. The lobbies need an option to kick or to votekick idle players as they come in the game and build a few towers the reap the benefits of xp with no action able to be taken against them and it gets worse when the random lobby host is rolled onto them on endgame and everyone has to find a new lobby.The building mana needs to have a higher drop rate as I have gone through games only being able to build a handful of towers that are then just destroyed as I dont have enough mana to upgrade or repair them.To sum up, levelling feels pointless apart from being able to equip slightly better armour now and then when the lynchpin of all rpg style games is character progression and on dd2 it feels completely dead and worthless. Many more issues such as droprates need to be looked at and until this is updated i will probably stay away from this game for now. I will change my reccomendation upon further updates if improvements are made.

number of helpful: 14 of 19 people (74%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 29, 2016
Early Access Review
								Ver. - AlphaHello, At the beginning I would like to say that the game itself isn't bad, but there's no "Neutral" button to press and my personal game preference pointer is slightly towards "Wouldn't recommend", that's why my review is negative.The game itself isn't that bad, just so you know.As a new player to the "Action-Tower Defense" games you'll probably like it. The opposite goes for players that spend XXX hours playing the first Dungeon Defenders.Anyway let's write about few things that I would like you guys to know...1. This time they've made a game as F2P(free to play) with cosmetic microtransactions(mostly) as Cash Shop. Don't be fooled by this. Character slots are limited to 4 - you need to pay to get more slots. And you will need more, when new characters will be introduced to the game. The second problem is you Inventory, starting bags are limited, they fill with items really quick - more bags of course are available with cash. It wouldn't really be that big problem if the items like chests or pet stuff would stack, but sadly it doesn't...2. Unlike DD1 you characters here have more skills to use, which is kinda nice - 3 skills + heal, but you have less towers to build, only 4.3. Game looks a bit better than DD1, a bit more cartoony I would say.4. If the game host got crappy connection or his internet will start doing some nasty stuff(high ping, dropping packets, etc) you and other players will be laggy as hell, be ready for that.5. Pet hatching time, 48h to hatch an egg - hatching can fail(no pet, sorry)6. Number of trash items dropped isn't bad, like it was in DD1, it was earlier in alpha but they've reduced trash drops.7. No character customization - just outfits unlocked via chests.I think that would be all I can think about at the moment.To sum it up, DD1 sucked me in for many, many hours of fun, and I really enjoyed it and love the game, while DD2 just doesn't feel this way, it lacks something that keeps you interested in the game.In a bit funny way I will type this:You sit at the table and you see two things on this table - 1. Sandwitch with cheese(represents DD2) and 2. Pizza(represents DD1). Which one would you pick? - This is how I see this two games. DD1 - 9/10 (-1 for the number of trash drops)DD2 - 4.5/10
