								Take this review (like you should with all reviews) with a grain of salt. I played Dungeon Defenders 1 back in the day on the Playstation with my bro and enjoyed it greatly. When DD2 was announced, I had a trip of nostalglia back ot the good ol' days. Initially, I got a chance for early access and didn't really like what I saw. Its really not a game for lengthy play throughs though. I get easily bored of the same maps after a while and can predict where all the major issues with waves come into play.That being said, its still a great game and still a good strategy tester. I even love the predictability of the waves which allow me to mess around with different characters and their tower strategy. This game has room to grow and has shown that it can grow. Dungeon Defenders will always have a spot on my game shelf.

Early Access Review
								When I played Dungeon Defenders 1 on the X-box 360 I enjoyed it, until it came to multiplayer and experienced nothing but hackers and modders. However here in Dungeon Defenders 2 I can honestly say that I have found my new haven in the video game community. In my first week of playing I felt all of the nostalgia from DD1 rush back. I quit many other games that I had invested (easily) hundreds of dollars in, to start this game and dedicate myself to the immersive game play that Trendy (and Etheria, the Realm they created) are known for. The game is, hands down, on the top of my list for games. I have invested (proudly, I might add) to the continuation of this games developement. This is the open Alpha, and there is nowhere to go but up for this game.Obviously, the game is Grind intensive, but you get out of this game what you put in. In my first week I had 5 level 50's and 700 iPwr on each of them.Overall, I heavily recommend DD2. I hope that our friends here at Trendy continue the great work and continue to amaze us with new content. Happy Hunting!

content:

Early Access Review
								Fun with a group of friends, but not that great for soloing unless you are willing to create multiple characters. Much like Dungeon Defenders 1, interactions between towers and the involvement of the player brings a new variable to what would otherwise be a traditional tower defense game. Average run length for each map is much shorter compared to DD1 (about 20-30min vs 1hour+) and the game overall is quite short, though there is decent replay value. Visuals and gameplay mechanis are much improved but the high degree of customizability that I loved from DD1 is reduced. Relatively a worthwhile purchase.

content:
Posted: June 4, 2015
Early Access Review
								Developer: Trendy Ent.Publisher: Trendy Ent.Genre: Action Tower DefenceThe emperor of the Action Tower Defence games is back. Help your friends, build towers, auras and traps; repair and upgrade 'em. Get back to endless waves ofâ¥â¥â¥â¥â¥kicking fun!In the first installation of the series, we were playing as the Little Defenders ( sons and daughters of the real heroes). These little heroes defended the Eternia Crystals and put an end to the Evil's plans but just when these littlelings lost all their power and hopes at the end of the first game, their beloved parents came to rescue at the right time and defeat the evil of the evillest.With Dungeon Defenders II, the developers giving us the "Real" heroes and their real adventures. Oracular graphics, incredible character models and wondrously designed maps and gameplay mechanics that mostly operating like cogwheels; these are also what they are throwing at us. And as a Early Access it stand out like a sore thumb among others.Lets start with seperating facts of DD1 and DD2:-DD1 adopted the simplest co-op game formula; buy the game and its â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥ of DLC's. DD 2 will be free when it is released ( People who bought the game before f2p release get cosmetic items, in-game crystals for costumes and some other premium gifts)-DD1 has cell-shade and simple graphics. DD2's graphics are resembling a good animation movie, it has cartoon/animation like graphic concept.-DD1 use mana as currency, DD 2 differentiate mana and currency. Now we have gold coins $$.-DD1 just have 1-2 basic costume per character and you need to buy DLCs for them. In DD2 we have evolving and much more detailed costumes ( even at this stage, there are many compared to DD1), which you can buy with real money currency.-DD1 has tons of DLCs, (it is not %100 clear but) developers thinking of earning money from cosmetic items like MOBA's and supporting the game with free expansions.-DD1 has offline private option. Ä°n DD2, you need to be online even though you are playing solo.Yes DD2 has core mechanics from the first installation; but it looks better on the surface, it feels better when you play it and it is much more refined than most of the other Early Access' and DD1. Let's get to pros and cons part:+ Will be F2P!+ Fantastic graphics and colour palette+ Refined gameplay mechanics ( developers are trying to make it much more stable )+ Developers that are listening to us.+ Good animations and rigging+ As a pre-alpha, it has less bugs than a lot of open beta phase games.+ Fun to play, get repetitive after some time but not boring.+ Except a few trolls, the community is awesome.+ Constant updates and hotfixes.- Minor graphical bugs- Some balance issues between classes- Pet system needs some work- 4 towers per character constrain some tactical elements- As of now, the content game has falls a little short.I think i managed to summerize what you can expect from the game at this stage. Hope it helps :)TL;DRGame is solid, but falls short on content. If you are not sure about buying this and haven't played the DD1 before, I suggest you to wait for it to be released for free.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 2
Early Access Review
								 I'm sorry I know I don't have too many hours in this game as it is but I played this game before the update made on 02/28/2017... I loved the game back then I was excited to play it but the new update literally killed this game for me! For instance one of my favorite towers was the Flameburst Tower. It did an excellent amount of damage and it did decent AOE when it hit. It was butchered to the Flamethrower Tower which now has pitiful range awful DPS and no AOE damage. The towers of the Apprentice pretty much stayed the same but now it just doesn't feel the same.  Next we have one of the other character's I loved to play the monk. His boost aura, Lightning Aura and Serenity aura were all must haves on the battle field. The Boost Aura allowed towers to become even more powerful and finish enemies quicker and easier!  The Serenity Aura healed team mates who were low on HP but didn't have enough time to get out of combat and heal up. The Lightning Aura was an AMAZING AOE tower that did a good amount of damage to anything inside of its aura. You could pair this up with the Barracade from the Squire and be set!  Now here's the thing... All three of those towers were amazing on their own... How did they screw it up? Change the previous Boost Aura to the Flame Aura, give it Lightning Aura's AOE effect but make it worse then what it did previously. Change the Serenity Aura to the NEW Boost Aura which gives pitiful amounts of boost to your towers. Seriously I couldn't tell the difference between a boosted and non-boosted tower! It's horrible! And then the kicker than may make me never want to touch Monk ever again, they change the Lightning Aura to the Lightning Strike aura... They got rid of the AOE storm damage of the amazing Lightning Aura tower and replaced it with a very slow, very unreliable, single strike tower. It doesn't do AOE and the damage it does if it even fires at all is awful! Why did they change what was so much fun to play in the first place?!  As I said they changed a lot in this patch already right? But there's one last thing they changed that I might never want to touch this game again because of... That would be the fact that they got rid of Skill Spheres, which were amazing in their boosts and quite useful in certain play styles, got rid of stat points, and replaced all of it with shards. SHARDS THAT GIVE SO LITTLE BOOSTS IN YOUR EQUIPMENT THAT THERE ARE NO NOTICEABLE DIFFERENCES WHATSOEVER!! They spat in my face when they refunded my Skill Spheres! This new shard system is not only confusing and doesn't help in the slightest but its also takes up so much inventory space! Granted you get a lot of inventory slots but that doesn't change the fact that Shards are useless with their minuscule stat boosts and their unappealing system.  Overall, this used to be a good game... I loved it so much and it was such an amazing one that I thought would last me a long time. The only reason I even got it was because of the Terraria crossover which was amazing. But after this recent update all my drive of playing this game again is gone. I'm sorry Trendy Entertainment but you butchered your game so much that I don't want to play it again until everything goes back to the way things were before the Endgame Update... They got rid of what Dungeon Defenders 2 fun and interesting to play for me... And that's something I just can't forgive.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 1
Early Access Review
								Stopped playing this game before terraria update, the current update made me want to come back and check things out and like a lot of people I didn't read the patch notes about gear being changed to all hero type gear except for relics being tower gear. Honestly that doesn't bother me that much and them changing the meta was fine with me. Before the update I was one of those people who did use the pdt and serenity build and if I had to create a whole new build for this update I was absolutely fine with that but as of right now I wouldn't say the game is unplayable but I just don't feel that sense of progression or feel like im getting anywhere even though I had some ipwr 750 gear pre-update. My biggest gripe with the game currently is with offensive towers where they at this point really can't kill anything on even chaos 1 and in order to kill most enemies I have to dps them down with a hero. Now I am generally a solo player so me having to dps is normal anyway I rarely afk in my own game so having a dps is fine but as of right now with the offensive towers being as they are to where I am legitimately doing most the work is wrong for a tower defense game. One major gripe is defense range, I'm not saying that they should roll back to the defense range it was before the update but this currently needs to be looked at because this update was suppose to make it where any dps hero can also be a builder but with offensive towers being how they are this doesn't seem viable. Although there some towers that will work it like the AL ram tower and apprentice firethrower tower and couple other ones it feels like unless you use these towers or have the heroes other then the original four your out of luck. Another thing is the inventory currenlty needs to be reworked since right now it is too clunky and messy this isn't too much of problem though in honestly since they do have a search but still needs to be looked at.  As of right now I will still play but not as much as before and right now I can't recommend this game until they rebalance offensive towers and fix up the inventory UI.Contiuation after Patch 19.2:So before this hotfix I was able to clear c3 decently while dpsing solo with my gunwitch and using dryad world tree and nimbus, huntress pdt for anti air, and abyss lord ramsters. After this patch though they have made things worst and not what everything was wanting which was to make the other towers more viable again.Instead of getting tower buffs for the towers not being used we get a cost to upgrade nerf to the world tree, severe damage nerf to the nimbus and the standing near tower DP shard nerf, damage of PDT is even nerfed more with crit chance reduced. Also the emp orc they made it even worse seemingly increasing its emp range and making ti stun on every attack now. So now in terms of offensive tower the only viable towers seemingly are the ramster or the flamethrower, for blockade at this point I would say either use which ever you can get to highest HP and upgrade quick. In terms of anti air I don't even know because I was using PDT as my anti air but now you might have to switch to skyguard which has a pretty low attack range and that is with a good bit of range points in Ascension.So sum up this hotfix all it did was just nerf some viable towers even more and buff enemies. At this point I don't believe they are even listening to the community or even really addressing the feedback from the community. I was one of those that was hoping for better changes but with this update I have lost hope in what they believe are fixes and balances to their game.So based upon this hotfix I still will not recommend the game still unless towers become more viable and the only time I will spend on this game currently if at all is only on doing the medal daily or weekly only.

content:
Posted: March 2
Early Access Review
								 I'm sorry I know I don't have too many hours in this game as it is but I played this game before the update made on 02/28/2017... I loved the game back then I was excited to play it but the new update literally killed this game for me! For instance one of my favorite towers was the Flameburst Tower. It did an excellent amount of damage and it did decent AOE when it hit. It was butchered to the Flamethrower Tower which now has pitiful range awful DPS and no AOE damage. The towers of the Apprentice pretty much stayed the same but now it just doesn't feel the same.  Next we have one of the other character's I loved to play the monk. His boost aura, Lightning Aura and Serenity aura were all must haves on the battle field. The Boost Aura allowed towers to become even more powerful and finish enemies quicker and easier!  The Serenity Aura healed team mates who were low on HP but didn't have enough time to get out of combat and heal up. The Lightning Aura was an AMAZING AOE tower that did a good amount of damage to anything inside of its aura. You could pair this up with the Barracade from the Squire and be set!  Now here's the thing... All three of those towers were amazing on their own... How did they screw it up? Change the previous Boost Aura to the Flame Aura, give it Lightning Aura's AOE effect but make it worse then what it did previously. Change the Serenity Aura to the NEW Boost Aura which gives pitiful amounts of boost to your towers. Seriously I couldn't tell the difference between a boosted and non-boosted tower! It's horrible! And then the kicker than may make me never want to touch Monk ever again, they change the Lightning Aura to the Lightning Strike aura... They got rid of the AOE storm damage of the amazing Lightning Aura tower and replaced it with a very slow, very unreliable, single strike tower. It doesn't do AOE and the damage it does if it even fires at all is awful! Why did they change what was so much fun to play in the first place?!  As I said they changed a lot in this patch already right? But there's one last thing they changed that I might never want to touch this game again because of... That would be the fact that they got rid of Skill Spheres, which were amazing in their boosts and quite useful in certain play styles, got rid of stat points, and replaced all of it with shards. SHARDS THAT GIVE SO LITTLE BOOSTS IN YOUR EQUIPMENT THAT THERE ARE NO NOTICEABLE DIFFERENCES WHATSOEVER!! They spat in my face when they refunded my Skill Spheres! This new shard system is not only confusing and doesn't help in the slightest but its also takes up so much inventory space! Granted you get a lot of inventory slots but that doesn't change the fact that Shards are useless with their minuscule stat boosts and their unappealing system.  Overall, this used to be a good game... I loved it so much and it was such an amazing one that I thought would last me a long time. The only reason I even got it was because of the Terraria crossover which was amazing. But after this recent update all my drive of playing this game again is gone. I'm sorry Trendy Entertainment but you butchered your game so much that I don't want to play it again until everything goes back to the way things were before the Endgame Update... They got rid of what Dungeon Defenders 2 fun and interesting to play for me... And that's something I just can't forgive.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 16, 2016
Early Access Review
								I liked the first Dungeon Defenders a lot. It's one of the most played games on my Steam account. I've only played a little bit of the sequel so far, but man, I am struggling to find any enjoyment in it.  The structure is mind-boggling. The focus on online/social taverns, extremely limited quick match options with no server browser, having to load back into the tavern in between every map in the campaign? What are the developers thinking? Forcing everyone to be online all the time and giving us no control over who we match up with leads to every game being half full of afk players or max level characters who are wiping the floor with the low level maps for some reason.At least when playing solo in a private game, I finally get to stop and look at the maps and use some strategy. But even then if I exit out of a map and try to do another one, I run into errors saying that I have made too many matchmaking attempts recently and to wait a few minutes. Can't even play the game alone. Thanks Trendy.I cannot recommend this game at all in its current state. If a loot and stat-based tower defense/action game sounds appealing to you, I would highly suggest playing the first game instead.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game would be great but....1.) you are constantly thrown in empty servers2.) the player base is full of people that don't understand strategy as basic as "if you put up walls so they are forced to stand in a high damage AOE they will die quickly"3.) People constantly leave games if they aren't full, an absolute rarity 4.) Once people have left there is no way, that I have found yet, to easily report them. This goes for spamming, griefing, etc.5.) This is a game that should not be played alone. The same fun as playing an entirely dead MMO. GW1, my baby, i'm looking at you.IF these problems get fixed from alpha this will be a great game. Not too buggy and fun game play. I prefer the fantasy vibe, but Sanctum 2 is executed better IMO. If you are willing to hold out, do it. If you want fun now and not in an unknown amount of time, play Sanctum 2.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 1, 2016
Early Access Review
								Honestly, half the not recommend reviews are just plain stupid. The game is great and has no paywalls. New heroes? You can get them by playing the game! I know, shocking. And no - Just because you can't get something within 5 minutes doesn't mean it is bad. Oh and the DLC you see that may turn you off from the game? Not a single one is what I would count as "True DLC", 2 of them are for people who wish to support the game (Defender & Starter pack) and the other ones? Skins or bag slots. They aren't making new content that you have to buy, they are selling skins. Stuff that the art team can make if they have no work to do.And for anyone who mentions how the game is still in early access? Yes, cause y'know, games take time to make. Not every company has 100 workers or whatever and can produce a game out every second. Can I recommend DD2? Yes, as my review says. I have yet to run into any problems so far - Not to say there aren't any. But early access is early access - You can't download/buy stuff like that and not expect bugs. Content doesn't come out super quick, but the devs also aren't silent like other devs. They may not post something every day, but they do keep us updated on stuff. DD2 gets my thumbs up.P.S. For anyone who thinks you should get all the new heroes for free because you bought into the game, you are stupid. You got what you payed for.

content:
Posted: February 11
Early Access Review
								I will be writing this post from the point of view of a player that has never played Dungeon Defenders I.This game is pretty much Sanctum meets Diablo and Borderlands.It is a pretty looking FPS (first person shooter) set in a tower defense game. The game itself is mainly centered around loot. Getting weapons, armor and pets which upgrade your hero(es).Pros:â¢	Pretty looking visuals.â¢	Fun loot system (rarities, traits, certain map/mission bound loot).â¢	Great co-op play with friends or random other players.Cons:â¢	Lack of/bad difficulty scaling. It will be impossible to beat a difficulty higher than hard with a low level character as it does not scale with your level but instead is set to level 50.â¢	Bugs. Lots and lots of bugs. For example: People joining private lobby sessions, loot being sent to bags which have autoloot disabled and many more.â¢	No support for Borderless Windowed mode (alt tabbing is a pain and might get your cursor stuck).â¢	âEarly accessâ after two years of release. Feels like an excuse to not do/delay bugfixes.â¢	Pricing of âDLCâ and currency. While the game is free to play, I would consider paying 20 Euros for some stuff. However that would be able to get me a single character. In order to buy all âyear 1â characters I would have to pay 60 Euros, the price of an AAA game title. As long as the prices stay this way I will not make a single purchase.â¢	Currently unobtainable currency locks skills in certain stores.â¢	Very slow free to play progression for additional heroes. Your first 10K medals costing hero can be bought in about a week due to campaign rewards. After that you will be getting like 300 medals a day for daily quests on average while heroes still cost 10K medals.â¢	Goblin Siege Rollers.While this game has issues, lots of them, I will still be giving it a thumbs up because I simply enjoy the (free to play) gameplay, and that is the most important thing about a game.

content:
Posted: January 23, 2016
Early Access Review
								Don't like the free to play aspect. I would have gladly paid $60 for a better experience. I recall annoucements that you would only be able to pay for asthetic items, nothing that would make the game easier. Well you have to pay to have more than 4 heroes and pay for more inventory. I personally am not dumping in the money pit. As far as content goes, only 4 heroes(which is understandable with early acess), but who knows if you would have to pay for some hero packs when those come out. Tower changes for each class which is refreshing. Not that i didn't like the old towers but something new like that is good. Maps are terrible. There is no challenge on a build. The enemy paths are so short that you could literally build anywhere and win. Armor does not show up on your hero, so you will buy costumes. Again, i would have gladly paid money for the game to have that capability and avoid a money pit. Costumes, as of right now, aren't that great. A couple of good ones for a couple heroes. Huntress costumes are garbage in my opinion. Amount of content is lacking and bugs are present. I wouldn't expect anything else from even a game that was just realeased let alone an early access. The deciding factor for me is this has been in alpha for over a year. Seems like progress is going to be very slow considering they were working on it before it was released for early access. But don't worry, the money pits are up and functional so you can dump some money in. It is free to play so it's not like you are going to regret the decision to download, but not worth the time for me.

								As a huge fan of Dungeon Defenders 1 and having spent many hours looking around and impatiently waiting for Dungeon Defenders 2, I finally decided to buy it and see what is going on with this game.I was way more impressed than I expected myself to be. Hopefully no more wipes though, pretty please.

content:
Posted: March 11, 2016
Early Access Review
								Pay To Win game. The best deal is $100 for 12,500 Gems. You convert gems into items in this game. To get a pass into the Dragonfall Carnival for a chance at Epic Items you need to pay 150 gems. This game used to be okay but after it went the route of PTW, it lost any chance to be a great game. Pity.PROS1. CampaignThere are 16 levels for you to play, ranging from Level 1 to Level 40 (Max).2. Dragonfall CityThe Tavern, the Personal Room, the City, the Catapults and all the Merchants make the game look great.CONS1. Pay To WinYou can pay cash to get Legendary items ahead of other players. PTW just spoils the game.2. Spin The Wheel for ItemsThis is a PTW mechanic. You either use 10 tickets that come from drops or spend Gems.3. Low Player CountFor a 4-player game, there are really few players.

content:
Posted: October 9, 2016
Early Access Review
								I played DD1 and loved every second of playing.  I was extremely excited about DD2 but when it came out as a MOBA, it bombed royally!  I was extremely disappointed with this and even paid money to support their plans to change it back into its original gameplay.  Instead of redoing the game, it appears they kept some coding and left a bit of a MOBA game play.Here are my issues with the game.1. Time - Itâs been years and this game is still in alpha/Beta testing.  Extremely disappoint considering how much time itâs been.2. Price for heroes - The price for heroes jumped from $2-$5 to $99!!!!!  What were you thinking?3. Maps - The maps are just wonky to say the least.  A whole wide hallway and one blockade in the center can stop them?4. Towers - Some hero towers are either underpowered (mage) or overpowered (Lava mancer).  One Volcano can hit an entire map from the center of the playing field.  Whatâs the point?5. Gear - Your gears IPwr is off.  One level 50 green with less stats have higher IPwr levels than a level 50 Mythical with more stats.  This makes no sense.6. Heroes - You limit the heroes to four unless you pay more money.  Not even LOL, Warcraft, Clash of clans, or other iOS games do this.  If I am going to pay money, then you better offer me something great in return not BS costumes!7. Costumes - its overkill!  Fix the game and make it actually work instead of playing dress up with your hero.8. Abilities - The old abilities are gone and replaced with junk abilities which require mana that cost too much and feel like a MOBA game.  9. Mana - The mana is way too small to see and having everyone run around the entire map just to collect mana that only they can see is annoying.  If Player 1 already covered an area, why does player 2 have to run that same area to get mana.10. Mana - The amount of Mana a player receives is way too low.  11. Pets - You no longer receive pets like last time, instead you have random drops with random stats, with random eggs, and no real way to farm.  itâs all just luck.  Which really sucks12. Bags - I have 12 bags or so with 16 slots and scrolling and trying to organize them is a pain and a hassle.  No real way to organize all your gear, instead you have to play move and shuffle just to get gear in the right place.13. Tutorial - you really get no tutorial on anything, it all just click and figure out on your own and hope you donât lose anything.14. Towns - You get randomly disconnected from town because a host has left.  Why do I have to rely on a host for a town meetup, shouldnât this be a server hosted town and not based on someoneâs connection.  Does this mean that one personâs PC is hosting all our heroes at once?  Seems crappy.15. End of map - You have to wait for all players to make a decision before replaying the map or going to town.  if a player disconnected or leaves the session before you all press G, you all have to wait for the countdown to be over before you can go to town.  Seems like a complete waste of time.16. Heroâs orbs/Spheres - The cost is too high and the abilities are too low.I can go on and on about how much this game is nowhere near game ready.  I recommend either waiting to even see if this game will finish or just going back to DD1.  As of right now, I cannot stand playing this game anymore.  I have four toons, all 680 ipwr levels and am bored with farming maps that have no real direction.

content:
Posted: July 8, 2016
Early Access Review
								I do not recommend that you pay money for this game.  The main reason is the server issues.  Every time I try to play this game with friends we have trouble connecting to each other in private sessions.  Sometimes the game itself will not even load because of bad server connections.  I regret paying money for the game (but that is mainly because it is free to play now).  Also, in my opinion, games that allow you to play but make you pay money for certain things that exist within the game is not cool.  If you do play, since it is free, and you do not have server issues and aren't tempted to pay a ton of money for a different costume, you will probably like the game.  It has tons of potential and I really hope they get the bugs worked out.  Until then, I am gonna have to recommend that you do not play this game.  If it gets better I will change my review.

content:
Posted: May 1, 2015
Early Access Review
								"it has a long time befor it becomes a succeser to the original", well that day has come.I'm officaly addicted, I had some mixed feelings about this in the beggining.but its safe to say, that this game is a succesor to the original!While im no where near to end game, my IPWR on my main builder being ~150, and only one charecter being max lv (in the procces of maxing another one).But lets start from the beggining;GOOD STUFF The early quests help you figure out what the h3ll is going on, and bassicly the basics.from a sertian point the quests becom something along the lines of this: "get a charecter to lv 40" and when you finish that one you have to go to some npc for a new feature or item and the loop starts over again.If you chose a DPS/CC charecter to start with, you must play in a group.and i even found farming to lv 50 in sertian maps diffcult without the other defenses can build, like the sky guard tower which is crucial for maps where the wyverns simply dont come out of the lanes where the mobs come out.In the very start Trendy has claimed that switching between towers and mixing the setup is crucial, and from what i see, IT IS!building with one set of towers is allmost impossible in most end game maps and modes.while element combos are not as effective as they first were, they still pack a punch.NEGETIVE STUFFThis is a free2play game, and an "in game currency" was a must to keep the cash flowing and to keep Trendy from not supporting the game.And the customes dont effect gameplay at all, and acttualy decreases youre currency in game, either from buying myth gear with gold or buying lockboxe's keys with wyvern tokens.but the bag system is one of the worst things i have ever seen in a free2play game.Grinding loot is the core of the game, and keeping alot of important loot is, well, important.If you have more bags, you will get further. hands down no question.some say its for more  but i call this a big load of BS!Auto pickup loot is a major thing with the bags, instead of every wave going and looking if you got good loot and then picking it up, you can just have 10 bags optomized for auto loot and in the end of the match just check everything.this is a pay2win concept, where  if you have more money to spend itll be much easier for you to get better and proggres.Pets.yes, pets have a terrible system.not the pets them selfs, or the hatching system, but the storage system.Pet food, eggs, rotten shells, â¥â¥â¥â¥ you need to evolve the pet, all stored withing the same place of youre loot.now how is that a problem? you may ask.It is a major flaw, and makes the game even more pay2win.its connected to the point i made earlier, you now even have less space for loot, since you need slots to keep youre eggs, shells pet food and the other stuff.Trendy did make the pets a different bag, where only pets can be stored, but you still have to pay more cash to store more pets!End notes:If you made it this far i thank you, for putting the time and dedication to read all of what i just wrote.I would love to hear feedback from you, the reader!I would give this game a solid 9/10 for new comers to the series, and for hardcore original fans a still pretty solid 7/10.

content:

Early Access Review
								Dungeon Defenders 2 is more or less the same as it's predecessor. Although there are less characters, less maps, and less viable strategies. The only thing really new in this game is Microtransactions. Community is rude, unlwelcoming and elitism is as rampant as it was in the first game. Leveling is slow, boring and ultimately devolves into pointless loot grind. The game is also very buggy and crash prone, requiring a lot of work to get to it run in a stable state. DD2 feels like a hollow shell of what the Dungeon Defenders was. None of the charm of the original game is present. Time will tell if DD2 improves, but right now I'm not holding out any hope.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 24, 2016
Early Access Review
								First off, this game is absolutely different from Dungeon Defenders 1. This isn't to say that it's a bad game, just don't go into it thinking you can pull the same stunts as the last game. You are not going to be afk farming in this game. You will be out on the battlefield holding down the fort and defending with all of you character abilities. Every original character feels really balanced and has a few roles they can fill. Gear hunting is great because there's actual game-changing abilities on the gear that can dictate how you are going to be playing the character. There's more game modes and difficulty options that can keep you entertained and on your toes. Also, they Devs really put an emphasis on "use more than one character or else you will fail". Like I said, you won't be sitting here building with a mage and afking wave after wave. In this game, it just isn't good enough. You need to find your combos and create/build characters that synergize. Have one character throwing oil while your mage is igniting them with his flame towers and stuff like that. It's a good twist. Not to mention there's no more stupid helicopters flying in and dropping ogres from random places on the map, or spiders that drop down from the sky out of nowhere to sabotage your builds. All in all, this is a solid game and I can definitely say it's a step in the right direction. Worth playing, hands down. My only real complaint is the strength of the DLC characters. The summoner and EV2 just don't belong in this game at the power they're currently at. The summoner is a step above all of the original 4 in terms of straight dps output. It takes a lot for others to compete with his tower strength and utility. However, EV2 is just absurd. Without gear and using one ability, EV2 can solo campaign mode on normal at lvl 13. Then she can solo nightmare 3 at lvl 30. At level 50 with around 300 gear score, EV2 is easily putting out about 300k dps. A hunter with straight hero dmg and ability power is only pumping out around 50k, but it requires double the gear score. That being said, EV2 is reaching levels of damage that SHOULD NOT be attainable in this game! SHE NEEDS AN IMMEDIATE NERF. Proton beams allow her to sit on the crystal and shoot halfway across the map and clear lanes with ease. Levels that should be challenging are just turned into minor inconveniences with her on your squad. She takes the fun out of the game because people who play her just don't have to actually PLAY the game. They don't need to find/build the synergy between their heroes, they don't need to farm gear and hunt for specific abilities. They don't need to balance stats or even move. They are able to push into the endgame with ease, and it's disgusting. By making these DLC characters as strong as they are, the Devs are just straight disrespecting the game they made. Playing a monk (whose towers are completely underwelming and weak) to playing EV2 or the summoner is just disgusting. Personally, I'm waiting for the barbarian to come back (shouldn't have even taking this long, in my opinion). However, if he's even half as  broken as EV2 while the other original 4 stay at the same terrible weakness they're at, then this game is going into the recycle bin.

								I want to like this game, but without knowing what the game's content is about, I can't. The main issue I had was performance issues, not the usual kind of fps issues that people are complaining about on the forums, but there was few troubles just trying to get the game launched.On my first try, I clicked the Play button in the launcher, then nothing happened. content:
Posted: November 26, 2015
Early Access Review
								I'm only recommending this game because it's free-to-play.  Micro-transactions are present in a lot of miniscule aspects of the game, but in my 90 hours of playtime I haven't felt like anything was an essential purchase.  I hesitate to recommend this game because after a while, I realized I wasn't playing this game for fun.  It was just a simple slow grind progression that I get sucked into so easily.  There was always another level to gain, or the hope for better gear, but for the most part, I would just set up my defenses on whatever the hardest map I could beat at the time and let the game play itself.  I rarely went online, and I say that it was an even split between good experiences, bad experiences, and joining games that already had everything under control.  The initial 20 hours or so were probably the most fun, since that's when new abilities were being learned, and I was still perfecting my map layouts.  Again, it's free, so give it a try. I'm going to wait for the official release before I dive back in.  I love the concept of these games, and spent many hours in dungeon defenders 1, but the sequel has worn thin for me in the endgame.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2015
Early Access Review
								Hard to review this one, as a fan of the original. Where to begin? Well...let's start off with what I don't like.The game is quite a bit easier. The maps are visually more interesting to look at and have more full 3D depth to them, which makes them interesting to run around in at times. But each lane is identified for you immediately, and the maps are designed in such a way that you can't have an "aha!" moment as you discover a way to place a single tower to cover multiple choke-points. Either the developer placed the chokepoint for you and pointed you right to it, or the chokepoint doesn't exist. This can help to eliminate the feeling of "trial and error" gameplay that existed in the first game, but it also means you can never feel like you're outsmarting the developer when you find a good way to place your towers.In some ways, this doesn't necessarily change the final feeling of the game, as in the first one, once you figured it out, you always placed towers in the best spots. I suppose this makes it easier to play the game in public groups or with friends that don't really play video games the same way you do, but it makes all of the maps feel a little samey after awhile, because you never get to experience that first moment of wonder as you treat the map like a puzzle to be solved.The pricing of the cosmetic items is...quite high. I find myself learning to enjoy the default skins, since purchasing the outfits i'd like would quickly put this game at a higher price than an off the shelf, AAA title. I don't have a problem with the microtransactions themselves, I think it'd just be nicer if they were a little more "micro" so I could get a few skins and not feel like i'm getting robbed.Now on to what's been improved!The new hero-deck system will (eventually) prevent a single player from effectively filling every role. Playing with friends in the first game could be quite difficult at times, because you were capable of leveling up and gearing out the entire cast, and placing every tower type. Your friends could quickly outgrow you, and if you didn't play a ranger or barbarian, there was little reason for you to be in the game with such a person, since their towers would be better than what you could make. Being limited to a certain number of heroes encourages you to work together - once there are more hero types than there are deck slots, you'll need at least two players to do everything. It's forced co-op sure, but at least you can always be useful to your friends, since you can bring something that they cannot.The way they introduce new unit types as mini-bosses feels good. Later maps and harder difficulties can repeatedly spawn mini-boss versions of these enemies too. Since there are a lot of things that can define an enemy (such as movement speed, walking or flying, special attacks, resistances), they keep your defenses in check and ensure that everyone has something to contribute. Defenses and your attentiveness get tested as each lane fights to divert your attention across the map. The new, proper bosses feel a lot more interesting than all of the bosses from the first game, too. They have mechanics that make them more than a "bullet sponge", and it was an excellent move making them a bit of an outside force that interacts with the map and the waves in interesting ways, instead of just being placed awkwardly and requiring that you blindly hit it with regular attacks and awkwardly placed towers.The aesthetics of the game are sweet. Everything is much nicer to look at.I think my biggest complaint is that I just wish the game was harder. Not in a "just make the numbers bigger" way, but that the maps were actually more interesting to play. It feels like the entire campaign is a tutorial to get you acclimated to the games mechanics. The maps never seem to get nearly as complex or interesting as they were in the first game....The revisited maps in 'the harbinger awakens' content update come closer and are definitely more fun than the maps that came before it, which gives me hope for the future. You really can't go wrong with "free" though, and I can see myself losing a few more evenings as I continue to play this with my fiancÃ©e. But ultimately, I don't think either of us will be sinking dozens or even hundreds of hours into it like we did the first time around.

It's forced co-op sure, but at least you can always be useful to your friends, since you can bring something that they cannot.The way they introduce new unit types as mini-bosses feels good. Later maps and harder difficulties can repeatedly spawn mini-boss versions of these enemies too. Since there are a lot of things that can define an enemy (such as movement speed, walking or flying, special attacks, resistances), they keep your defenses in check and ensure that everyone has something to contribute. Defenses and your attentiveness get tested as each lane fights to divert your attention across the map. The new, proper bosses feel a lot more interesting than all of the bosses from the first game, too. They have mechanics that make them more than a "bullet sponge", and it was an excellent move making them a bit of an outside force that interacts with the map and the waves in interesting ways, instead of just being placed awkwardly and requiring that you blindly hit it with regular attacks and awkwardly placed towers.The aesthetics of the game are sweet. Everything is much nicer to look at.I think my biggest complaint is that I just wish the game was harder. Not in a "just make the numbers bigger" way, but that the maps were actually more interesting to play. It feels like the entire campaign is a tutorial to get you acclimated to the games mechanics. The maps never seem to get nearly as complex or interesting as they were in the first game....The revisited maps in 'the harbinger awakens' content update come closer and are definitely more fun than the maps that came before it, which gives me hope for the future. You really can't go wrong with "free" though, and I can see myself losing a few more evenings as I continue to play this with my fiancÃ©e. But ultimately, I don't think either of us will be sinking dozens or even hundreds of hours into it like we did the first time around.

content:
Posted: October 19, 2015
Early Access Review
								If you like RPG's and tower defence games, this is the game for you. Choose between an apprentice, huntress, monk or squire to defend Etheria from the Old ones. They're trying to take the magical crystal back with waves and waves of orcs, goblins and all manner of crazy beasts. Level up and fully custimize your hero with stat points, spehres, pets and gear to deal with the baddies in the way you see fit. Work on your hero themselves or your defences. Each hero has there own set of defences such as walls and towers and traps to ''defend'' the chosen objective. Each mission is very colorful and completed with difficulties for your team to overcome. A great co -op and friends game , becuase you all need to work together, hero and defence wise to protect the objective and well, from experiece if you don't....you fail. You spend equal time defending, as setting up defences to gearing up and looking through loot. It's also not a play to win, they only negative is a long loading time or game crashes but i'm sure Itll be fixed and renderd ASAP...

content:
Posted: October 20, 2015
Early Access Review
								First of all, DD2 feels like a complete reboot of DD1.Graphics and animations aside, the few changes that felt refreshing to me were the substats you get from loot and the spheres, especially uber spheres. The substats (e.g. hearty blockade) are way more important than just the stats you add from leveling whereas the spheres gives you a diverse option to build your towers. Oh, and you can no longer add defense attack speed with equips, so that makes it different from DD1.Similar to DD1, this game is all about the loot. Pretty self-explanatory, you progress from getting better loot and to get better loot, you gotta keep replaying maps. Essentially making the game feel "grindy". Just a disclaimer, loot isn't the most important aspect of this game, there're still ways to beat levels such as strategising tower placement and countering magic/physical resistance. I feel that loot is what drives the game, it is the 'core' of Dungeon Defenders.Which brings me to...What I don't like about DD2 right now 19/10/2015:- THERE IS LIMITED BAG SPACE!!!!!!! You get pretty good loot that you wanna keep (that takes up space). You gotta wait 48 hours for an egg to rot and become a material required for evolving your pet (that takes up space). You get pet food for your pet (that takes up space). You get some other material required for evolving pet (that takes up space). It's disheartening that you have to either sacrifice loot for progressing your eqp/pet, or sacrifice progress for loot. Moreover, certain maps gives you a lot of loot, so you gotta sell items in between waves (playing with people, everyone is in a hurry to 'g' up).- So gems are no longer just solely for cosmetics. Since more bag space also requires gems, would this make it P2W?- Server lags. This game just became free to play recently, so no doubt this would happen. However, playing this game every now and then, I find myself off the side of the cliff. You decide if you wanna put up with that (personally I'd give it time).Other than the few main points above that I have problems with, the game is still in Alpha with lots more potential. Can't wait to see it in completion.The game is free to play, so what are you waiting for? Try it.

content:
Posted: August 28, 2016
Early Access Review
Looking for a free to play, non pay to win game? This one is the game.May contain mild spoilers.Dungeon Defenders 2 is by far one of the best free to play MMO's I have ever played. Sure there are in-game purchases, but you don't need to purchase anything to progress through the game, everyone levels up equally, there is NO Gameplay Advantage to those who buy in-game items.About the gameA general summery of the game.Dungeon defenders 2 is just like any other tower defense game, except you can play with your friends, and have a free roaming expirence. Protect your lands against orcs, or else you will end up in defeat! There are 4 characters to choose from at the start, the apprentice, huntress, squire, and the monk. Play with up to 4 friends in an in-game co-op party, and have fun leveling up at your own pace. Gain more ipwr by defeating the orcs, and picking up gear that you can equip at your level. Gain money, to buy power ups, that make your hero, or defenses stronger.Cons?Nope, not many at all.This is one in many free to play games that has very little cons to it. I'd have to say the only downfall to this game, is having to pay for costumes for your characters, and there is no other way to unlock them yourself.TL;DR?Too long; didn't read?In short, Dungeon Defenders 2 is one of my most highly recommended free mmo games out there right now. There is tons of gameplay, and the game is still in development with more maps and upgrades. You can play with your friends, and have fun leveling up at any pace you'd like. Levels get harder as you progress, making it funner to level up.Definitely do try out this game. What is there to lose? It's free-to-play!Like my reviews?To see more of my reviews on games, you can view more HERE!(http://steamcommunity.com/id/redsauce117/recommended/)

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 25, 2016
Early Access Review
								It's a good, somewhat completed game, that's fun in LAN. :) It's free to play, and there's no real "pay-to-win" need, either. I love how you can collect items throughout, reminding me of Borderlands and Diablo. None of those wussy items like in Secret World and Age of Conan, either. ;) Tons of small gimmicks, like pets and skills. Later in the game you can change some of the effects on the other towers. A few downsides, though: it's buggy (it's alpha, so no surprise there). You'll be thrown out of the game and have to rejoin the match at times (fortunately you don't have to wait for the match to finish before you can rejoin), sometimes the weapon-animations suddenly stop showing, or trying to carry more than 1 gold/crystal during the Kobolt Challenge will simply delete the other, sometimes you just can't connect with a friend and both gotta restart the game... I do wish there'd be a few more towers to chose between for each character, though, but at least you can change character ingame as often  as you wish, and use several types. Yeah, there are downsides. It's a free alpha though, so can't complain and let it prevent me from giving a recommendation, because we (four of us) had a lot of fun. Some even bought the hideously expensive Hero/Costume packs - not worth it in my opinion. My tip? Download it, play it for free, enjoy it a lot (or not, and no money lost). If you like it enough that you'll buy pretty-coloured things for lots of real money, well - all power to you, I suppose. Enjoy!

content:
Posted: June 25, 2016
Early Access Review
								I see a lot of reviews from people who are upset about the grind to get new characters - Devs realized it was a bit too hard to grind for the medals, so they increased the amount you receive from missions, maps, etc... I am now capped on medals after just a few days of playing. There has been a ton of content released for this game in the last few months, including new maps, incursions, weapons, and even two new characters. The community has a say in how this game is progressing, which is more than I can say for a lot of other games. I can also look at news for this game and weekly (if not every few days) there is detailed** updates on where the devs are in updates, and even a look at what is to come, whether it be a thought, or a work in progress. Overall, I've been playing this game since release, and I still play it almost every day. If you enjoy tower defense, you should not pass up the opportunity to at least try the game out.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game has for the most part been garbage, and a real disgrace to DD1.Most maps seem to be made with appearance in mind (and they do look pretty good) rather then gameplay, as good tower placement is all but forgotten in the map designs (which is of critical importance to a tower defense game).Combat itself is fairly clunky, leaving you with a lackluster experience as you run about hacking at waves of mobs.Tuning is evidentaly very poor, in most cases leaving you with either extreme ease or impossible difficulty. Difficulty, in this case, a result of being undergeared/leveled.Despite not yet even being released, updates have been centered around monitization schemes. The free to play is a bait-and-switch designed to lure you in to show you pretty maps, and then ask you for money.Trendy has gone down the drain hard. Where DD1 was a fun and unique game that got great support and a thriving community. DD2 has been a half-baked game and a terrible money grab.

content:
Posted: October 28, 2015
Early Access Review
								The game is amazing, because it has the same concepts as DD1, but does feel like a different game. Just as enjoyable as the first game. I realize this game is in Alpha stage (even though it feels like it's been forever, and DD1 took forever to come out fully). I'll give a positive review, because it's a great game, but there's one problem...The jump button barely works if you're using an XBox controller. I loved DD1, and played it with a controller, and loved it. Now, when I'm in the middle of a battle, trying to do what needs to be done, I can't even get around my towers because the jump button is so bugged out! I even end up dying sometimes because I fall in a pit, because the jump button doesn't register.I think the problem might be because the "A" button does other things, so I've tried to remap the jump button to something else... But the remapping aspect of the controller menu doesn't work!The game is absolutely amazing, and IF they fix this problem, I will totally love it, and probably play it just as much as I did DD1 (250 hours). However, if they don't fix this, I'll probably give up after a while because it's just so infuriating.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2016
Early Access Review
								In short, Dungeon Defenders II would have been a good game, had DD1 not existed.The game is quite close to a neutral level to me, however I still can't recommend it much. That said, if there was an indifferrent option, I would select tht instead. Dungeon Defenders 2 is a decent game in its own right, although certain controls can be more complicated and somewhat difficult to remember. For some gamers, myself included, controller support is a must-have, however DD2 lacks this and uses a keyboard and mouse only. Unlike DD1, it's a generally more complicated game, in that the maps are slightly more complicated and use more paths to make things harder. That said, the game is generally easier if you've played DD1 or DDE.As a rating, I give DD2 a 4/10, because it isn't a bad game, but it dismisses some redeeming factors and negates their usage, such as the forementioned controller. The game is still early access, and as such, I would call it one to watch, and with any such improvement, my review may change to recommendation.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 7, 2016
Early Access Review
								TL;DR, modern tower defense with a hero element.  can build freely anywhere and everywhere in most cases.  MMO-ish looting and rarity hierarchy ex: white, green, blue, purple, orange flavor text.  all heroes in a deck level up regardless of them being active so long as they are in your deck.  all content can be obtained without spending a penny even heroes and hero slots. premium options are conveniences or skins ex: inventory expander or unlocking heroes.  you cannot purchase spheres or special things with premium currency.dungeon defenders 2 being the sequel to dungeon defenders continues the tale of the four youngsters who are now all grown up.  Etheria is in a golden age after the defeat of the old ones and eveythings hunky dory for a wile.  however, someone's running amok releasing those old ones once again and the original 4 are enlisted to fight once more.  taking place in the kingdom of dragonfall you work with the locals to ship out the eternia crystals to hopefully fix whoever's making a mess of things.the old ones have adapted and enlisted some new and old units alike to aid their advances to destroy the shards.  you'll face off against most of what you known from the first game, goblins, orcs, mages, even ogres return.  the goblins got a new ranged unit that throws bombs, the mage has been adapted to resurrect the dead, and the ogres are more geared to the teeth to do some serious damage.  the archer and dark elf assassin units have been retired, the archer has been replaced by a javelin thrower capable of piercing through defenses and enlisted the drakins as a bombardment of magical flame to shoot at things from a distance.but that's not all, they enrolled many new units to help their conquest such as the witherbeast, a supportive tanky unit that burrows itself into the ground and emits a healing field for enemies and debuffing nearby defenses to take more damage while also receiving less damage from them.  the kobolds have taken to the skies and have learned the art of paragliding, and will dive-bomb into their targets.  a new air unit has also been discovered, a lightning bug, capable of dealing chained damage to defenses.many more dangerous enemies await but what of the heroes, have their friends made a comeback? well, sort of.  EV comes back with her second edition and the summoner now retitled to 'abyss lord' also make a return.  they handle and function very differently than their previous incarnations so expect different game play.  some new faces also join in on the fight as well such as the lavamancer, a living molten rock of a man along with the mystic, who has a huge fixation to appeasing the snake gods, and, as of just recently, the dryad from terraria has also came on in to help.  the game has also been streamlined to reduce the whackyness and longevity needed to complete a map, guesstimated to 1/5th the insanity that was dungeon defender 1.  the game will adjust each lane after each wave to be more difficult.  it will spawn special enemies, such as ogres, less often and more predictably, but as a result, they are much more vicious.  you are also rewarded a chest at the end that will guarantee one item's loot quality depending on its color.  gold replaces mana in terms of spending money for functions such as upgrading.  defender medals, obtained through daily/bonus weekly missions and map completion, are used for specific things such as skill spheres and unique items.overall i think it's a solid game for it being free, although a year or so ago there was a buy in price but now that has been lifted and a lot of content adjusted for a free to play model i think it's heading in the right direction.  they got some kinks and cracks to undo and seal up as it is but they are introducing some nice new player friendly features such as an ability to try the dryad in a 'normalized' mode.  on top of the campaign giving a generous heaping amount of defender medals to be comparable to a new hero with about 1~2k missing.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 24, 2016
Early Access Review
								First off, this game is absolutely different from Dungeon Defenders 1. This isn't to say that it's a bad game, just don't go into it thinking you can pull the same stunts as the last game. You are not going to be afk farming in this game. You will be out on the battlefield holding down the fort and defending with all of you character abilities. Every original character feels really balanced and has a few roles they can fill. Gear hunting is great because there's actual game-changing abilities on the gear that can dictate how you are going to be playing the character. There's more game modes and difficulty options that can keep you entertained and on your toes. Also, they Devs really put an emphasis on "use more than one character or else you will fail". Like I said, you won't be sitting here building with a mage and afking wave after wave. In this game, it just isn't good enough. You need to find your combos and create/build characters that synergize. Have one character throwing oil while your mage is igniting them with his flame towers and stuff like that. It's a good twist. Not to mention there's no more stupid helicopters flying in and dropping ogres from random places on the map, or spiders that drop down from the sky out of nowhere to sabotage your builds. All in all, this is a solid game and I can definitely say it's a step in the right direction. Worth playing, hands down. My only real complaint is the strength of the DLC characters. The summoner and EV2 just don't belong in this game at the power they're currently at. The summoner is a step above all of the original 4 in terms of straight dps output. It takes a lot for others to compete with his tower strength and utility. However, EV2 is just absurd. Without gear and using one ability, EV2 can solo campaign mode on normal at lvl 13. Then she can solo nightmare 3 at lvl 30. At level 50 with around 300 gear score, EV2 is easily putting out about 300k dps. A hunter with straight hero dmg and ability power is only pumping out around 50k, but it requires double the gear score. That being said, EV2 is reaching levels of damage that SHOULD NOT be attainable in this game! SHE NEEDS AN IMMEDIATE NERF. Proton beams allow her to sit on the crystal and shoot halfway across the map and clear lanes with ease. Levels that should be challenging are just turned into minor inconveniences with her on your squad. She takes the fun out of the game because people who play her just don't have to actually PLAY the game. They don't need to find/build the synergy between their heroes, they don't need to farm gear and hunt for specific abilities. They don't need to balance stats or even move. They are able to push into the endgame with ease, and it's disgusting. By making these DLC characters as strong as they are, the Devs are just straight disrespecting the game they made. Playing a monk (whose towers are completely underwelming and weak) to playing EV2 or the summoner is just disgusting. Personally, I'm waiting for the barbarian to come back (shouldn't have even taking this long, in my opinion). However, if he's even half as  broken as EV2 while the other original 4 stay at the same terrible weakness they're at, then this game is going into the recycle bin.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2015
Early Access Review
								Hard to review this one, as a fan of the original. Where to begin? Well...let's start off with what I don't like.The game is quite a bit easier. The maps are visually more interesting to look at and have more full 3D depth to them, which makes them interesting to run around in at times. But each lane is identified for you immediately, and the maps are designed in such a way that you can't have an "aha!" moment as you discover a way to place a single tower to cover multiple choke-points. Either the developer placed the chokepoint for you and pointed you right to it, or the chokepoint doesn't exist. This can help to eliminate the feeling of "trial and error" gameplay that existed in the first game, but it also means you can never feel like you're outsmarting the developer when you find a good way to place your towers.In some ways, this doesn't necessarily change the final feeling of the game, as in the first one, once you figured it out, you always placed towers in the best spots. I suppose this makes it easier to play the game in public groups or with friends that don't really play video games the same way you do, but it makes all of the maps feel a little samey after awhile, because you never get to experience that first moment of wonder as you treat the map like a puzzle to be solved.The pricing of the cosmetic items is...quite high. I find myself learning to enjoy the default skins, since purchasing the outfits i'd like would quickly put this game at a higher price than an off the shelf, AAA title. I don't have a problem with the microtransactions themselves, I think it'd just be nicer if they were a little more "micro" so I could get a few skins and not feel like i'm getting robbed.Now on to what's been improved!The new hero-deck system will (eventually) prevent a single player from effectively filling every role. Playing with friends in the first game could be quite difficult at times, because you were capable of leveling up and gearing out the entire cast, and placing every tower type. Your friends could quickly outgrow you, and if you didn't play a ranger or barbarian, there was little reason for you to be in the game with such a person, since their towers would be better than what you could make. Being limited to a certain number of heroes encourages you to work together - once there are more hero types than there are deck slots, you'll need at least two players to do everything. It's forced co-op sure, but at least you can always be useful to your friends, since you can bring something that they cannot.The way they introduce new unit types as mini-bosses feels good. Later maps and harder difficulties can repeatedly spawn mini-boss versions of these enemies too. Since there are a lot of things that can define an enemy (such as movement speed, walking or flying, special attacks, resistances), they keep your defenses in check and ensure that everyone has something to contribute. Defenses and your attentiveness get tested as each lane fights to divert your attention across the map. The new, proper bosses feel a lot more interesting than all of the bosses from the first game, too. They have mechanics that make them more than a "bullet sponge", and it was an excellent move making them a bit of an outside force that interacts with the map and the waves in interesting ways, instead of just being placed awkwardly and requiring that you blindly hit it with regular attacks and awkwardly placed towers.The aesthetics of the game are sweet. Everything is much nicer to look at.I think my biggest complaint is that I just wish the game was harder. Not in a "just make the numbers bigger" way, but that the maps were actually more interesting to play. It feels like the entire campaign is a tutorial to get you acclimated to the games mechanics. The maps never seem to get nearly as complex or interesting as they were in the first game....The revisited maps in 'the harbinger awakens' content update come closer and are definitely more fun than the maps that came before it, which gives me hope for the future. You really can't go wrong with "free" though, and I can see myself losing a few more evenings as I continue to play this with my fiancÃ©e. But ultimately, I don't think either of us will be sinking dozens or even hundreds of hours into it like we did the first time around.

content:
Posted: October 28, 2015
Early Access Review
								The game is amazing, because it has the same concepts as DD1, but does feel like a different game. Just as enjoyable as the first game. I realize this game is in Alpha stage (even though it feels like it's been forever, and DD1 took forever to come out fully). I'll give a positive review, because it's a great game, but there's one problem...The jump button barely works if you're using an XBox controller. I loved DD1, and played it with a controller, and loved it. Now, when I'm in the middle of a battle, trying to do what needs to be done, I can't even get around my towers because the jump button is so bugged out! I even end up dying sometimes because I fall in a pit, because the jump button doesn't register.I think the problem might be because the "A" button does other things, so I've tried to remap the jump button to something else... But the remapping aspect of the controller menu doesn't work!The game is absolutely amazing, and IF they fix this problem, I will totally love it, and probably play it just as much as I did DD1 (250 hours). However, if they don't fix this, I'll probably give up after a while because it's just so infuriating.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 10, 2016
Early Access Review
								Pros:- Mixes RPG and Tower Defense together which diversifies and gives the game a unique playstyle.- Unlock 4 classes for free.- 2 playstyles which you can build each class the way you want. (i.e. building or fighting which the game will explain).- You can switch classes based on how they are built. (i.e. At the end of a wave switch to a class that you have specialized to be a builder, then switch to a class you've built to be a fighter after you're done building.- The stat points and the equipment also support the way you want to specialize your classe in.- Simultaneously gain experience and levels for all the other heroes when only using one, this helps for grinding.- Afraid that you're alone or it's too difficult? Worry not, you can play multiplayer or go off to be a lone wolf.- Has an auto collect system where it does the equipment collecting for you.- You get 4 bags which hold equipment.- Dying doesn't punish besides respawn timer.- Challenging for those who want it.- You can play with friends.Cons:- VERY grindy- Requires you to use your brain as does every TD game- Not very F2P as grinding and playing a lot will only be the way to advance- Time consuming- Only 4 main classes are available as free, (Squire, Monk, Huntress, and Apprentice) the others you must grind a lot for or buy with gems.- A LOT of things require gems such as costumes or skins for your characters and getting pets.- NO guilds or clubs for people looking to socialize and work with others.- Gets quite boring after grinding for many hours.TLDR; Don't play if you don't have a lot of free time and don't expect the game to be full F2P as it requires gems for a lot of things, otherwise the game is unique, thrilling, and challenging.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 24, 2016
Early Access Review
								First off, this game is absolutely different from Dungeon Defenders 1. This isn't to say that it's a bad game, just don't go into it thinking you can pull the same stunts as the last game. You are not going to be afk farming in this game. You will be out on the battlefield holding down the fort and defending with all of you character abilities. Every original character feels really balanced and has a few roles they can fill. Gear hunting is great because there's actual game-changing abilities on the gear that can dictate how you are going to be playing the character. There's more game modes and difficulty options that can keep you entertained and on your toes. Also, they Devs really put an emphasis on "use more than one character or else you will fail". Like I said, you won't be sitting here building with a mage and afking wave after wave. In this game, it just isn't good enough. You need to find your combos and create/build characters that synergize. Have one character throwing oil while your mage is igniting them with his flame towers and stuff like that. It's a good twist. Not to mention there's no more stupid helicopters flying in and dropping ogres from random places on the map, or spiders that drop down from the sky out of nowhere to sabotage your builds. All in all, this is a solid game and I can definitely say it's a step in the right direction. Worth playing, hands down. My only real complaint is the strength of the DLC characters. The summoner and EV2 just don't belong in this game at the power they're currently at. The summoner is a step above all of the original 4 in terms of straight dps output. It takes a lot for others to compete with his tower strength and utility. However, EV2 is just absurd. Without gear and using one ability, EV2 can solo campaign mode on normal at lvl 13. Then she can solo nightmare 3 at lvl 30. At level 50 with around 300 gear score, EV2 is easily putting out about 300k dps. A hunter with straight hero dmg and ability power is only pumping out around 50k, but it requires double the gear score. That being said, EV2 is reaching levels of damage that SHOULD NOT be attainable in this game! SHE NEEDS AN IMMEDIATE NERF. Proton beams allow her to sit on the crystal and shoot halfway across the map and clear lanes with ease. Levels that should be challenging are just turned into minor inconveniences with her on your squad. She takes the fun out of the game because people who play her just don't have to actually PLAY the game. They don't need to find/build the synergy between their heroes, they don't need to farm gear and hunt for specific abilities. They don't need to balance stats or even move. They are able to push into the endgame with ease, and it's disgusting. By making these DLC characters as strong as they are, the Devs are just straight disrespecting the game they made. Playing a monk (whose towers are completely underwelming and weak) to playing EV2 or the summoner is just disgusting. Personally, I'm waiting for the barbarian to come back (shouldn't have even taking this long, in my opinion). However, if he's even half as  broken as EV2 while the other original 4 stay at the same terrible weakness they're at, then this game is going into the recycle bin.

Even when I'm alone, in a private session, the game is laggy and unplayable.If you have a good, reliable internet connection and enjoy tower defense games, then give it a try. If your internet sucks, it's not worth the hassle.

content:
Posted: July 12, 2016
Early Access Review
								TLDR at bottom: Do you like Tower Defense? Do you like multiple difficulty and balanced gameplay for all heroes? well you won't find that here! At first its great fun playing with a friend, the amount of diversity of gear and item sphere's to modify all aspects of your characters, the real feel of "oh i don't have to pay anything and can be just as good as anyone else" until you get to the end game. Level 50, new patch comes out "Power Up Update" promises to balance old heroes to stand up with the newer "Paid" heroes, promise gleemingly seems true as all heroes became stronger than ever to a point that you could throw your towers out the window and purely focus on hero defense. But i hear you saying why the negative review? Surely this is an amazing game that you can blow countless hours at and feel constant rewards and satisfaction, well yes it is at first. After 3 days of this Power Up Update the nerf bats came in strong, nerfing new content that made the original 4 characters viable in Nightmare IV Difficulty, You would still get one shot and had to have the best gear available to stand a chance but now without your dps you then have to rely on your towers. So the issue here is even with full ipw 700 gear for the squire and the 125k gold sphere's for the monk to increase blockade hp to its absolute maximum you get to around 580k hp, seems like a lot yeah? well the Orc Blockades From the Abyss Lord in similar gear have 1.5 million hp and deal almost 4x the damage. Then onto dps, my monk was doing 700k dps single target similar to the new "Gun Witch" in similar gear another Paid hero,, now you can technically "unlock" these characters in game via doing a daily for 200 coins per day, and around 20 per nightmare dungeon, so thats 2 solid months to unlock a new hero that starts at level 1 or pay $20 to get it today and another $40 to get a full kit of legendary gear and level 50, The problem here is normal heroes in the best Nightmare IV ipwr 700 dps gear all do around 60-70k dps with the squire doing around 30k whilst all of the paid heroes do 10x the damage and have 3x to health. Nightmare IV is by design isn't meant to be doable with the original 4 characters regardless of gear or skill level.TLDR: Decisively Pay to win, Given hero buffs and take them away after 3 days due to no testing, server unstable crashing 4x a night 3 nights in a row when releasing the new patch, unable to download new patch, no support, no response from tickets/bug reports in game or email, all backers got shafted.The one kick in the face that you get for gaining max level 50? 200 "paid" gems that aren't enough to purchase ANYTHING WITH!? This feels more like ransomware than a game at this point.

content:
Posted: July 14, 2016
Early Access Review
								As many here I loved Dungeon Defenders: the loot grind, tower defense, character builds, and the general carefree game play of it was loads of fun. So naturally I was super happy when I saw Dungeon Defenders 2 was being developed, and waited patiently for its early access. For the first few months things were great, it lacked content but it felt like Dungeon Defenders and things were looking good. Up until a few updates ago the game started to take a sharp turn for worse. Poison turret hunter got deleted I think and overpriced and unbalanced heroes made the game seem cheap. It seems like the games more after your wallet than it is after your time. I get that developing a game takes stacks of cash, but if people feel like their getting ripped for their micro transactions they'd just rather not play at all. All said I do really wish the developers would focus on making their game fun alongside good advertisement to fund the game instead of inflating their content prices. I truly do believe it would benefit everyone.

content:
Posted: July 23, 2016
Early Access Review
								Free to play in every sense of the word. Pets need to be fed with a special item, which you can buy with money, or with in game moey (at fastly increased prices) but DOES drops... sometimes. New characters need to be bought, anything beyond the first 4 at least.Chests drop that you need to buy keys for (this is by far the most aggregious of the examples IMO)If you had just made this game pay to play, as Dungeon Defenders 1 was, this game would have been at the top of my list in fun games to play. It's a shame, too, they made a lot of improvements to the game over DD1. (They stil have player collision with other players though, such an oversight in a multiplayer coop game.) A shame indeed.Do not play this game. It will waste your time, as you need to spend more money than the game is actually worth to get any enjoyment out of it.
