content:
Posted: July 25, 2016
Early Access Review
								So many things went wrong in execution. It took many great features from the first game and then split them into a microtransaction format. Not necessarily a horrible thing, except they made it unusually expensive to have; almost like someone thought people will pay the ridiculous prices solely from loving the first game.Of the things it kept in, they expanded in poor ways. The larger environments don't have anything to keep them going. One thing about the first game was how tight and well designed its levels were, but that's gone now. It's like the microtransaction model was made to rely on past players, but the design doesn't attract them.

content:
Posted: October 24, 2015
Early Access Review
 Deep review This is a towerdefense game of a 3rd person view. I would say this game can be comapred to diablo series. Because of the loot system and the grinding involved into it. So lets start of picking your 4 heroes, each hero has its own kit/style. Mage The mage has a  LOT  of aoe spells and places turrets that also deal aoe dmg. Hes ranged and builds turrets pretty well (The mage has a freeze turret that helps pretty well in defense also because his normal turrets deal aoe dmg he can easy deal a lot more dmg). The weapon he uses i a staff.  Fighter The fighter is a mele class hero and uses of course a sword. He can build small walls better than others (they deal dmg when someone tries to destroy them).  Hunter The hunter places traps that can CC (Crow Control: Stuns, Slows, Silence etc). Also some just deal dmg. She places turrets that can poision the target for a small amout of time. She is ranged and uses a bow. Monk I like to call him lee sin  Because in league of legends lee sin is a blind monk  . Hes weapon is a staff but different from the mages cuz he is mele. He can create totems that will heal you or buff your turrets. Gameplay As i said this is a towerdefense game with where you can roam freely building your towers and walls to not let the enemies get pass you and break the core. You have crystals (green crystals is like your building material and blue is more like your mana to let you use spells). There is a limit on how much building you can build in the field so if a person uses all that liming to build only in one lane and dosent want to destroy it youre screwd.The  loot  system is almost the same as diablo (if not the same). A big amount of grinding is nessecay for leveling up and getting the best loot. Most of the loot you get are usefull at start but at the end game lvl 38 for example, 95% of the loot you get will be useless and is just junk that you sell. Even if you get a legendary it might be useless, someway because of the level cuz youre grinding on low levels and somethimes just of its stats.So lets talk about  XP . At the start its easy to level up as you proceed the campain but after youre done it will get easier. To unlock the insane difficulty and nightmare, nightmare 2 and so on. You have to complete the called quests, but the quest are no more than just lvl up to 50 so when youre lvl for example 38, you have to replay ALOT of the same level to get the most xp out of it and do it agan and again and again till you reach lvl 50 and unlock the insane difficulty to get better loot. Here is where i think is a big gap and alot of people thinking of quiting when they reach this certain point. You can see that the developmers has helped a bit and added daily exp to the first finishing missions. But on the other hand there is still something missing. That gap from lvl (exmpl) 38 to lvl 50 takes a lot of time of replayability so i think that the devolopers can add something into that like for exaple letting them acces the unlimited modes at a lower level than at 40 and still keeping the insane difficulty there. I think that would at least do something (if not fix it). Co-Op  is in this game and i highly recommend playing this game with a friend. You can still solo it and do well. But plaing multiplayer is easier because heroes in this game has a great synergy with each others for example lee sin (Monk class) can create totems that gives your turret a lot of power and a significantly increase in dmg. Free2Pay As the develpers are saying its NOT a pay2win game. Right now you can only use special money on cosmetics and chests that you find as loot. The chest CAN have very good loot but often dosent and just gives you a small boost on your items (Other words: you get better loot but not too far away from what you had). I hope this systems will stay as the realise comes. Development The game patches is pretty common and i mean it. There was a patch yesterday and a patch today. Those patches arent that big BUT add small features that the community requested. For example the sort panel on bags that wasent before todays patch. You can see (or read) with your own eyes that the developers react to their community and helps. Final verdict I dont mind grinding and farming for loot like in diablo with a small gap between the hero lvl. Graphics are ok for a free to play game and port is well optimised. This game is specialy good to play with friends but you can still solo it. The developers are nice and  hear  the community.I give this game a  8/10

content:
Posted: July 12, 2016
Early Access Review
								TLDR at bottom: Do you like Tower Defense? Do you like multiple difficulty and balanced gameplay for all heroes? well you won't find that here! At first its great fun playing with a friend, the amount of diversity of gear and item sphere's to modify all aspects of your characters, the real feel of "oh i don't have to pay anything and can be just as good as anyone else" until you get to the end game. Level 50, new patch comes out "Power Up Update" promises to balance old heroes to stand up with the newer "Paid" heroes, promise gleemingly seems true as all heroes became stronger than ever to a point that you could throw your towers out the window and purely focus on hero defense. But i hear you saying why the negative review? Surely this is an amazing game that you can blow countless hours at and feel constant rewards and satisfaction, well yes it is at first. After 3 days of this Power Up Update the nerf bats came in strong, nerfing new content that made the original 4 characters viable in Nightmare IV Difficulty, You would still get one shot and had to have the best gear available to stand a chance but now without your dps you then have to rely on your towers. So the issue here is even with full ipw 700 gear for the squire and the 125k gold sphere's for the monk to increase blockade hp to its absolute maximum you get to around 580k hp, seems like a lot yeah? well the Orc Blockades From the Abyss Lord in similar gear have 1.5 million hp and deal almost 4x the damage. Then onto dps, my monk was doing 700k dps single target similar to the new "Gun Witch" in similar gear another Paid hero,, now you can technically "unlock" these characters in game via doing a daily for 200 coins per day, and around 20 per nightmare dungeon, so thats 2 solid months to unlock a new hero that starts at level 1 or pay $20 to get it today and another $40 to get a full kit of legendary gear and level 50, The problem here is normal heroes in the best Nightmare IV ipwr 700 dps gear all do around 60-70k dps with the squire doing around 30k whilst all of the paid heroes do 10x the damage and have 3x to health. Nightmare IV is by design isn't meant to be doable with the original 4 characters regardless of gear or skill level.TLDR: Decisively Pay to win, Given hero buffs and take them away after 3 days due to no testing, server unstable crashing 4x a night 3 nights in a row when releasing the new patch, unable to download new patch, no support, no response from tickets/bug reports in game or email, all backers got shafted.The one kick in the face that you get for gaining max level 50? 200 "paid" gems that aren't enough to purchase ANYTHING WITH!? This feels more like ransomware than a game at this point.

number of helpful: 5 of 10 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								I played 800+ hours at DD1 and as Trendy totally gave up on it (no bug fixes, no new maps), I was super excited to hear there was a DD2. But after being release (in early access, which is still the case now) the reviews were pretty mixed, especially from the ones that players DD1. So I waited a few months hoping the game will use the same magic recipe as DD1 and will be an improvement.As the game was on sale, I decided to get it and give it a try hoping I will have a tremendous number of hours coming on. Unfortunately after 20 hours on it I was pretty disappointed and don't understand why Trendy made so many bad changes:PRO:- better graphics- details on monsters for the incoming wave- can see your defenses range by holding the Shift key.and to be honest that's pretty much it.CONS:- right after getting the game I wasn't able to join any public game, the servers weren't working properly. Seems to have gone better but it seems like that's a recurring issue. Even joining the public tavern sometimes doesn't work.- 4 heroes with 4 towers, compared to 8 x 5. They might add some more later on but right now we are missing a lot on diversity.- the stats system has totally changed and is so confusing: gear rating/comparison doesn't seem right, can't boost particular stats anymore (you've to find objects with stats you want), we've lost the range stats (no more high-range harpons).- this game will become a free to play (Yeah!) but some upgrades will require real money (Boooo!)- most of the shortcuts have changed from DD1- DD1 was having a listing of all games and it was easy to join the party you felt will be fun to play (map/mode/difficulty). Now you just join a public tavern and have to select a map+difficulty and you might join a starting game or it will create a new game (and if you quit/cancel right away you are loosing social points, wth!?)So far I haven't had any fun playing DD2, I might try to continue leveling up (I've 3 heroes lvl 20) to see if it gets better and unlock some other maps but I'm seriously considering going back to DD1...

content:
Posted: December 31, 2016
Early Access Review
								In short, Dungeon Defenders II would have been a good game, had DD1 not existed.The game is quite close to a neutral level to me, however I still can't recommend it much. That said, if there was an indifferrent option, I would select tht instead. Dungeon Defenders 2 is a decent game in its own right, although certain controls can be more complicated and somewhat difficult to remember. For some gamers, myself included, controller support is a must-have, however DD2 lacks this and uses a keyboard and mouse only. Unlike DD1, it's a generally more complicated game, in that the maps are slightly more complicated and use more paths to make things harder. That said, the game is generally easier if you've played DD1 or DDE.As a rating, I give DD2 a 4/10, because it isn't a bad game, but it dismisses some redeeming factors and negates their usage, such as the forementioned controller. The game is still early access, and as such, I would call it one to watch, and with any such improvement, my review may change to recommendation.

								Dun Def 2 is still in alpha but right now It's pretty neat. The event stuff for halloween was fun. We have our four base classes back like the Squire, Huntress, Apprentice, and the Monk. They all play similarly to the original game. I just wish the game had mmore boss fight throughout the campaign. Like in the original game there would be a nice big boss every so few levels. Now there is only a final boss at the last level and the campaign simply introduces new enemy types as if they were bosses when they will be regular mobs later on and in the harder difficulty/modes.Its still got a ways to go. I also know people are eager to see what classes will be added, as well as more maps for modes like Incursion and Onslaught.Still pretty nice for an Alpha at the moment.

content:
Posted: February 9, 2016
Early Access Review
								    I have played this line of games since Trendy first started the dungeon defenders series and will continue to as long as they make them. It is a very interesting game to me because i like the challenge and the grind factor that seems to be endless. I like the progression level of the game as well wiht the exception of the massive increase between nm3 and nm4. Now that said there a few things that need to be addressed with the game like the supposed fixes that cause more problems than they fix and the push to rush new content that is incomplete or broken. i am sure that most would rather have quality over quantity. This problems seems to derive from the fact they want to sell something new to you to keep the money rolling which is understandable but its not worth it to pay for something that doesnt work since they keep coming up with new things to sell you without fixing what they have already sold. It is a great game and i hope that they keep producing but would like to see more solid fixes and updates as well as better balancing.

It's beautiful and loads of fun.The ratings for the game reflected that, too, until March 24th when Trendy decided to sue an ex-employee who had violated his contract.  And then people started to rate the game badly.  Seriously, go look at the ratings prior to the 24th and then the avalanche of ratings on the 24th that announced how horrible that is.  BTW, nothing significant changed about the game on the 24th.So we have a bunch of liars, basically, who are willing to claim that this fine game sucks because they don't like what the company is doing elsewhere.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 4, 2016
Early Access Review
								Graphics:- Nice comic-style with a lot of bright colors, resulting in a very "warm/lovely" atmosphere- A lot of variation in maps for example old dungeons, green fields, gigantic sewers, burning cities, spooky forests or a throne room and there is much more! New maps are constantly added, each with their own layout and theming.- The characters are designed with a lot of love for details and they all look very different from each other. You can also buy skins with ingame currency to give you a bit more variation.-> Overall one of the biggest pros for me are the graphics. I could stare hours into the beautiful landscapes and also write hours about it ;)Balance/Bugs/Ingame Currency-> Trendy constantly adds new content to the game, so they can have all features they want as quickly as possible, but this also results in a lot of bugs. The worst bugs get fixed quickly. The balance issues are not that bad in early stages of the game, but in the endgame there are only a few viable towers/characters. IÂ´m sure the balance will get fixed, since most of the old characters will get reworked soon to be as good as the new ones. The ingame currency is fine. You can get some skins and additional inventory slots with it, but nothing that would give you an advantage in the game.Gameplay:- A lot of variation in maps, difficulties, items and characters. You can even equip spheres to boost your character to the max. or take a pet to help you in battle- Tons of enemies, each with their own strengths and some with special abilitiess- The normal gamemode is nice and balanced and will take you a good amount of time to reach the last difficulties.- The second gamemode is named "onslaught" and is basically an endless mode. The gamemode is fun but does not provide good rewards at the end. IÂ´m sure they will make some work on this gamemode soon.- The third and last gamemode is named "incursion" and is a much harder version of the map you choose. The gamemode is very challenging and is okey so far. But they currently work on adding a different task for each map and a unique reward if you win. There is already one map with this concept and iÂ´m very happy with it.- Daily missions/monthly missions have good rewards and are well done.- Characters all have their own playstyle and look.I could write on for hours, because there is so much more to talk about, but i wanted to keep it short and just give you an idea of the current state of the game!  Result:-> The fantastic graphics, love to details and the variety of characters, pets, enemies and maps, make this one of my favorite games. I spent over 440 hours on this game so far and donÂ´t regret anything. The Trendy team is friendly and listens to the community. Constant patches with new characters, challenges, maps and much more keep the game interesting and fun. Just keep in mind that the game is in development and still contains some bugs and balance issues, but overall I can totally recommend you to test it out yourself, you wonÂ´t regret it!!

content:
Posted: February 8, 2016
Early Access Review
								It's DD1 with upgraded visuals. Very enjoyable. For a while.It lacks all the little things, the depth, that makes you want to keep playing the game beyond the first 10-15 hours.In DD1, you could really delve into stats, builds, and have fun with varied maps and challenges. Plus, there was an actual feel of progression. Here, you grind through a lvl 30 map until you get to the level cap (50), simply because it's better than any other gamemode or map when it comes to XP per hour per effort.In truth, if DD2 didn't kill all activity on DD1, I'd still be playing DD1.This game is not an improvement. It's a dumbed down game with better graphics.But the potentional is there.

								Games like these are the ones that you would spend the whole day playing, but since this is only alpha and not the full release, your area and items are limited, but there are alot to choose from. Although, your time on playing the game isn't that fun after you crash. For me I keep crashing for every 6 to 7 hours, then I have to do a process to get back to the game. I sort of found a way to get back to your game again, but even if you do the process,the game will still crash. Overall, this game is fun, really fun and especially with your friends, but it can be ruined when your game suddenly crashed and you can't get back on it. content:
Posted: April 23
Early Access Review
								You know, I used to enjoy this game.  To be honest, it used to be my favorite game, until chaos came out.  I came back after a few months of not playing, due to more recent games like overwatch.  I came back to see that all of my spheres, which made it super fun to play, were deleted.  iPwr, which I spent about 200 hours farming, just to be able to finish Nightmare IV, which is now gone, has been deleted as well.  All of my kits I had spent so long building, and all of the friends I had spent so long gaining, are now gone.  Even my friends are reccomending me to quit, which I might as well do until the previous game I used to love comes back.  My kits for Nightmare IV are still there, just not as effective due to the removal of spheres.  My shields for the squire went from having approximately 500K to 55K.  My Poison Dart Towers went from about 15K dps to 1k dps.  I instantly was furious.  I had spent so much time, just to watch all of my hard work crumble right before me.  I shall not be returning to this game, until I see on the youtube channel that there was an update allowing spheres again.  Thank you to those who read this extensive review, but to be honest, I would not reccomend this game anymore.  Maybe previously, but not now.

content:
Posted: December 9, 2014
Early Access Review
								First 2hrs, already impressed. In my opinnion for its current stage is a big improvement from DD1. Hopefully when its on its final release the anti-cheat will stop the hackers. Since it will be free. So far I rate it 8/10. Great game! Must buy if you got the cash!^ 12/13/2014------ Updated Review.Now for a better review as I have more game time.Straight off we will start yes this game is lacking some very needed functions or should I  say core elements for the game, as trading or even just to drop items in your tavern should be in but I am just going to leave that as it's still in Pre Alpha.As you journey on playing the difficulty "Normal" on some levels if you are new or unexperienced, the levels seem to be some what difficult for someone new to the game. If you are playing alone that is. As again you are meant to play with people, More people more chance of bonus loot(better loot) 4 Players becomes a large chance of good loot.From DD1, I can say that the towers have been nerfed? That don't seem to feel do as much damage as I would rather expect. I was suprised when they had said there wasn't going to be PvP, slightly dissapointed but it isn't that much of a big deal as I got the game to play with friends. Graphics:In my opinnion I think they are a lot better then the previous dungeon defenders and truly like the new graphcs! But again I miss the more cartoony side of the old DD not sure if that makes sense but can't really explain it. - Overall: 7.5/10Maps:Great maps, so far loved all of them! each map is unique and some what different in a way wether your helping crystals or just a cart. Overall: 9/10AI:AI are great, so far there are some great monsters/enemys to verse in DD2, they have annouced there will be more enemys which is great and excited about that! overall: 6.5/10Towers:So far I've played as Monk, Apprentice and Squire. From what my experiences have been the towers lack power as they had more power in DD1. other then that I really like the desings of some towers that are in the current DD2. Overall 5/10Taverns:It can be quite confusing as there is an "Entry Tavern" and a "Private Tavern" (Not sure if there was a public tavern as I played in private groups) And going to the war recruiter is a bit annoying as if you have a player thats 1 level below the war recruiters you can't play, I guess it's to stop boosters? Eh overall: 6/10Inventory:Inventory is really basic at the moment all though, the "Temporary bag"(if your bags full it goes there) just seems to be endless and you can keep getting items not sure if that was intetnional or what. Inventory can be a bit buggy, you can purchase a "Small Bag" for $10,000 In-game Credits and a "Large Bag" for $50,000 In-Game credits. I am not sure if I like this or not, I haven't purchased one as I don't need it. But seems pretty cool. Each item you get can be transferred to other characters ( just stays in your inv) which is handy as same does your money transfers across, I am not sure what happened but a mate and I both got the game at the same time, played same time and he ended up with $40,000 and I had $13,000 but had collected close to same amount of coins laying around. Not sure what happened. Overall 8.5/10Money system:I like how they approched this, insted of Mana being your currecny it's gold. Which is great! Overall: 8/10Overall:Still think with everything I have mentioned it is a fun game, and it is great to participate in the development of this game. Rating:7/10Worth Buying?:Yes and no. It all really depends on yourself. Do you want to support or just wait?If you want to help development then sure go right ahead, but aside that there are a lot of bug's that will be fixed in the near future hopefully but still great game and I do personally think it's worth buying.

content:
Posted: July 7, 2016
Early Access Review
								Loved Dungeon Defenders I.  Dungeon Defenders II is a steaming pile of poop.  It isn't ready for release to the public at all and I'm very, very unhappy that they charged a fee for a game in this state.  I originally bought the game months ago (it's 7/7/16 now), and as of yesterday the game is still garbage.  I feel insulted and I feel like I was taken advantage of.  I spent more than a decade making games professionally, and what I see in this "released" game is horrible.The biggest problem with the first game appears to be that the art direction (which I think is lovely) attracts an incredibly young player base who isn't particularly suited to strategy gameplay.  The sequel seems to be lining up to be the same mess of incredibly young player population who play selfishly rather than cooperatively even at the cost of losing the match, and prefer to have their characters speed leveled by high level games rather than earning their levels and actually learning how to play the character classes and the maps.I wouldnât consider recommending this game to anyone for any reason in its current state.  After the game is actually in a completed state I would recommend it as I would the original game, if you have a player group already assembled who can play together, go for it.  But, as an adult  it isnât worth the time to deal with the immature player population.

content:
Posted: July 23, 2016
Early Access Review
								Free to play in every sense of the word. Pets need to be fed with a special item, which you can buy with money, or with in game moey (at fastly increased prices) but DOES drops... sometimes. New characters need to be bought, anything beyond the first 4 at least.Chests drop that you need to buy keys for (this is by far the most aggregious of the examples IMO)If you had just made this game pay to play, as Dungeon Defenders 1 was, this game would have been at the top of my list in fun games to play. It's a shame, too, they made a lot of improvements to the game over DD1. (They stil have player collision with other players though, such an oversight in a multiplayer coop game.) A shame indeed.Do not play this game. It will waste your time, as you need to spend more money than the game is actually worth to get any enjoyment out of it.

content:
Posted: July 25, 2016
Early Access Review
								So many things went wrong in execution. It took many great features from the first game and then split them into a microtransaction format. Not necessarily a horrible thing, except they made it unusually expensive to have; almost like someone thought people will pay the ridiculous prices solely from loving the first game.Of the things it kept in, they expanded in poor ways. The larger environments don't have anything to keep them going. One thing about the first game was how tight and well designed its levels were, but that's gone now. It's like the microtransaction model was made to rely on past players, but the design doesn't attract them.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
Early Access Review
								The game is just so bland and unoriginal.In their previous game each hero actually had a selection of towers to defend with. Here you get 4 for each but expect to only be using like one or two of them.I liked the monk in the first game so I picked him again here. My job is to put up boost auras on each tower and then baby sit them all. My lightning field just doesn't help all that much and it's much better to just boost the mages fire tower.So the strat me and my brother have been using it. Mage shield, mage fire tower and then boost aura. Every single time we played it. Not even the slightest hint of being able to change anything with the setup.It's boring, soul crushingly boring.Also you basically get up the setup on the first and second round and after that it's mainly buffing up the towers.Tl:dr version: Developers added bare minimum in terms of towers and variation and it's making the game pretty damn boring.Get Orc Must Die 1 and 2 if you want a quality Tower Defense game. Some actual planning in those two games.

content:
Posted: March 8
Early Access Review
								The UI in this game might be one of the worst I've ever interacted with. The game itself looks pretty, but the user experience, navigating between screens, and not to mention the controls for the xbox controller really are not intuitive. This on top of the fact that they removed literally the best part of the game - the local co-op. I used to play this with my wife, and friends in split screen and it was awesome during the first dungeon defenders. It sounded like they had planned to add local co op back in, and so my friends and i were stoked for more awesome lan party play, it really made this game unique. Now its a WOW wanna be, and just lost its magic. Kinda like you had a great thing going and broke it.I'll update this review if they ever fix the menus, controller issues, UI, UX, and add in local co-op. But until then, I'm gonna sadly stay away from it. If you're looking for the great experience you had in the first one, you won't find it here sadly.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 13, 2015
Early Access Review
								           So, I've written two other reviews, and I'm coming back to write a 3rd. What can I say? I bought the first Dungeon Defenders on my Playstation 3, loved it, so I purchased it on my pc with all of the DLC. One of my all time favorite games, this one had a lot to live up to. So does it? Heck yeah it does! I purchased the game on Early Access, and let me just say that this is Early Access done right! With so many dev teams abusing the Early Access platform on steam, this definetly gives me hope for Early Access in general. The developers respond to feedback and even allow players to vote for changes to the game on the launcher. Early Adopters were rewarded with $30 of in-game currency as well as a unique cosmetic for each of the 4 heroes currently available in the game (although I do wish the items were a little flashier for bragging purposes :D) I would say the campaign is a bit shorter than the original, and develops the story very little. I would assume that expansions are on their way, as I cannot stress enough how little the plot progresses, so if you're looking for a full story, you won't find it yet.             But how's the gameplay? The tower defense is amazing, although there are many tower's that haven't returned or have been altered significantly. But to make up for this, there are a few new towers. Hero spells have also been changed, and a whole new type of energy is used for them, which frees you up. You don't have to choose between using hero abilities, or getting that tower upgrade you desperately need. The action element of the game definetly feels nice, but you won't find yourself being able to completely ditch towers like you could with a maxed barb or huntress in the first Dungeon Defenders. You could argue that this is actually a plus though.            Should you buy it? F2P? YES! What are you waiting for!? P2P? YES! The Devs deserve the support! But I recommend trying it F2P first, just to make sure it's your thing.

								Dungeon Defenders 2 is by far my favorite tower defense game ever, It surpasses DD1 buy leaps and bounds by making the game more than just towers, the player needs to pay attention to the map and attack more difficult monsters to complete the missions, although there are some problems with their servers, but when I talked to them on twitter they said "There are starting to be some issues with the way our backend service handles all of the matchmaking requests coming in so quickly" and they also said that they have engineers working on the servers throughout the week of 10/19/15, I believe once the servers are working normally, DD2 will be an amazing game...
